{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "nr": 1, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-01T20:02:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gd6v7134AUa", "data": "lqvcjvt8bnu7j4", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-01T20:02:01Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gd6v7134AUa", "subject": "Welcome to Piazza!", "created": "2024-01-01T20:02:01Z", "content": " Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:
  1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).
  2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).
  3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.
  4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.
  5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.
  6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.
  7. View and download class details and resources.
Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0103"], "nr": 14, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-08T19:17:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lr5b1gp0rpk5xn", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-08T19:17:24Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "data": "lr5b9sw4yul3cb", "to": "lr5b1gow915xm", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-08T19:23:53Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A1 PCE Clarification on first example", "created": "2024-01-08T19:17:24Z", "content": "

Hello, i was wondering if someone could clarify where the 1/4 (highlighted) came from in this example on the A1 PCE. Do you need to multiple the antiderivative 1/2 (e^2x) by some value and why?

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 150, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-08T19:23:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Aqsam Chaudhary", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1sqfpt3ux", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Manahil Saeed", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm562039i1l1bg", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ziyun Gui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk729f7y11q", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-08T19:23:53Z", "content": "The antiderivative of e^2x is 1/2e^2x (you can verify with the substitution rule we learned last semester). In this case we have the integral of 1/2e^2x. We can factor out the 1/2. Then we end up with 1/2 * 1/2 * e^2x as being the result of integrating 1/2*e^2x"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["jvbpijsmgxy40f", "lm7ul1sqfpt3ux", "lm562039i1l1bg", "lm7uk729f7y11q"], "children": [], "id": "lr5b9svzi3p3c9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr5b1gow915xm", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716172861054, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello,

The way that I have learned integration by parts was that u and v were the 2 parts of the integrand, and du and dv were the derivatives. Although in the pce, they made the 2 parts of the integrand u and dv. (Shouldn’t they have been u and v)?

IMG_7602.jpeg

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A1 PCE question", "created": "2024-01-08T21:02:43Z", "content": "

Hello,

The way that I have learned integration by parts was that u and v were the 2 parts of the larger term, and du and dv were the derivatives. Although in the pce, they made the 2 parts of the integrand u and dv. (Shouldn’t they have been u and v)?

IMG_7602.jpeg

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A1 PCE question", "created": "2024-01-08T21:02:21Z", "content": "

Hello,

The way that I have learned integration by parts, my u and v were the 2 parts of the larger term, and du and dv were the derivatives. Although in the pce, they made the 2 parts of the integrand u and dv. (Shouldn’t they have been u and v)?

IMG_7602.jpeg

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 141, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T04:59:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-09T04:59:12Z", "content": "IBP is used when an integrant is a product of a function and a derivative of another function (we called them $$u$$ and $$d v$$). {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0103"], "nr": 17, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T00:29:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lr5m73uau044mu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-09T00:29:43Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lr5pgr89rluj0", "to": "lr5m73u728t4mt", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-09T02:01:12Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lr5pr8ndfhz67p", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-09T02:09:21Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lr5prqpgjg6ou", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-09T02:09:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Problem Question from Lecture Today", "created": "2024-01-09T00:29:43Z", "content": "

I just need clarification on why we take the absolute value of the numerator |x+3|? Also, how to intuitively know when to take the absolute value? Is it because of the square root, which causes it to become an absolute value?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 153, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T02:01:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Matthew Desmarais", "endorser": {"k3t0tl7krg32to": 1579115969, "k52y9qu3rg41mr": 1584116403, "global": 1587066490, "k38wsyi5wxb1hz": 1587254389, "ktdwmksib25673": 1634571238, "kt03zgk52gf2vz": 1634684358}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ryan Bahlawan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul50mkwy46n", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-09T02:09:44Z", "content": "

We arrive at $$|x+3|$$ from the identity $$\forall x\in\mathbb{R}\ \left(\sqrt{x^2}=|x|\right)$$. Thus you are correct in saying the square root is the source of the absolute value.

I leave full proof to you, but the outline is as follows. We define the principal square root of a number $$x\in\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$$ to be the number $$y\in\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$$ such that $$y^2=x$$, and we denote this $$\sqrt{x}$$. Normally we have that $$k^2=(k)(k)=(-k)(-k)$$ for any number $$k$$, but when we take the principal square root we only get back $$k$$, even if we originally had $$-k$$. This is the same effect as taking the absolute value.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-09T02:09:21Z", "content": "

We arrive at $$|x+3|$$ from the identity $$\forall x\in\mathbb{R}\ \left(\sqrt{x^2}=|x|\right)$$. Thus you are correct in saying the square root is the source of the absolute value.

I leave full proof it to you, but the outline is as follows. We define the principal square root of a number $$x\in\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$$ to be the number $$y\in\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$$ such that $$y^2=x$$, and we denote this $$\sqrt{x}$$. Normally we have that $$k^2=(k)(k)=(-k)(-k)$$ for any number $$k$$, but when we take the principal square root we only get back $$k$$, even if we originally had $$-k$$. This is the same effect as taking the absolute value.

Hi, 

I think this would be a question given to test knowledge of trig substitution. You have to look at the integral and the relationship between the terms, and think what trig relationships you know which have these same appearances. tan^2(x) +1 = sec^2(x) comes to mind. Then make the substitution for x = tan(u) to make that relationship appear in the integral. Hopefully my own understanding is correct: 

Edit: After reviewing the topic, there are three distinct patterns which you should be familiar with and one of these is sqrt(a^2+x^2) as seen in this question. Based on which you are presented with, you should make a decision on which trig substitution to make (and each pattern consistently has its own trig ratio which is used). Like I said above, for a^2+x^2 (here a =1), we are looking to make a substitution x=a*tan(theta) (this substitution is derived from Pythagorean triangle length relationships)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ali Alizada", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f0oonxcv9r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 152, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-10T05:07:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-10T05:09:51Z", "content": "

There's an error in the substitution for $$\sqrt{1+9x^2}$$. You define $$x=\frac{1}{3}\tan(\theta)\Rightarrow\tan(\theta)=\frac{3x}{1}$$, so the adjacent side of the right-angled triangle with angle $$\theta$$ is equal to $$1$$ and the opposite side is equal to $$3x$$. By the Pythagorean theorem, we know that the hypotenuse is equal to $$\sqrt{1+9x^2}$$.


Returning to the integral, we have $$\sqrt{1+9x^2}=\frac{\sqrt{1+9x^2}}{1}=\sec(\theta)$$ (the hypotenuse on the adjacent side). So the denominator in the second line should be $$\sec(\theta)$$ not $$\frac{1}{3}\sec{\theta}$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-10T05:07:35Z", "content": "

Il y a un erreur dans la substitution pour $$\sqrt{1+9x^2}$$. Vous définissez $$x=\frac{1}{3}\tan(\theta)\Rightarrow\tan(\theta)=\frac{3x}{1}$$, donc le côté adjacent du triangle rectangle avec l'angle $$\theta$$ est égal à $$1$$ et le côté opposé est égal à $$3x$$. Par le théorème de Pythagore, on sait que l'hypoténuse est égal à $$\sqrt{1+9x^2}$$.

Retournant à l'intégrale, on a $$\sqrt{1+9x^2}=\frac{\sqrt{1+9x^2}}{1}=\sec(\theta)$$ (l'hypoténuse sur le côté adjacent). Donc le dénominateur dans le deuxième ligne devrait être $$\sec(\theta)$$ pas $$\frac{1}{3}\sec{\theta}$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lr7bkazzqtv6e6", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Is the error due to the fact that I treated tanθ=x/(1/3) instead of tanθ=3x/1?

When you have a coefficient for x, how would that change the process?

", "created": "2024-01-10T05:30:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

It still works if you use $$\tan(\theta)=\frac{x}{\frac{1}{3}}$$ but the process is a little different. In this case, the opposite side is equal to $$x$$, the adjacent side is equal to $$\frac{1}{3}$$ and the hypotenuse is equal to $$\sqrt{\frac{1}{9}+x^2}=\frac{1}{3}\sqrt{1+9x^2}$$.

It follows that $$\sec(\theta)=\frac{\frac{1}{3}\sqrt{1+9x^2}}{\frac{1}{3}}=\sqrt{1+9x^2}$$. So the denominator should still be $$\sec(\theta)$$ not $$\frac{1}{3}\sec(\theta)$$.

The coefficient in front of $$x$$ doesn't change the process; we use different values for the triangle, but we still use the same link between the sides (trigonmetric functions).

Hi, 

I was wondering whether knowledge of integration by partial fraction decomposition is required for Question 3 of Webwork 1? I won't show my answer but I was able to simplify all the way down to [algebraic terms + integral (1/(x^2-1))]. I can do this last integral with partial fractions, but was curious whether we could evaluate Q3 entirely without the use of partial fractions since I think the WW is due before we would learn this topic. 

Thanks

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "subject": "WebWork 1 Q3", "created": "2024-01-10T22:43:17Z", "content": "

Hi, 

I was wondering whether knowledge of integration by partial fraction decomposition is required for Question 3 of Webwork 1? I won't show my answer but I was able to simplify all the way down to [algebraic terms + integral (1/(x^2-1))]. I can do this last integral with partial fractions, but was curious whether we could evaluate Q3 entirely without the use of partial fractions since I think the WW is due before we would learn this topic. 

Thanks

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0103"], "nr": 47, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-11T00:50:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lr8htkmxb5x3ca", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-11T00:50:31Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lr8inq62fv66gr", "to": "lr8htkmshp73c8", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-11T01:13:58Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lr8jnh007vynm", "to": "lr8htkmshp73c8", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-11T01:41:46Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lecture A1 Q6", "created": "2024-01-11T00:50:31Z", "content": "

For the 4th and 7th question, how did you do it? 
Also, is the derivative of arctan something I should know as basic knowledge? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 118, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-11T01:13:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Cynthia Wei", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llyn3ipyfn37ep", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-11T01:13:58Z", "content": "

For the 4th I first use integration by parts ($$u=\tan^{-1}(x)$$ and $$dv=1\,dx$$) then a substitution ($$k=x^2+1$$) for the remaining integral.

For the 7th, you can remove $$x^2$$ from the integral because it concerns $$t$$, not $$x$$.

The derivative of the function $$\arctan$$ is not difficult to find; use the equation $$\tan(y)=x$$ with implicit differentiation.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["llyn3ipyfn37ep"], "children": [], "id": "lr8inq5z63e6gp", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-11T01:41:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-11T01:41:46Z", "content": "There is a partial solution posted on Quercus under the lecture page. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lr8jngzz9dunl", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr8htkmshp73c8", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716172896851, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 56, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-11T17:41:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lr9hx4l3ssa2cj", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-11T17:41:03Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lr9hxy42in93hl", "to": "lr9hx4l0sz42ci", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-11T17:41:42Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lr9luszbgx61m5", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-11T19:31:13Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Derivative of inverse trig functions", "created": "2024-01-11T17:41:03Z", "content": "Are we expected to know how to differentiate inverse trigonometric functions?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-11T17:41:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Justin Fang", "endorser": {"lmebuo1hd0t46v": 1698703109}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm75necjjjm23z", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-11T19:31:13Z", "content": "

did we not learn this last term…?

(From another student) Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions were in the MAT186 learning objectives, so they assume you already know them.

If you need a reminder, you calculate them as follows (I'm only showing you the derivative of $$\arcsin$$, but the process is similar for the others):

$$\arcsin(x)=y\implies \sin(y)=x,\ x\in[-1,1]$$. Taking the derivative of both sides with respect to $$x$$ we have $$\cos(y)\frac{dy}{dx}=1\implies\frac{dy}{dx}=\sec(y)$$. Using a reference triangle, we find that $$\sec(y)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$$, so $$\frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$$ for $$x\in[-1,1]$$.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-11T17:41:42Z", "content": "did we not learn this last term…?"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm75necjjjm23z"], "children": [], "id": "lr9hxy3ya553hk", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "lm7ukgfqdy6208"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr9hx4l0sz42ci", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716172906622, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 99, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-12T02:50:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-12T03:50:06Z", "content": "

They used the fact that $$\int\csc(\theta)\,d\theta=-\ln\left|\csc(\theta)-\cot(\theta)\right|+C$$ (a proof can be found here).

Regarding how you find this result yourself, first start with the definition of an antiderivative. In this case, a function whose derivative equals $$\csc(x)$$.

We start with the functions $$\csc$$ and $$\cot$$ because $$\frac{d}{dx}\csc(x)=-\csc(x)\cot(x)$$ and $$\frac{d}{dx}\cot(x)=-\csc^2(x)$$. These are not what we want, but they're close.

Remember that $$\frac{d}{dx}\ln\left|f(x)\right|=\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$$. So if we can find a function whose derivative contains itself, we can create it in our integral by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same expression.

Let $$g(x)=\cot(x)+\csc(x)$$. So $$g'(x)=-\csc^2(x)-\csc(x)\cot(x)=-\csc(x)\left[\csc(x)+\cot(x)\right]=-\csc(x)g(x)$$. We've found a function that satisfies the criteria in the previous paragraph. Moreover, $$g'(x)$$ contains $$csc(x)$$, so we don't need to manipulate the integral any further.

Using this function $$g(x)=\cot(x)+\csc(x)$$, we have that $$\int\csc(\theta)\,d\theta$$

$$\displaystyle=\int(-1)(-1)\csc(\theta)\frac{g(\theta)}{g(\theta)}\,d\theta$$

$$\displaystyle=\int\frac{\csc(\theta)\left[\csc(\theta)+\cot(\theta)\right]}{\csc(\theta)+\cot(\theta)}\,d\theta$$

$$\displaystyle=-\int\frac{-\csc\left[\csc(\theta)+\cot(\theta)\right]}{\csc(\theta)+\cot(\theta)}\,d\theta$$

$$\displaystyle=-\ln\left|\csc(\theta)+\cot(\theta)\right|+C$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-12T02:50:59Z", "content": "They used the fact that $$\int\csc(\theta)=-\ln\left|\csc(\theta)-\cot(\theta)\right|+C$$ (un preuve se trouve ici)."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukgfqdy6208"], "children": [], "id": "lra1kc4qm2o778", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr9x96xh8994c9", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716172912045, "default_anonymity": "no"}

An easier way to have integrated your ln(x-1) and ln(x+1) is to just use the ln integration formula which is xlnx-x, but in this case you would sub in (x-1) where ever you see an x in the formula. Check the integral of ln(x+1) for example. For simplicity I just kept my constant over the entire final integral.

It also looks like you did your integration correctly with the first method, but you just inputted it incorrectly into WeBWorK (You didn't include the absolute values for the natural logarithm).

For your second method, you should integrate $$\frac{1}{x^2-1}$$ using partial fractions decomposition. I would say that the second method is "easier" and more "standard" than the first method, as integrating the natural log can be prone to mistakes (chain rule and such).

No, you've made a mistake.

Starting where they left off, you need to check that the integrand is continuous (and therefore defined) on the interval $$\left[\frac{2\pi}{3},\pi\right]$$ before you can simplify it (this is actually the case here, but I'll leave the proof to you). The rest of the solution follows.

$$\displaystyle\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \frac{\sqrt{16\sec^2(\theta)-16}}{4\sec(\theta)} \cdot 4\sec(\theta)\tan(\theta) \, d\theta$$

$$\displaystyle=\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi 4\sqrt{\sec^2(\theta)-1}\cdot\tan(\theta) \, d\theta \qquad \forall x\in\mathbb{R} : \sec(x) \ne 0$$

$$\displaystyle=4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \sqrt{\tan^2(\theta)}\cdot\tan(\theta) \, d\theta \qquad \forall x\in\mathbb{R}\setminus\left\{\frac{\pi}{2}+k\;\middle|\;k\in\mathbb{Z}\right\} : \sec^2(x)-1=\tan^2(x)$$

$$\displaystyle=4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \left|\tan(\theta)\right|\tan(\theta) \, d\theta \qquad \forall x\in\mathbb{R} : \sqrt{x^2}=|x|$$

$$\displaystyle=4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi -\tan(\theta)\tan(\theta) \, d\theta \qquad \forall{x\in\left[\frac{2\pi}{3},\pi\right]} : \tan(x) \le 0$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \tan^2(\theta) \, d\theta$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \left(\sec^2(\theta)-1\right) \, d\theta \qquad \forall x\in\mathbb{R}\setminus\left\{\frac{\pi}{2}+k\;\middle|\;k\in\mathbb{Z}\right\} : \sec^2(x)-1=\tan^2(x)$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\Big[\tan(\theta)-\theta\Big]_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\left[\left(\tan(\pi)-\pi\right)-\left(\tan\left(\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)-\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)\right]$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\left(0+\sqrt{3}-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) = 4\left(\frac{\pi}{3}-\sqrt{3}\right)$$

Non, vous vous êtes trompé.

Commençant où ils ont arrêté, il faut vérifier que l'intégrande est continue (et donc défini) sur l'intervalle $$\left[\frac{2\pi}{3},\pi\right]$$ avant qu'on peut le simplifier (c'est en fait le cas ici, mais je laisse le preuve à vous). Le reste de la solution est suivant :

$$\displaystyle\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \frac{\sqrt{16\sec^2(\theta)-16}}{4\sec(\theta)} \cdot 4\sec(\theta)\tan(\theta) \, d\theta$$

$$\displaystyle=\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi 4\sqrt{\sec^2(\theta)-1}\cdot\tan(\theta) \, d\theta \qquad \forall x\in\mathbb{R} : \sec(x) \ne 0$$

$$\displaystyle=4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \sqrt{\tan^2(\theta)}\cdot\tan(\theta) \, d\theta \qquad \forall x\in\mathbb{R}\setminus\left\{\frac{\pi}{2}+k\;\middle|\;k\in\mathbb{Z}\right\} : \sec^2(x)-1=\tan^2(x)$$

$$\displaystyle=4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \left|\tan(\theta)\right|\tan(\theta) \, d\theta \qquad \forall x\in\mathbb{R} : \sqrt{x^2}=|x|$$

$$\displaystyle=4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi -\tan(\theta)\tan(\theta) \, d\theta \qquad \forall{x\in\left[\frac{2\pi}{3},\pi\right]} : \tan(x) \le 0$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \tan^2(\theta) \, d\theta$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi \left(\sec^2(\theta)-1\right) \, d\theta \qquad \forall x\in\mathbb{R}\setminus\left\{\frac{\pi}{2}+k\;\middle|\;k\in\mathbb{Z}\right\} : \sec^2(x)-1=\tan^2(x)$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\Big[\tan(\theta)-\theta\Big]_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\left[\left(\tan(\pi)-\pi\right)-\left(\tan\left(\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)-\frac{2\pi}{3}\right)\right]$$

$$\displaystyle=-4\left(0+\sqrt{3}-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) = 4\left(\frac{\pi}{3}-\sqrt{3}\right)$$

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 72, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T20:20:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrcihe777u42o1", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-13T20:20:07Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrcr6zxdyyt2en", "to": "lrcihe74xb52o0", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-14T00:23:59Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Absolute values in Indefinite Integrals", "created": "2024-01-13T20:20:07Z", "content": "

Hi im having trouble understanding conceptually the whole idea of bounds when preforming trig substitution on integrals. What are we bounding? Additionally why are we able to drop the absolute value when preforming indefinite integrals? Here is an example below.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Chris Mak", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1695815518}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-14T00:23:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Boris Potapov", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llyhj9awro63lb", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-14T00:23:59Z", "content": "

When we use trigonometric substitution (in fact, whenever we define something), we can impose any condition on $$\theta$$ as long as the definition is valid for all $$x$$ in the domain.

The domain of $$f(x)=\sqrt{9-x^2}$$ is $$[-3,3]$$, thus we deduce that $$x\in[-3,3]$$. The utilised substitution appears to be $$\frac{x}{3}=\sin(\theta)$$. Notice that $$\frac{x}{3}\in[-1,1]$$.

When we arrive at the expression $$3\left|\cos(\theta)\right|$$ we would be stuck if we have only $$\theta\in\mathbb{R}$$, since then we have that $$\cos(\theta)\in[-1,1]$$.

Let us use the condition $$\theta\in(-\frac{\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2}]$$ One can verify that there exists $$\theta$$ such that $$\frac{x}{3}=\sin(\theta)$$ for all $$x$$ in the domain. Notice that now $$\cos(\theta)\ge0$$ for all $$\theta$$. With this condition, we can now safely remove the absolute value bars.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "llyhj9awro63lb"], "children": [], "id": "lrcr6zx8p62em", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukgfqdy6208", "lm7ukqff3d82v1"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrcihe74xb52o0", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716172924028, "default_anonymity": "no"}

In the case of non-repeated roots, the referenced facts are (probably) a combination of Bézout's Identity, the fundamental theorem of algebra and polynomial Euclidean division. See the following links:

  1. https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/48051/the-existence-of-partial-fraction-decompositions
  2. https://proofwiki.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zout's_Identity
  3. https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/368665/derivation-of-the-general-forms-of-partial-fractions

This paper gives two approaches to the proof. A linear algebraic one, and an algebraic one. Note that (as mentioned in PCE) this proof is way beyond the scope of the course, however, you are already familiar with all the ideas that go into the linear algebraic proof. 

https://www.m-hikari.com/imf/imf-2012/29-32-2012/cookIMF29-32-2012.pdf

Hi, 

I was wondering what exactly Q1 of the PCE was actually asking? I know exactly how to do PFD but am unsure; 

Are we asking about what the general PFD setup would be similar to Q2? Or whether we would come across any of these terms at all? For example, if we tried to solve this question with A / [linear] and B / [linear] then we would eventually see an Ax term if we actually separated out all of the numerator to solve. We would also see a B term. But, if we simply chose E and D instead of A and B, then we would see the general PFD setup just with letters that are not the first and second of the alphabet. And having all of these options simultaneously would be nonsensical for one fraction (we need only two distinct letters). 

So could someone clarify please? 

Thank you

From my understanding, the question is asking how you would separate the rational function into a sum of factors. 

Hint: The denominator can be factored into two factors, try expressing them as separate factors, and think about how it can be manipulated to get $$\displaystyle\frac{x-3}{x^2-1}$$. Then the answers should become apparent.

", "created": "2024-01-14T18:59:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The question asks you to select all the options that represent the general form for at least one term in the decomposition.

For example, if the question asked us to decompose $$\frac{3x+1}{(x+1)(x-2)}$$", we'd have the answer $$\frac{2}{3(x+1)}+\frac{7}{3(x-2)}$$. The general forms would be $$\frac{A}{x+1}$$ and $$\frac{B}{x-2}$$ respectively.

Thank you for posting your steps! I see one error:

Based on what you said:

$$u=x$$$$du=dx$$
$$v=\frac{1}{2}xf(2x)$$$$dv=f'(2x)dx$$

Your v term is integrated wrong, specifically, you're missing the $$\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}$$ in the v. See if that leads you to the correct answer.

", "created": "2024-01-14T19:56:55Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Om Patel", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699977470, "llax09p5hb11ji": 1700315642}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgc33a41zw", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "llyi7s8ecap62t", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I'm sorry, just a bit confused. I assumed the integral of f'(x) = f(x) and by that logic f'(2x) = f(2x). Where can I reference more information regarding why f'(2x) = 1/2xf(2x)?", "created": "2024-01-14T19:59:26Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrdx6mqvfz951y", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-01-14T19:59:26Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You're employing the derivative chain rule. When you differentiate $$f(2x)$$, you get $$f'(2x)dx$$ BUT you also have to take into consideration that $$2x$$ is a composite function of say $$g(x)=2x$$. So, by the chain rule, you have to multiply $$f'(2x)dx$$ by the derivative of $$2x$$, resulting in $$2f'(2x)dx$$.

So to eliminate the 2, the original $$f(2x)$$ term must have 1/2 as a coefficient to get $$\frac{1}{2}f'(2x)dx$$.

Asuming you're talking about increasing/decreasing the number of intervals (and not the size), no it should not affect whether the trapezoidal sum will be an over/underestimation.

\n

I have a quick question. Say I want to integrate $$\displaystyle\frac{x^3+6x^2+3x+6}{x^3+2x^2}$$. I turn it into a proper rational function and get $$\displaystyle1+\frac{x^2+3x+6}{x^3+2x^2}$$. 

When I decompose it, should it be like:

a) $$\displaystyle\frac{A}{x^2}+B(x+2)$$

b) $$\displaystyle\frac{A}{x}+\frac{B}{x^2}+C(x+2)$$ (asking because $$x^2$$ is a repeated term)

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A3 - PFD", "created": "2024-01-15T00:44:23Z", "content": "

I have a quick question. Say I want to integrate (x^3+6x^2+3x+6)/(x^3+2x^2). I turn it into a proper rational function and get 1 + (x^2+3x+6)/(x^3+2x^2). 

When I decompose it, should it be like:

a) A/x^2 + B(x+2)

b) A/x + B/x^2 + C(x+2) (asking because x^2 is a repeated term)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 106, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-15T01:10:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-15T01:10:29Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lre8anggnsg2qf", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Oh, that's interesting. When I looked it up on an online calculator, it went with option A. I was a bit confused about that because isn't x^2 a repeating factor?", "created": "2024-01-15T01:12:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Yes, x^2 is a repeating linear factor to the best of my knowledge. For example, if we had an x^4 term, we would have: 

A/x + B/x^2 + C/x^3 + D/x^4. 

For irreducible quadratics, a similar rule applies; only this time the numerator is a linear function as opposed to a constant.

This is for the A4 PCE (second one)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 91, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-15T02:46:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-15T02:47:03Z", "content": "

Bounds of integration can be negative or positive. They can be any two real numbers within the domain of the integrand. 

The bounds don't affect $$\tan^2 \theta$$. What they affect is the sign of $$\tan \theta$$, and hence the value of $$|\tan \theta|$$. To see this answer think about the following two questions:

1) Is $$\tan \theta $$ negative or positive within the given bound. 

2) What is the absolute value of a negative quantity

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 74, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Putting this here cause I don't know if this is the best answer but..

The way I approached it was looking to see how many times the denominator could go into the numerator (after setting up the divisor and dividend). You'd get 2 as the first term and then -multiply the divisor by 2 and subtract that expression from your dividend. The remaining expression would be 11x +64 in this case, which is also known as your remainder. Technically, to fully divide the numerator expression by the denominator, we'd need to continue division of the 11x+64 term by the denominator. However, given the fact that 11x+64 over the denominator is a proper rational function, we can go ahead and use PFD.

If you want to see the steps, I'd recommend a calculator like symbolab. Synthetic division is also a faster alternative.

Replace $$\sin(2\theta)$$ with $$2\sin(\theta)\cos(\theta)$$ (double angle identity) and then use a reference triangle.

In general, when we want to replace $$\theta$$ expressions with $$x$$ expressions, we need to use trigonometric identities to eliminate expressions of the form $$a\theta$$ where $$a\in\mathbb{R}$$.

For this question, how do you know which substitution to make?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0103"], "nr": 111, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-17T02:32:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrh644o2g8z3v3", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-17T02:32:44Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrh7t2buneq5lu", "to": "lrh644nz24j3v2", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-17T03:20:07Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A3 slides - example 6", "created": "2024-01-17T02:32:44Z", "content": "

In example 6 for lecture A3 (see picture), I don't understand how we knew to let the numerator be (Ax + B) and (Cx + D), as opposed to just A and B. Could someone please explain? Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 75, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-17T03:20:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-17T03:20:07Z", "content": "

Intuitive answer:

When we construct the decomposed terms, we only know the degree of the numerator is less than the degree of the denominator (as otherwise we may perform polynomial division). In the case of quadratic denominators, all we can guarantee is that the numerator is at most a linear term.

We thus construct an arbitrary linear term with two coefficients, with the possiblility of the linear coefficient being zero should it turn out we only need the constant.

Full answer:

The theorem guaranteeing the existance of the decomposition states that the terms with quadratic denominators may have linear numerators -- see W.T. Bradley and W.J. Cook for a proof of the theorem.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0101"], "nr": 121, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T01:29:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrijalrsgiu2vy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-18T01:29:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "l79etwepln061q", "data": "lril27cmsco5hq", "to": "lrijalrovmp2vw", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-18T02:18:55Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "midpoint rule vs trapezoid rule", "created": "2024-01-18T01:29:27Z", "content": "

Why is it that this area (triangle BDF) included in the error for the trapezoid rule even though the error area is inside the function? Also why does it appear that the error of the midpoint rule is greater than the error for the trapezoid rule?

\n

The pink/peach color is the error for the midpoint rule, which here is illustrated as the tangent line through (m_i, f(m_i)).

Hello, I was a little confused on part b) for this question:

I tried taking the integral, but I can't seem to get the answer [f(b/2)]*b as was suggested during lecture. Could someone please help me on this part?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 112, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T16:58:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jessica Varriale", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukm34ttf2hc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T16:58:25Z", "content": "

Remember the general equation for the tangent line to the function f at $$x=k$$ : $$y(x)=f'(k)(x-k)+f(k)$$.

For the question, we have $$x=\frac{b}{2}$$, so the equation is $$y(x)=f'(\frac{b}{2})(x-\frac{b}{2})+f(\frac{b}{2})$$.

Taking the definite integral:

$$\int_0^b y(x)\,dx = \int_0^b f'\left(\frac{b}{2}\right)\left(x-\frac{b}{2}\right)+f\left(\frac{b}{2}\right)\,dx$$

$$=f'\left(\frac{b}{2}\right)\left[\int_0^b x\,dx - \frac{b}{2}\int_0^b dx\right] + f\left(\frac{b}{2}\right)\int_0^b dx$$ ; since $$f'\left(\frac{b}{2}\right),f\left(\frac{b}{2}\right)$$ constant

$$=f'\left(\frac{b}{2}\right)\left[\frac{b^2}{2}-\frac{b^2}{2}\right] + bf\left(\frac{b}{2}\right)$$

$$=bf\left(\frac{b}{2}\right)$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukm34ttf2hc", "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "kjvi78x7tda2lo"], "children": [], "id": "lrjgh99w5pwxe", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T20:13:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T20:14:40Z", "content": "Student's answer is complete."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T20:13:11Z", "content": "I posted the solutions for that question. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrjnfqamkh51e8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrjfcre01d11wi", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716172991308, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Clearly 2 is an upper bound for f(x), since f(x)<=2 for all x. But it isn't a very good upper bound. The least upper bound on an interval is the smallest such constant M such that f(x)<=M on that interval. So the least upper bound for sin(x) over the real numbers is 1.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 140, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T19:05:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrjl09826nj1px", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-18T19:05:10Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "lrjm7g6nstkqo", "to": "lrjl097ycd21pv", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-18T19:38:45Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Textbook Question (Pg 322) Example 3.44", "created": "2024-01-18T19:05:10Z", "content": "

I had a question regarding one of the textbook questions for error bounds (Image linked below). I was just wondering, for the |f"(x)|, how do you find its max value, as shown in the textbook as |f \u2033(x)| = 2e(x^2)(1+2x^2)\u2264 2 \u00b7 e \u00b7 3 = 6e? Can I only find 6e by graphing the function or is there a formula to do so? Thank you for the help.

\n

Screenshot_2024-01-18_134824.png

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T19:38:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Cheraldine", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk2hzunvawj3nc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T19:38:45Z", "content": "In this case, we just look at the formula for f''(x), that being $$2 e^{x^{2}} (1 + 2x^2)$$, and then we find the max for each factor of that. So, in $$[0,1]$$ the max of $$x^2$$ is 1, so the max of $$1 + 2^{x^2}$$ is 3 and the max of $$e^{x^2}$$ is $$e$$, so we put it all together and see that the maximum of the expression is 6e.

This is basically how you'll always do it, not exactly a formula but often straightforward. Though, it's less straightforward when you have some parts of the expression that can be negative. Then you have to check whether each part will contribute to the overall expression being bigger if it was positive or negative.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lk2hzunvawj3nc"], "children": [], "id": "lrjm7g6ij2zqm", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrjl097ycd21pv", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716172997832, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork"], "nr": 145, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T23:35:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrjun9b8wme6qo", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-18T23:35:00Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lrjv65v2wjg1nn", "to": "lrjun9b4xq76qn", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-18T23:49:42Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lrjv74n1xlg3ui", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-18T23:50:27Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lrjun9b4xq76qn", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-19T01:38:18Z", "cid": "lrjz1tmvwhr3hi", "uid_a": "a_2"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "lrjun9b4xq76qn", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-19T02:07:21Z", "cid": "lrk036tvwja4ny"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "webwork 2 problem 4", "created": "2024-01-18T23:35:00Z", "content": "

Hello,

I was wondering if anyone could steer me in the right direction to solve this question. I thought i would start by trying to use partial fraction decomposition, but it seems like I should simplify the expression first and I don't know how to find f(x). Any tips on how to get started with this question would be much appreciated.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 173, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T23:49:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T23:50:27Z", "content": "

The way I started this question is by writing out the general form of a quadratic: Ax^2+Bx+C. From this you can already determine one of the unknowns. 

Moving forward, since we are looking for the value of f'(0), taking the derivative of the quadratic in its general form and seeing what information we can derive might be helpful (very helpful). 

In the end, I did have to do a partial decomposition, and yes, there was a lot of terms. 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T23:49:42Z", "content": "

The way I started this question is by writing out the general form of a quadratic: Ax^2+Bx+C. From this you can already determine one of the unknowns. 

Moving forward, since we are looking for the value of f'(0), taking the derivative of the quadratic in its general form and seeing what information we can derive might be helpful (very helpful). 

In the end, I did have to do a partial composition, and yes, there was a lot of terms.

That height does refer to the height of the cone, as you labelled, and the radius just above it refers to the radius of the cone.

\n


The radius of the ball isn't the same as the radius of the cone

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk8uze41ca", "lm7ul1bsu483t3"], "children": [], "id": "lrk1jthxgn75gq", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-19T02:48:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Om Patel", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699977470, "llax09p5hb11ji": 1700315642}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgc33a41zw", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Eileen Yang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk8uze41ca", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jenny Chung", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-19T02:48:35Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 157, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-19T04:12:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrk4jiyfued1sq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-19T04:12:02Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrk4tfga6ci6m", "to": "lrk4jiybj8u1sp", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-19T04:19:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Hw 1 Q3b", "created": "2024-01-19T04:12:02Z", "content": "Is the denominator in the question e^(|x|+x^2) or e^(|x|)+x^2"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 144, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-19T04:19:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brayden Chan Carusone", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul6ini0p4au", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-19T04:19:44Z", "content": "I think it's $$e^{|x|}+x^2$$, where $$x^2$$ is not in the exponent of $$e$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul6ini0p4au"], "children": [], "id": "lrk4tfg6pas6l", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrk4jiybj8u1sp", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173016278, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Question 2b on the calc assignment seems to have changed, previously the bounds were given for the second and third derivative of velocity (which would help us find bounds for numerical schemes using the acceleration graph), now the question has been changed to the first and the second derivatives of velocity. This change would make sense if the graph given was also changed to velocity, however it remains as acceleration. I was just wondering if there has been some sort of mistake, or if the current version is the final version?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brayden Chan Carusone", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul6ini0p4au", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Justin Fang", "endorser": {"lmebuo1hd0t46v": 1698703109}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm75necjjjm23z", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 174, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "^^ and the function for 3b changed too", "created": "2024-01-19T04:15:12Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I think that was a typo correction, but yeah!! Recall that displacement is the velocity integral $$\int v(t)\,dt$$.

For the upper limits of approximation, we must therefore use the maximum of $$|v'|$$ and $$|v''|$$ for the right/left and middle/trapezoid sums respectively.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-19T16:03:18Z", "content": "

Recall that displacement is the velocity integral $$\int v(t)\,dt$$.

For the upper limits of approximation, we must therefore use the maximum of $$|v'|$$ and $$|v''|$$ for the right/left and middle/trapezoid sums respectively.

We use the acceleration graph to decide which approximation we would use, but it doesn't give us any information about accuracy limits.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-19T16:00:57Z", "content": "

This question does not depend on acceleration, since displacement is the velocity integral ($$\int v(t)\,dt$$).

For the upper limits of approximation, we must therefore use the maximum of $$|v'|$$ and $$|v''|$$ for the right/left and middle/trapezoid sums respectively.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kjvi78x7tda2lo"], "children": [], "id": "lrktv7ffhku787", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I understand that we would use those bounds if we were performing a numerical approximation on the velocity graph, however we are given the acceleration graph. I am confused whether we are applying the approximation methods on the given acceleration graph, or are we supposed to use the acceleration graph to find which approximation method would be used on the corresponding velocity graph. 

Following the latter line of thinking, here is an example: If the acceleration graph is + and decreasing we would know the velocity graph is increasing and concave down. And then we could choose an appropriate approximation method based off that. Ln and Tn would be under approx. Rn and Mn would be an over approx. etc.", "created": "2024-01-19T20:53:17Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukotj9jp2qd", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I'll probably make a separate post about this.", "created": "2024-01-19T20:54:02Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukotj9jp2qd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrl4c3uaavm3zz", "updated": "2024-01-19T20:54:02Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Generally for the + portions, if acceleration is positive then displacement will be positive. So you can just overestimate it. 

But if it’s -, you’d want to underestimate it, so displacement is the most.

", "created": "2024-01-19T21:00:48Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrl4ktpul6zkm", "updated": "2024-01-19T21:00:48Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Also, this was somewhat discussed in @97, but I'm still a little unsure.

(Assuming you want to find $$M$$ in the formula for the error of a right/left approximation)

Remember the process for finding the maximum/minimum value of a function -- you have to take the derivative and calculate its zeros, then evaluate the function at the zeros and endpoints.

With your method, you only evaluate the endpoints, so there is a possibility you missed the actual maximum/minimum. Thus you may calculate the wrong value of $$M$$.

The radius is technically constant, but depending how you're doing this question, I think you probably won't differentiate 'with respect to' the radius, exactly.

\n

For example, if you were trying to find the volume of the ball, you might define the height of the ball at a given x-position as a function, which would be non-constant, and so you could differentiate and not get zero.\u00a0

I guess just ask yourself in what context you're differentiating the radius

Do I just eyeball it and say that the left-hand side of the parabola is steeper than the other?

However, I am asking this question, as I feel like there are more accurate options than what I currently have.

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 171, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-19T21:23:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukotj9jp2qd", "data": "lrl5dt7oh793c3", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-19T21:23:21Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lrmu0ps27pf58z", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-01-21T01:40:46Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lrqgddx22uz7gv", "to": "lrl5dt7kzil3c2", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-23T14:29:48Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Homework Question 2 - acceleration graph", "created": "2024-01-21T01:40:46Z", "content": "

We are given the acceleration graph in question 2. I was wondering if we

1. are applying the approximation methods on the given acceleration graph,

or 

2. are we supposed to use the acceleration graph to find which approximation method would be used on a corresponding velocity graph?

The first method of thinking fits with the original v'' and v''' bounds given (since we'd apply these to get an error bound for the area under the acceleration graph). However these bounds were updated to v' and v'', which aligns better with the second method.

For the second line of thinking, here is an example: If the acceleration graph is + and decreasing we would know the velocity graph is increasing and concave down. And then we could choose an appropriate approximation method based off that. Ln and Tn would be under approx. Rn and Mn would be an over approx. etc.

This method of thinking matches with the given v' and v'' bounds, which would help us find bounds on the area under the velocity graph.

I also have a bonus question that I've asked before, but hasn't been fully addressed. Are we only allowed to use each approximation method once over the 4 intervals? Or can I use the same one multiple times? This question has received different answers in @154 and @130.

And then we could choose an appropriate approximation method based off that. Ln and Tn would be under approx. Rn and Mn would be an over approx. etc.

"Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T14:29:48Z", "content": "

Note that you are looking for displacement which is the area under the velocity curve. You should use teh data you are given, which is the acceleration graph, to determine which method should be used. Your line of thinking for 2 is correct. 

You don't have to use each method once. You can use them multiple times if you believe that the method gives you teh best approximation.

(Note: primitive is another word for antiderivative, for some reason my translator plugin prefers it

Note 2: the translator breaks with LaTeX; here are some words to help you read until I fix the translation manually:

« donc » = thus, « soit » = let, « mais » = but, « on a » = we have

the other words are cognates so they are what they look like in English)

Explication:

Let $$F(x)=\int_0^x |t|\,dt$$ (you can choose any real number for the lower limit, I use 0 because it's easier).


You're right that the area under the curve is always positive, but that doesn't mean that the primitive is similar. Remember that when $$x<0$$ the integral turns into $$-\int_x^0 f(t)\,dt$$. Since $$f(t)>0$$ for all $$t\in\mathbb{R}$$, the area is also positive, so $$-\int_x^0 f(t)\,dt < 0$$.

We know that $$x^2\ge 0$$ for all $$x$$, so it's impossible for $$x^2$$ to be the primitive.

Démonstration (informel)

Let $$F(x)=\int_0^x |t|\,dt$$ (I choose zero since it's easier, but any real number works).

If $$x\ge0$$, then $$\int_0^x t\,dt=\left.\frac{t^2}{2}\right\rvert_0^x=\frac{x^2}{2}$$. Otherwise if $$x<0$$ then $$\int_0^x -t\,dt=\left.-\frac{t^2}{2}\right\rvert_0^x=-\frac{x^2}{2}$$. It seems that

$$\displaystyle F(x)=\begin{cases} -\frac{x^2}{2} &x<0 \\ \phantom{-}\frac{x^2}{2} &x\ge 0. \end{cases}$$

We prove this as follows.  Let $$x<0$$. Thus $$F(x)=-\frac{x^2}{2}\implies F'(x)=-x$$. Next let $$x>0$$. Thus $$F(x)=\frac{x^2}{2}\implies F'(x)=x$$. Finally let $$x=0$$. The function is defined differently on the left and right, so we must use the definition of the derivative:

$$\displaystyle\lim\limits_{h\to 0^-} \frac{F(0+h)-F(0)}{h} =\lim\limits_{h\to 0^-} \frac{-\frac{h^2}{2}-0}{h} =\lim\limits_{h\to 0^-} -\frac{h}{2}=0$$

$$\displaystyle\lim\limits_{h\to 0^+} \frac{F(0+h)-F(0)}{h} =\lim\limits_{h\to 0^+} \frac{\frac{h^2}{2}-0}{h} =\lim\limits_{h\to 0^+} \frac{h}{2}=0$$.

Thus $$\lim\limits_{h\to 0} \frac{F(0+h)-F(0)}{h}=0$$, and by definition $$F'(0)$$ exists and equals zero.

Now we write $$F'$$ as a piecewise function (in the second case, when $$x=0$$ the expression evaluates to zero, so this is a valid description):

$$F'(x)=\begin{cases} -x & x<0 \\ x & x\ge 0. \end{cases}$$

But this is exactly the definition of absolute value, thus $$F'(x)=|x|$$, and by definition $$F$$ is an antiderivative of $$|x|$$.

Knowing $$F$$ is a primitive of $$|x|$$, now we show that $$F=\frac{x|x|}{2}$$. One can verify that $$F(x)=\frac{x}{2}\cdot g(x)$$, where $$g(x)=\begin{cases} -x &x<0 \\ \phantom{-}x &x\ge 0 \end{cases}$$. But $$g(x)=|x|$$ by definition, thus $$F(x)=\frac{x|x|}{2}$$. QED

(Note: primitive is another word for antiderivative, for some reason my translator plugin prefers it

Note 2: the translator breaks with LaTeX; here are some words to help you read until I fix the translation manually:

« donc » = thus, « soit » = let, « mais » = but, « on a » = we have

the other words are cognates so they are what they look like in English)

Explication:

Let $$F(x)=\int_0^x |t|\,dt$$ (you can choose any real number for the lower limit, I use 0 because it's easier).


You're right that the area under the curve is always positive, but that doesn't mean that the primitive is similar. Remember that when $$x<0$$ the integral turns into $$-\int_x^0 f(t)\,dt$$. Since $$f(t)>0$$ for all $$t\in\mathbb{R}$$, the area is also positive, so $$-\int_x^0 f(t)\,dt < 0$$.

We know that $$x^2\ge 0$$ for all $$x$$, so it's impossible for $$x^2$$ to be the primitive.

Démonstration (informel)

Soit $$F(x)=\int_0^x |t|\,dt$$ (je choisis zéro parce que c'est plus facile, mais n'importe quel réel marche).

Si $$x\ge0$$, on a $$\int_0^x t\,dt=\left.\frac{t^2}{2}\right\rvert_0^x=\frac{x^2}{2}$$. À part ça, si $$x<0$$ on a $$\int_0^x -t\,dt=\left.-\frac{t^2}{2}\right\rvert_0^x=-\frac{x^2}{2}$$. Il paraît que

$$\displaystyle F(x)=\begin{cases} -\frac{x^2}{2} &x<0 \\ \phantom{-}\frac{x^2}{2} &x\ge 0. \end{cases}$$

On peut le démontrer comme suivant.  Soit $$x<0$$. Donc $$F(x)=-\frac{x^2}{2}\implies F'(x)=-x$$. Puis soit $$x>0$$. Donc $$F(x)=\frac{x^2}{2}\implies F'(x)=x$$. Finalement soit $$x=0$$. Le fonction est différente à la gauche et à la droite, donc on doit utiliser la définition de la dérivative:

$$\displaystyle\lim\limits_{h\to 0^-} \frac{F(0+h)-F(0)}{h} =\lim\limits_{h\to 0^-} \frac{-\frac{h^2}{2}-0}{h} =\lim\limits_{h\to 0^-} -\frac{h}{2}=0$$

$$\displaystyle\lim\limits_{h\to 0^+} \frac{F(0+h)-F(0)}{h} =\lim\limits_{h\to 0^+} \frac{\frac{h^2}{2}-0}{h} =\lim\limits_{h\to 0^+} \frac{h}{2}=0$$.

Donc $$\lim\limits_{h\to 0} \frac{F(0+h)-F(0)}{h}=0$$, et par définition la dérivée de $$F$$ existe et elle est égal à zéro à $$x=0$$.

Maintenant on écrit $$F'$$ comme une fonction défini par morceaux (dans le deuxième cas, quand $$x=0$$ on a $$F'(x)=0$$, donc cette définition est valide):

$$F'(x)=\begin{cases} -x & x<0 \\ x & x\ge 0. \end{cases}$$

Mais cela est exactement la définition de la valeur absolue, donc $$F'(x)=|x|$$, et par définition $$F$$ est une primitive de $$|x|$$.

Connaissant que $$F$$ est une primitive, maintenant on démontre que $$F=\frac{x|x|}{2}$$. On peux vérifier que $$F(x)=\frac{x}{2}\cdot g(x)$$, où $$g(x)=\begin{cases} -x &x<0 \\ \phantom{-}x &x\ge 0. \end{cases}$$ Mais $$g(x)=|x|$$ par la définition, donc $$F(x)=\frac{x|x|}{2}$$. QED

First, check the values you're using for the sums. It looks like you're using $$f(x)$$ from every $$x$$ ($$\Delta x=1$$), but you need to take $$f(x)$$ from every other $$x$$ ($$\Delta x=2$$ because there are 6 intervals).

Also, I'm not sure, but I think the values used for the sum on the left and the sum on the right should be the same. Specifically, let's say the sum $$L_6=2(y_0+y_1+y_2+y_3+y_4+y_5)$$. The sum $$R_6$$ should be $$2(y_1+y_1+y_2+y_3+y_4+y_5+y_6)$$, where $$y_1$$ to $$y_5$$ are the same in both.

Hi there, I am looking for guidance to answer the question. So far, I have done Integration by Parts with u = f(x) and dv = g'(x)dx and have gotten a result. I have read on other questions that Riemann sums would be used to calculate the integral, but since the integrand I got was 3x^2g(x), how would Riemann sums be applied?

I do not think this is the purpose of that question. The instructors only mentioned that it must not be solved by geometrical means (aka without integration). Personally I solved it by integrating one curve then subtracting the area of two triangles (using area formulas).

Asking to derive the area formulas of shapes seems redundant (and will require double integral I think): as long as you are not fully solving with geometry, you are good. 

If you are unsure where to start, there was a thread in which an instructor mentioned starting with a semicircle >> my following steps involved creating proper bounds of integration using geometry, then integrating.

"uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-20T20:47:09Z", "content": "

The beginning of your solution is correct, and it's possible to find an answer.


If we take the integral of the general form, we'd have $$A\ln|x|-\frac{B}{x}+C\ln|x+1|-\frac{D}{x+1}-\frac{E}{2(x+1)^2}$$. Since we know that the primitive is rational, we can conclude that $$A$$ and $$C$$ must equal zero.

So we can write $$\frac{f(x)}{x^2(x+1)^3}=\frac{B}{x^2}+\frac{D}{(x+1)^2}+\frac{E}{(x+1)^3}$$, equivalent to $$f(x)=B(x+1)^3+Dx^2(x+1)+Ex^2=(B+D)x^3+(3B+D+E)x^2+(3B)x+B$$. We also know that $$f(x)$$ is quadratic, therefore, we can conclude that $$(B+D)=0$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-20T20:43:09Z", "content": "

The beginning of your solution is correct, and it's possible to find an answer.


If we take the integral of the general form, we'd have $$A\ln|x|-\frac{B}{x}+C\ln|x+1|-\frac{D}{x+1}-\frac{E}{2(x+1)^2}$$. Since we know that the primitive is rational, we can conclude that $$A$$ and $$C$$ must equal zero.

So we can write $$\frac{f(x)}{x^2(x+1)^3}=\frac{B}{x^2}+\frac{D}{(x+1)^2}+\frac{E}{(x+1)^3}$$, equivalent to $$f(x)=B(x+1)^3+Dx(x+1)+Ex^2$$. We also know that $$f(x)$$ is quadratic.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm44343jfuy70y", "kevjvelwj8x73e", "lm7uktk0zrg32n", "ljww2wwy5x05wq", "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "ljyg2f9nar04c8", "lmavuguld506fy", "lm7ukbje9e51kn"], "children": [], "id": "lrmjdz17q5h1w7", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "What do you mean by "the primitive is rational"? And why is A and C must equal to zero?

I understand everything, except for when you made the A and C terms zero.", "created": "2024-01-21T03:53:15Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The word "primitive" is a synonym for "antiderivative"; I sometimes use the former because it's closer to the word in French.

Recall that a rational function is the quotient of two polynomials. Since the antiderivative is a rational function, we know that there are no terms with non-constant logarithms. But if $$A$$ or $$C$$ don't equal zero, the antiderivative will have a non-constant logarithm, a contradiction. So we conclude that $$A$$ and $$C$$ equal zero.

When it states can bob ever catch up to alice, are we to assume before alice finishes memorizing? Since ultimately they will both end up memorizing all of the work (L=1), alice will finish first, then technically bob will catch up.

\n

I've read all the related posts for this, but I am still quite confused by what is asked in this question. Could someone provide clarification, heres my thought process for [0,A]:

1/ I notice that the acceleration is positive, but velocity is negative, hence the particle is slowing down.

2/ Assuming the particle started at the origin. we would want the the area under this a(t) curve to be UNDERestimated, since the velocity here is acting against the acceleration. (this is the major logic I want to ensure I understand correctly!)

3/ To do so we would use the right endpoint.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tutorials"], "nr": 195, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-21T19:04:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kf2z2j444pg31s", "data": "lrnvasx1aen381", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-21T19:04:23Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kf2z2j444pg31s", "subject": "Note on Tutorial Communication", "created": "2024-01-21T19:04:23Z", "content": "

Hello all,

I wanted to make the following comments briefly on tutorial submissions, particularly pertaining to communication. 

While it may seem difficult to include written components into your solutions, here are some simple approaches to clearly communicate your approach.

1. Start with an introductory sentence. This should typically be in the form of "We want to compute ...", "We want to solved .... ", "We want to prove ...". This clearly sets the tone for what you want to accomplish within the question. This can also be equally paired off with a closing sentence affirming that you have in fact shown what you intended to do within the question.

2. Add a sentence alongside your computations. This does not need to be anything inherently complex. Even key words such as "Simplifying", "Expanding", "Cancelling Terms", "By Theorem A", greatly improve the context into your procedure. This is similar to recipe instructions. One does not expect each step to be thoroughly detailed, rather, an instruction reading "mix 1/3 cup of milk" contains all the necessary information to understand this step. 

3. If you are unsure how to correctly communicate something in writing, discuss among yourselves or ask a TA! Often, writing mathematics requires a complete understand of the notions involved, so it is a great opportunity to discuss with your peers or inquire from TAs how one might discuss these topics. 

I will also add that in addition to writing being indicative of a thorough understanding of the matter, there are indeed other motivations to practice mathematics communication. For one, mathematics is a field of great precision, and thus, it is important that our work reflects this precision through our means of describing solutions. Additionally, in many professional settings, you may be required to explain mathematics to individuals that may not have a formal background in mathematics. When one has practiced communicating math, discussing the topic in a comprehensible manner is feasible. 

Try and keep the above in mind throughout the semester and going forward. I will also include a submission of some my own past work. Although it does not pertain to a calculus problem, you may observe that the solution guides the reader through the steps. 

MAT401W2023-Q8.pdf

The PCEs were originally written by the 2020 instructor team: Michael Breeling, Shai Cohen, Paul Milgram, Fabian Parsch, Mary Pugh.

The fact that there are five original authors is the reason why you might notice them being written in different voices. We think that this a feature (to mix things up a bit over the year) and hope you see it that way too!

Since they were originally written, the PCEs have been edited and polished by subsequent instructors (based on curriculum changes, feedback, ...). So a lot of work from many people went into them.

It's great to see in the comments that some of you like them. Thanks for the feedback! :-)

Edit: And of course we know that none of them are perfect, but hopefully year over year they are getting better :-)
