{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 200, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T02:21:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lroaxc51gyt3wu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-22T02:21:48Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lroc2y1wj2f5yo", "to": "lroaxc4xe323ws", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T02:54:10Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lroc4wlepbl33k", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-22T02:55:41Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PCE A5", "created": "2024-01-22T02:21:48Z", "content": "A bit out of context, Why is it on PCE A5, the fraction of toys that will break goes smaller overtime? It doesn't really make sense?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T02:54:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T02:55:41Z", "content": "I would guess that it's because as you increase the amount of time they last, the fraction of all toys that survive all that time become smaller and smaller, as toys that break after a longer time are scarcer than those that break within the first year.\u00a0

Remember that the integral is modeling the probability distribution of the toy breaking over some time. I.e. it's far less likely a toy will break after lasting 10 years vs 1 year.
"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T02:54:10Z", "content": "I would guess that it's because as you increase the amount of time they last, the fraction of all toys that survive all that time become smaller and smaller, as toys that break after a longer time are scarcer than those that break within the first year."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["jvbpijsmgxy40f"], "children": [], "id": "lroc2y1s4x35ym", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lroaxc4xe323ws", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173062949, "default_anonymity": "no"}

\n

if you can prove at least one of the integrals in a sum of integrals is divergent, the sum must also be divergent (which makes sense). I was reviewing last need's lecture notes and I was confused about the formula for the error bound. Does “M” need to be PRECISELY the maximum of f’(x) / f”(x) on the given interval? Or can it be just an upper bound value?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "lectures_section0102", "lectures_section0103", "student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 129, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T04:13:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Warrick Tsui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukyklcmy3k9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T04:14:09Z", "content": "

It's possible to use an upper limit other than the exact maximum, but it gives you a less strict limit for the error.

Proof:

Let $$f:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ be differentiable on $$[a,b]$$, and $$L_n$$ a left-handed Riemann sum of $$f$$ with $$n\in\mathbb{N}$$ subintervals. So $$\left|\int_a^b f(x)\,dx - L_n\right| \le \frac{M(b-a)^2}{2n}$$ where $$M=\max\limits_{a\le x\le b} |f'(x)|$$. [A4]

Let $$U\ne M$$ be an upper bound of $$f$$. Since $$M$$ is the supremum, it follows that $$U>M$$. Then $$\frac{M(b-a)^2}{2n} < \frac{U(b-a)^2}{2n}$$. So $$\left|\int_a^b f(x)\,dx - L_n\right| < \frac{U(b-a)^2}{2n}$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T04:13:08Z", "content": "

It's possible to use an upper limit other than the exact maximum, but it gives you a less strict limit for the error.

Demonstration:


Let $$f:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ be differentiable on $$[a,b]$$, and $$L_n$$ a left-handed Riemann sum of $$f$$ with $$n\in\mathbb{N}$$ subintervals. So $$\left|\int_a^b f(x)\,dx - L_n\right| \le \frac{M(b-a)^2}{2n}$$ where $$M=\max\limits_{a\le x\le b} |f'(x)|$$.

Let $$U\ne M$$ be an upper limit of $$f$$. Since $$M$$ is the upper bound, it follows that $$U>M$$. Then $$\frac{M(b-a)^2}{2n} < \frac{U(b-a)^2}{2n}$$. So $$\left|\int_a^b f(x)\,dx - L_n\right| < \frac{U(b-a)^2}{2n}$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukyklcmy3k9"], "children": [], "id": "lroewigtde54qw", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T15:07:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T15:07:28Z", "content": "Note that you are computing an upper bound, and not the exact value of the integral. If your M is exactly the maximum, then you are achieving the best bound that the given formula allows you to achieve. If your M is greater than the maximum, you are still getting an upper bound."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T15:07:10Z", "content": "Note that you are computing an upper bound, and not the exact value of the integral. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0101", "lectures_section0102", "lectures_section0103"], "nr": 203, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T12:32:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrowqzakouyds", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-22T12:32:43Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrp5qq98l2y4td", "to": "lrowqzagm64dr", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T16:44:28Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "How would you estimate the maximum value on a function", "created": "2024-01-22T12:32:43Z", "content": "If you were to be given a functions such as 2x(e^-x2) on an interval of -10 to 10 how would you estimate the maxiumum absolute value of this function to use in the error bound formula."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "lectures_section0102", "lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tala Abdelmaguid", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1y9ok83vg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 111, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T16:44:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T16:44:28Z", "content": "

Assuming your equation is $$\left|2x\exp(-x^2)\right|$$, you can find the true maximum value (in terms of $$e$$) using the optimization process [1] (calculate the derivative, find its zeros, evaluate the function at the zeros).

For an estimate, you can use the following facts:

  1. $$\left|2x\exp(-x^2)\right|$$ is an even function
  2. $$\exp(-x^2)$$ decreases faster than $$x$$ increases [2].
  3. The maximum value of $$\exp(-x^2)$$ is $$1$$.

We can therefore conclude that $$\left|2x\exp(-x^2)\right| \le 2(1) = 2$$ (the true maximum is about 0.858).

[1] Calculation of maximum value (even function so we only take $$x>0$$):

$$\frac{d}{dx}2x\exp(-x^2) = 2\exp(-x^2)-4x²\exp(-x^2)=2\exp(-x^2)\left[1-2x^2\right]=2\exp(-x^2)\left[1-x\sqrt{2}\right]\left[1+x\sqrt{2}\right]$$.

So there are critical points at $$x=\pm\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$$, but we ignore the negative one.

Evaluating at critical and end points:

$$f(10) = 2(10)\exp(-10^2) = \frac{20}{e^{100}}$$

$$f(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}) = 2\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\exp\left(-\frac{1^2}{\sqrt{2}^2}\right)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{e}}$$

So maximum is $$\sqrt{\frac{2}{e}}$$.

[2] Formally, $$\lim\limits_{x\to\infty} x\exp(-x^2) = \lim\limits_{x\to\infty} \frac{x}{\exp(x^2)}=\lim\limits_{x\to\infty} \frac{1}{2x\exp(x^2)}$$ by the Hospital's rule; the previous equals 0 so $$\lim\limits_{x\to\infty} x\exp(-x^2)=0$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kjvi78x7tda2lo"], "children": [], "id": "lrp5qq949ex4ta", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ul1y9ok83vg"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrowqzagm64dr", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173066202, "default_anonymity": "no"}

For $$\lim_{x\to a} f(x)=l$$ to exixst and equal $$l$$, we need $$f(x)$$  to be approximately $$l$$ on both siders of $$x=a$$:

$$\lim_{x\to a} f(x)=l \Leftrightarrow \lim_{x\to a^-} f(x)=l \quad\&\quad \lim_{x\to a^+} f(x)=l$$

If the two one-sided limits are different, or if one (or both) of them fail to exist, then the overall limit doesn't exist. Note that the value of $$f(a)$$ doesn't enter into this. We only care about what happens when $$x$$ is slightly less than $$a$$ , or slightly greater than $$a$$ , not what happens when $$x$$ is equal to $$a$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T21:17:45Z", "content": "

$$\lim_{x\to a} f(x)=l \Leftrightarrow \lim_{x\to a^-} f(x)=l \quad\& \quad \lim_{x\to a^+} f(x)=l$$

If the two one-sided limits are different, or if one (or both) of them fail to exist, then the overall limit doesn't exist. Note that the value of $$f(a)$$ doesn't enter into this. We only care about what happens when $$x$$ is slightly less than $$a$$ , or slightly greater than $$a$$ , not what happens when $$x$$ is equal to $$a$$.

In general, when we have a function with a fraction, we choose a function in the form of $$\frac{1}{x^p}$$ for some $$p\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$$ for comparison, because it's easy to determine whether the second converges or not.

For integral A :

We know that $$\ln(x)\ge 0$$ when $$x\in[1,\infty)$$, so $$x-\ln(x)\le x \implies \frac{1}{x-\ln(x)}\ge\frac{1}{x}$$ (the reciprocal function is decreasing).

For integral B:

We know that $$0 \le \sin^4(x) \le 1 \implies 4 \le 4+\sin^4(x) \le 5$$. Moreover $$\frac{1}{x^2}>0$$ for all $$x\in[1,\infty)$$ so $$\frac{4+\sin^4(x)}{x^2} \le \frac{5}{x^2}$$.

It's not given in the question, and this information wouldn't help you find the y-coordinate -- the resulting triangle would still have an unknown height.

More useful is that the ratio between radius and height equals 1, so the angle between the sides of the cone and the x axis is $$\\frac{\\pi}{4}$$ radians. Using this, it's possible to construct a right-angled triangle with a known angle and side, but I leave it to you to figure out where.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 215, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T03:52:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrptlws18ky2ug", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-23T03:52:34Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrqdx18eybrh0", "to": "lrptlwryv9p2uf", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-23T13:21:05Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Homework 1 Question 3 Part A", "created": "2024-01-23T03:52:34Z", "content": "

For the question asking whether it converges or diverges, observing the function as it approaches -inf and inf, we can obviously take the limit to see what the limit will result in. However, in terms of integrals, a random function such as limit approaching infinity of (5/(1+x^2 e^x) will collapse to 0, but and we can tell that the integral will eventually converge since the denominator is so large. With our current knowledge, however, it is impossible for us to integrate that by hand. Would it be enough to say the integral will eventually converge due to the incredibly rapid pace that the denominator is growing at? Is there any way to prove this statement because I cannot think of any other way to say this, other than the fact that we just know it will.

Furthermore, for a limit such as limit approaching inf of x^2 e^-x, would we also be allowed to state that the limit is also approaching 0, as we know that the exponential function will grow much faster than x^2? I did use L Hopital's to prove it, but I was also wondering if we could also just state that since we know e^x will grow much faster, itll eventually approach 0.

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sophia Alexanian ", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6unadbfxc6rw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Manahil Saeed", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm562039i1l1bg", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jenny Chung", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 146, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T13:21:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Linda Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm44343jfuy70y", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T13:21:05Z", "content": "

The statement that the integral converges because the denominator increases very quickly is not a valid mathematical argument -- you don't explain what "speed" is sufficient for convergence (for example, why does $$\frac{1}{x}$$ diverge but $$\frac{1}{x^{1.01}}$$ converge?), and you don't explain what you mean by "speed".

You must use the comparison theorem for this argument. With the $$\frac{1}{1+x^2e^x}$$ example, you can use $$2e^{-x}$$ for the upper limit (I'll leave the proof to you). Since $$\int_0^\infty 2e^{-x}$$ is convergent, you know that $$\int_0^\infty \frac{1}{1+x^2e^x}$$ is too.

For your second question, again, "increasing faster" is not a valid argument and you have to prove the limit with l'Hôpital's rule.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework", "other"], "nr": 216, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T04:46:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrpvj3z4dgl1nb", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-23T04:46:23Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lrqftx29m4u6qa", "to": "lrpvj3z05vs1na", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-23T14:14:39Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "Assumed Properties of Linear Approximations", "created": "2024-01-23T04:46:23Z", "content": "

For this course, may we use that the tangent to a convex (concave up) function will always lie below that function, and that the tangent to a concave (down) function will always lie above it? This fact is used in the lecture slides (A4-2) to "prove" that a midpoint sum over or underestimates the function depending on its concavity.

The proof for this fact is not difficult (https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3019362), however I realise we do not actually have a proper definition of concave/convex functions (from this or the previous course); without it the proof is impossible.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sophia Alexanian ", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6unadbfxc6rw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jenny Chung", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 94, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T14:14:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Chris Mak", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1695815518, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1705340166, "global": 1705340166, "lr51f0oibsv66y": 1705923949}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T14:14:39Z", "content": "

Yes, you can use this fact without proof. 

The definition of concavity that we have been using is indeed the sign of teh second derivative. We did not give a geometrical definition via the convexity of a curve, which is indeed the most intuitive way of thinking about concave up/down, especially in relation to a straight line.

We don't know for sure that $$g(x)$$ is convex. You're right that the data suggests the function is convex (concave up), but we don't know what the function does between these values; the function could be concave (down) there.

In this course, your options for approximation are $$R_n$$, $$L_n$$, $$M_n$$ and $$T_n$$. We know that $$M_n$$ and $$T_n$$ are more accurate, so you should prefer them when possible. Another factor is the number of intervals -- with an table of values there will be fewer intervals for $$M_n$$ than $$L_n$$, $$R_n$$ and $$T_n$$. So $$T_n$$ is often better for table questions such as Q5.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T15:30:24Z", "content": "

Another factor is the number of intervals -- with an table of values there will be fewer intervals for $$M_n$$ than $$L_n$$, $$R_n$$ and $$T_n$$. So $$T_n$$ is often better for table questions such as Q5.

I think I found my mistake, but I have question about mathematical concept for the upper bound and maximum (M). For example, does abs(f'x) for M (for Ln and Rn) and upper bound of abs(f'x) different? 

I learned in the lecture that we should always choose safe upper bound. And in the tutorial 2 answer key for part 3 (b), the upper bound is abs(f'x) < 6 and seems like we are using different abs(f'x) value for part (c). I am wondering if abs(f'x) for M and the upper bound of abs(f'x) are different

", "created": "2024-01-23T17:48:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

There isn't the one correct upper bound. So we can't say "the upper bound". We can only see "an upper bound".

In this example, you could pick M=6. Or M=7. Or M=8. Or M=9. All of them are correct upper bounds.

The answer key is just giving you one possible answer. There are many other correct answers. For example n=1000000000000000000000000000000000 would also give an error of less than 10^{-4}. But we should of course be reasonable. Doing that many intervals is a bit of "overkill in precision".

However, if you are interested (and this is very out of scope for this course), you can look into the "convolution" of two functions, which you can think of as a sort of integral of a product of 2 functions. 3Blue1Brown has a nice video series on this and how it all relates to statistics and probability (it's also related to a technique used for solving differential equations, but it's not going to be covered in this course): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IaSGqQa5O-M"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm6unadbfxc6rw"], "children": [], "id": "lrqiqqnag2y3zg", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T23:04:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sophia Alexanian ", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6unadbfxc6rw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T14:23:06Z", "content": "The definite integral of the product of two functions is the area under the product, which is NOT equal to the product of teh integral under each curve.  The best way to think about the integral of a product is either through the substitution rule or the integration by part rule. In both cases, you will be modifying teh integral into a different one in the hope that you can directly visualize the latter integral."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "subject": "", $$g(x)$$, defined on interval $$[a, b]$$, then the integral of the product $$f(x). g(x)$$ from $$a$$ to $$b$$, represents the signed area between the curves of $$f(x)$$ and $$g(x)$$!"}, {"anon": "no", {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 221, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T14:52:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrqh6s17lzt7j2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-23T14:52:39Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrqhyjtq69o72a", "to": "lrqh6s14vb37j1", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-23T15:14:15Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrqi11wlndp400", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-23T15:16:11Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Homework 1 Question 1", "created": "2024-01-23T14:52:39Z", "content": "I know that we have to use integrals to solve the question, but can we use integrals to compute the area of an arc, the cone etc. to reach to the shaded area? 

As i would assume that in previous posts, we are told to use the integral to compute the shaded area using the functions of absolute value and the function of the blue circle "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 182, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T15:14:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T15:16:11Z", "content": "

(I assume that by arc you mean sector because an arc doesn't have an area.)

It's possible to use integrals to calculate the area of a sector and a cone (more precisely a triangle because the diagram is in 2D), and you can derive general formulas with it, but it won't help you with this question.

We don't have the height of the cone, so it's impossible to find its area. Even if we did, the shaded area would not be equal to the area of the triangle minus the area of the circle, nor minus a sector of the circle.

(Although this hypothetical would have symmetry and you could find the shaded area with that, you would rely on a geometric argument, not an integral as desired.)

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["logistics"], "nr": 222, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T16:07:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrqjvffw9qi7z", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-23T16:07:48Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "data": "lrqkwj3jlsu23d", "to": "lrqjvfft25m7y", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-23T16:36:39Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Midpoint and right endpoint Riemann sum", "created": "2024-01-23T16:07:48Z", "content": "

Hi, 

For a function that is continuous, increasing and concave up on an interval, both the midpoint and right endpoint sum would give an overestimation. However, does the midpoint sum always give a better approximation than the right endpoint sum if the numbers of subinterval?

Thanks

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 99, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T16:36:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Qilin Gu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljmcvfv9vfu1oa", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Benson Zhang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljqb0nbtrox4pb", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T16:36:39Z", "content": "

Yes, this is true. You can confirm that by drawing a graph with those properties.

Using the following names:

A="area above curve but still within right endpoint box"

B="area above curve but still within midpoint endpoint box"

C="area below curve that the right endpoint box is missing"

D="area below curve that the midpoint rule is missing"

Then

Error for right endpoint = A-C=A-0=A

Error for midpoint = B-D

Visually, B<A. This also means that B-D<A. Therefore Midpointerror < Rightpointerror

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljmcvfv9vfu1oa", "ljqb0nbtrox4pb"], "children": [], "id": "lrqkwj3fscs23c", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrqjvfft25m7y", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173086821, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 91, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T18:18:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T18:19:06Z", "content": "

$$\tan^{-1}(0)=0$$ (by evaluating directly)

$$\lim_{t\to-\infty}\tan^{-1}(t/2)=-\pi/2$$

This limit can be seen by observing two things: The "divide by two" doesn't matter since t is going to infinity. So this limit is the same as

$$\lim_{t\to-\infty}\tan^{-1}(t)=-\pi/2$$

To see that this limit is correct it might help to look at the graph of the $$tan^{-1}$$ function see here: https://www.desmos.com/calculator/byppu5glbp

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T18:18:45Z", "content": "

If the area is growing even by a very small amount for every increase in x, how is the area not infinite?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T19:04:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-23T19:04:17Z", "content": "In reality infinite is not actually a number, it is just a concept where the bound is limitless. So when the area is found using limits, it means that the actual area barely deviates from the actual value as the area increases. It can go on forever and the area wont change enough to cause an effect. That is just my understanding of it, not sure if its right or not."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk1qrnpwn0"], "children": [], "id": "lrqq6e0u9ui249", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "that makes sense but wouldn't an infinite amount of "negligible" increases, eventually have an effect?", "created": "2024-01-23T19:06:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

(I will post the source once I find it again)

The intuitive idea is that the digits eventually "stabilize" -- that is terms eventually stop affecting the more significant (leftmost) digits, and when you continue the process indefinitely all digits will stabilize.

Take the example of the sum $$\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{1}{2^k}$$ as $$n$$ goes to infinity. Listing out the terms (starting n=1):

             1 (+1)

          1.5 (+0.5)

        1.75 (+0.25)

      1.875 (+0.125)

    1.9375 (+0.0625)

  1.96875 (+0.03125)

1.984375 (+0.015625)

Notice how eventually the extra terms have zeroes in the most significant digits. This means that those digits will no longer increase, so the sum stops increasing past a certain point.

Hey just looking for some feedback on my analysis thus far, I have been told prior that taking the derivative and setting equal to 0 gives you M. But I don't think its that applicable here since we don't know what A, B  etc,. are, I went for a more analytical approach. 

If I used Mn for the first interval [0, A] (hypothetically), the upper bound formula is missing the M:

I think you are trying to find the exact maximum of the derivative. Note that it is not at all necessary that M is the maximum. There is no such thing as "THE M". There are many possible and correct Ms that bound a derivative.

For example, if $$f''(x)=\sin(x)$$ you could actually take $$M=2$$ if you wanted. It just needs to be a reasonably upper bound on the second derivative.

So in short: Don't try to find the exact maximum of particular functions. Just find a bound that works.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mohammad Samin Yasar Chowdhury", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lmrrcro0rhmpp", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jiaying Dou", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljo7qmxghwe1u6", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Angel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lke8u9r64dg785", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 176, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-24T15:23:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tharinsa Withanage", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm2n795hd584e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-24T15:23:29Z", "content": "

Let's say you want to show that

$$\frac{1}{x^2+\sin(x)+1}\leq\frac{1}{x^2}$$

When trying to show this, you first need to consider why this is the case, i.e. rather than trying to push it around, what - from looking at it - make this inequality true.

In this case, for example, one could say that this is true because $$\sin(x)+1$$ is only making the denominator larger (we are adding something positive), so we divide by more.

So what we are using here is $$\sin(x)\geq -1$$. That is what makes the original inequality true. Now you can start with $$\sin(x)\geq -1$$ and manipulate it until you get to the original inequality $$\frac{1}{x^2+\sin(x)+1}\leq\frac{1}{x^2}$$.

There isn't the one cookie-cutter way of pushing these things around and it depends a lot on the particular functions involved, but the more you juggle, the more familiar these things will get.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm2n795hd584e"], "children": [], "id": "lrrxqaffn9d6gy", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lmrrcro0rhmpp", "ljo7qmxghwe1u6", "lke8u9r64dg785", "lm7ukr1754d2wl"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrrbhk5yktrba", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173103112, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hi, I just had a question of the graph for the question 2 of the homework.

Thank you

The properties you should use should be very obvious properties of the function, not something that could only be assumed by using a lot zooming/guessing. Try to focus on these obvious properties.

Maybe start by trying to sketch an antiderivative to the graphed function.

", "created": "2024-01-24T18:05:03Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrs3i27io2k51t", "updated": "2024-01-24T18:05:03Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The question asks for most accuracy for an overestimation, if this was a linear function you would have to disregard Tn and Mn, if it had concavity then you have to disregard Ln and Rn. So are you suggesting we take the dominant feature of the function? (I.e we are certain [0, A] is decreasing)", "created": "2024-01-24T18:12:12Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrs3r8yyjti8i", "updated": "2024-01-24T18:12:12Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Based on what you write, it seems that you are trying to find the integral of a(t).

You need to find the integral of v(t), not the integral of a(t).

", "created": "2024-01-24T18:15:03Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrs3uxfz5ax1iz", "updated": "2024-01-24T18:15:03Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "My thought process is that since these estimations must be applied to a(t) graph, we can conclude that velocity in [0,A] is increasing, positive, and concave down. So we need to overestimate [0, A] in the a(t) graph to maximize the v(t) and in turn the area under the v(t) graph. ", "created": "2024-01-24T18:19:46Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrs40zs8gg07m2", "updated": "2024-01-24T18:19:46Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Ah okay I now see what you mean. The "best accuracy" in the question is referring to making choices as well as you can. If you are unsure about a specific pick between two options, try to explain your choices/considerations.

Also, you are saying that "If this was a linear function, you would have to disregard Tn and Mn" but that is not the case. Draw a linear function and it's trapezoid or it's midpoint approximation. What do you observe?

", "created": "2024-01-24T18:28:23Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrs4c2dzxj86p0", "updated": "2024-01-24T18:28:23Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

So if we went with the assumption that it is concave down to concave up and we explained it well and defended it and properly supported our work with the right summation type, we would get the same mark as someone who may have chose that it is strictly concave down, but also properly explained their work?

In essence, this question is meant to be more broad?

I can't say what is or isn't correct and what is worth marks.

Generally, I do think that you are overthinking the shape of this curve. You are zooming in too much. This is a computer graphic so if you zoom in too far you might starting to see ghosts :)

There is no way that the function is concave down in that first part, no matter how you look at the graph.

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 244, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-24T23:19:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrsepyf6c7o724", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-24T23:19:07Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lrseqenge7nj9", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-01-24T23:19:28Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "data": "lrsfagsvmy71ae", "to": "lrsepyf1qd723", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-24T23:35:04Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Clarification for assumption in Q2 (b)", "created": "2024-01-24T23:19:28Z", "content": "

Hello,

Need a quick clarification for (b). Say for the sake of the question, I'm trying to find the upper bound to $$|v''(t)|$$ on $$\left[0,A\right]$$. which is given to me in the question with $$|v''(t)| \leq |2\cos(\frac{t}{4\pi})e^{-\frac{t}{20}}|$$ for $$\left[0,D\right]$$.

Say, I do the work to calculate the $$t$$ which maximizes $$|2\cos(\frac{t}{4\pi})e^{-\frac{t}{20}}|$$. Do I just assume $$t \in \left[0,A\right]$$? I can't evaluate the function on the boundaries because I don't know what $$t=A$$ or any other letter will produce in the function?

My best bet seems to be assuming such a $$t$$ I find which maximizes the function will always be within the range I'm looking in but I wanted to clarify as this seems a bit too hand-wavy.

Thanks,

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Clerification on assumption in Q2 (b)", "created": "2024-01-24T23:19:07Z", "content": "

Hello,

Need a quick clarification for (b). Say for the sake of the question, I'm trying to find the upper bound to $$|v''(t)|$$ on $$\left[0,A\right]$$. which is given to me in the question with $$|v''(t)| \leq |2\cos(\frac{t}{4\pi})e^{-\frac{t}{20}}|$$ for $$\left[0,D\right]$$.

Say, I do the work to calculate the $$t$$ which maximizes $$|2\cos(\frac{t}{4\pi})e^{-\frac{t}{20}}|$$. Do I just assume $$t \in \left[0,A\right]$$? I can't evaluate the function on the boundaries because I don't know what $$t=A$$ or any other letter will produce in the function?

My best bet seems to be assuming such a $$t$$ I find which maximizes the function will always be within the range I'm looking in but I wanted to clarify as this seems a bit too hand-wavy.

Thanks,

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Alex Guo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukx0b16m3f0", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mahreen Naila", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uklh38no2ft", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 202, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-24T23:35:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-24T23:35:04Z", "content": "

You don't need to find the t which maximizes the expression. You only need to find a bound on the derivative. The M in the error bound formulas can be any M that bounds the derivative.

Example: If I told you $$\gamma''(t)\leq \sin(t^2)$$, you should be able to give me a bound on the second derivative without needing to find "the t" and even without me telling you the range of $$t$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kjvi78x7tda2lo"], "children": [], "id": "lrsfagsred21ad", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukx0b16m3f0", "lm7uklh38no2ft"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrsepyf1qd723", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173110714, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 250, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T02:22:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrsl9atp3sj5rq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-25T02:22:07Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukfo2lqj1xq", "data": "lrslehc7k2a6zk", "to": "lrsl9atltl55rp", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-25T02:26:09Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lrslqu396gn4jp", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-25T02:35:46Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lrslszdscdf1pj", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-25T02:37:26Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lrsopi6f5rg3me", "to": "lrsl9atltl55rp", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-25T03:58:42Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Comparison Theorem with constants", "created": "2024-01-25T02:22:07Z", "content": "Are we allowed to compare functions with constant functions? For example, can I compare a function to y = 5? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T02:26:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T02:37:26Z", "content": "

If the entire function is below your constant, such that the constant acts as an upper bound at all times to your function, then yes, but this generally doesn’t happen since the function at hand may tend to infinity as you tend to zero, which is where constants wouldn’t work out, but if your function is below the constant y=5 for the entire range, then I’m pretty sure you can use it as a comparison. 

Different person here: if my interpretation of this question is correct, I believe you are asking about whether or not you can compare polynomial, exponential, trig, etc. etc. function with a constant function. TL;DR, yes, but it would be to prove divergence, not convergence. You can probably do something like e^x and compare that to y=5, and you will get a result where for some value x e^x=5,  take the indefinite integral, (bounds ln5 and inf) and then realize oh, it is divergent because it is a constant+diverging integral. 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T02:35:46Z", "content": "

I know trig can be used, but i want to understand why partial fractions didn't work out.  is the boundary of partial fractions exponents greater than or equal to 1?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 129, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T03:49:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l5lpb0fj1l4165", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T03:49:55Z", "content": "<md>I tried to set it up and it failed because I couldn’t get 1 by itself without an $$x$$.

$$\int\frac{1}{x^{1/2}(1+x)}dx$$


$$=\int\frac{A}{x^{1/2}}+\frac{B}{x+1}dx$$


$$A(x+1)+B(x^{1/2})=1 $$

$$A(x+1)\neq1$$</md>"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrsoe7nt7i97h8", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I tired writing x^1/2 as (x+0)^1/2 and used a numerator of Ax+B, which didn't work either,so I'd love for someone to confirm?", "created": "2024-01-25T04:13:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Partial fraction decomposition can only be done on proper rational functions. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0101"], "nr": 254, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T05:13:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrsrd3y8qp23uv", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-25T05:13:03Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrsstg5ki5bwk", "to": "lrsrd3y5cjw3uu", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-25T05:53:45Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrsstq06fyz1d4", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-25T05:53:57Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Improper Integrals", "created": "2024-01-25T05:13:03Z", "content": "

Can someone explain why the integral's not split into 1 to 3 and 3 to infinity? Why is there another integral (3 to 5)?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T05:53:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jaewon Shon", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukwctwd63cu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mohammad Samin Yasar Chowdhury", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lmrrcro0rhmpp", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T05:53:57Z", "content": "

Integration requires the function to be continuous on the integration interval (here $$[1,\infty)$$), but $$\frac{1}{\sqrt{|x-3|}}$$ is discontinuous at $$x=3\in[1,\infty)$$. So we have to split the integral in two around $$x=3$$.

The second separation is because we can't have two improper limits in a single integral. Since the function is discontinuous at $$x=3$$, integrals with an integration limit of 3 are improper integrals. The choice of 5 is arbitrary.

The process is as follows:

$$\displaystyle \int_1^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{|x-3|}} \, dx = \int_1^3 \frac{1}{\sqrt{3-x}} \, dx + \int_3^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx$$

$$\displaystyle = \int_1^3 \frac{1}{\sqrt{3-x}} \, dx + \int_3^5 \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx + \int_5^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx$$

$$\displaystyle = \lim\limits_{m\to 3} \int_1^m \frac{1}{\sqrt{3-x}} \, dx + \lim\limits_{n\to 3} \int_n^5 \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx + \lim\limits_{p\to \infty} \int_5^p \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T05:53:45Z", "content": "

Integration requires the function to be continuous on the integration interval (here $$[1,\infty)$$), but $$\frac{1}{\sqrt{|x-3|}}$$ is discontinuous at $$x=3\in[1,\infty)$$. So we have to split the integral in two around $$x=3$$.

The second separation is because we can't have two improper limits in a single integral. Since the function is discontinuous at $$x=3$$, integrals with an integration limit of 3 are improper integrals. The choice of 5 is arbitrary.

The process is as follows:

$$\displaystyle \int_1^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{|x-3|}} \, dx = \int_1^3 \frac{1}{\sqrt{3-x}} \, dx + \int_3^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx$$

$$\displaystyle = \int_1^3 \frac{1}{\sqrt{3-x}} \, dx + \int_3^5 \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx + \int_5^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx$$

$$\displaystyle = \lim\limits_{m\to 3} \int_1^m \frac{1}{\sqrt{3-x}} \, dx + \lim\limits_{n\to 3} \int_3^5 \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx + \lim\limits_{p\to \infty} \int_5^p \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-3}} \, dx$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukwctwd63cu", "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "lmrrcro0rhmpp"], "children": [], "id": "lrsstg5gd6rwj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrsrd3y5cjw3uu", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173121555, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 255, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T06:44:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lrsumftwejz7c0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-25T06:44:17Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "data": "lrv3lm8dvp641u", "to": "lrsumftszin7bw", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-26T20:31:07Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "Mathematical Logic Puzzle", "created": "2024-01-25T06:44:17Z", "content": "

This is far outside the scope of the course, but it is math-related so I post it here regardless. I have been stumped by a math puzzle in my analysis book for the last few months, so I put it to the class to see if anyone has ideas. The problem is as follows:

Let $$W$$ be a property that is satisfied by certain subsets of $$\mathbb{R}$$. Given $$X\subseteq\mathbb{R}$$, we say $$X$$ is $$W$$ iff it satisfies property $$W$$, and we say it is $$\overline{W}$$ iff $$\mathbb{R}-X$$ is $$W$$.

Now suppose we know that given an arbitrary number of $$\overline{W}$$ sets, the union of all of them is also $$\overline{W}$$. What conditions must the property $$W$$ satisfy (in other words, what are some necessary conditions for $$W$$?)

Hint: Below we list examples of conditions that satisfy the requirement on $$W$$:

  1. The set is finite.
  2. The set has less than eight elements.
  3. The set contains only integers.

We now list examples of conditions that do not satisfy the requirement on $$W$$:

  1. The set contains exactly eight elements.
  2. The set contains an even number of elements (and is hence finite).

One of my first ideas was that the property must not bound the cardinality below, but this is disproven by the property "The set contains only the number 1." This turns out to be a valid choice of $$W$$ since only a single set is $$\overline{W}$$, hence the union of an arbitrary collection of $$\overline{W}$$ sets is also $$\overline{W}$$.

Another idea I considered was that the intersection of all $$\overline{W}$$ sets must be the empty set, but the above property disproves that.

Does anyone have any ideas/methods to approach this?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 119, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T20:31:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Chris Mak", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1695815518, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1705340166, "global": 1705340166, "lr51f0oibsv66y": 1705923949}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T20:31:07Z", "content": "This is a really interesting puzzle! I do feel that it's quite tricky to give a very generic answer to this. This does, however, smell a lot like the definition of open and closed sets in topology. (W is closed iff it's complement is open etc.)"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukqff3d82v1"], "children": [], "id": "lrv3lm88q5v41t", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrsumftszin7bw", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173122638, "default_anonymity": "no"}

The question doesn't give you values for either the cone's radius or its height, nor does it allow you to use them in your equation. So this equation doesn't work for this question.

Also, we know that $$r=h$$, so your equation becomes $$2r^2=R^2 \implies |r|\sqrt{2}=|R| \implies |r|=\frac{|R|}{\sqrt{2}}$$. If we use $$r$$ as a variable, the equation describes a pair of lines, not a circle (the equation is in the form $$|x|=C$$).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T15:59:47Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T15:56:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T15:56:10Z", "content": "

We can factor the polynomial in the numerator to $$(y-1)(y+1)$$. Then we see that $$y'(t)<0$$ when $$y\in(-1,1)$$, that $$y'(t)>0$$ when $$y\in(-\infty,-1)\cup(1,\infty)$$, and that $$y'(t)=0$$ when $$y\in\{-1,1\}$$.

Since $$0.9\in(-1,1)$$, the function is decreasing. Moreover, we know the equilibrium to be $$-1$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 284, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T23:59:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrvb27jduo55v5", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-26T23:59:59Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "data": "lrvf6ye3f6x6zd", "to": "lrvb27j8amz5v3", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-27T01:55:39Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "problem2(b)", "created": "2024-01-26T23:59:59Z", "content": "for Ln, M is the maximum of |v'| which is equals to a(t). When x is A-B, according to the a(t) graph, we know that we can get M( the biggest value of |v'| when t is near the middle of A and B, but how can we define the definite value of this t?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Linda Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm44343jfuy70y", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 159, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-27T01:55:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Linda Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm44343jfuy70y", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-27T01:55:39Z", "content": "

You don't need to find the precise maximum of |v'|. M just needs to be an upper bound on the derivative, not the exact maximum.

Consider this: $$f(t)=\sin[e^{\arctan t}+\sqrt{t}+t^{-7}]+\cos(\cos(\cos(\ln t)))$$

You could never find the exact t that maximizes this expression. But can you give me an $$M$$ so that $$|f(t)|\leq M$$?

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm44343jfuy70y"], "children": [], "id": "lrvf6ydzkdd6zc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm44343jfuy70y"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrvb27j8amz5v3", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173154061, "default_anonymity": "no"}

This is a substitution with a name change:

\n

$$\\displaystyle \\int\\frac{1}{y-20}\\frac{dy}{dt}\\,dt$$, let $$y(t)=u$$, so $$\\frac{du}{dt}=\\frac{dy}{dt} \\implies du=\\frac{dy}{dt}dt$$.

\n

Then we have $$\\displaystyle \\int\\frac{1}{u-20}\\,du$$. Renaming $$u=y$$ we have $$\\displaystyle \\int\\frac{1}{y-20}\\,dy$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kjvi78x7tda2lo", "lm7ukgfqdy6208"], "children": [], "id": "lrwliirti1b4", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrwjqna8lgja2", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173163826, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 298, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-28T01:35:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrwtx1ldewrnx", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-28T01:35:37Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lrxqai7g8sh7na", "to": "lrwtx1l55lknw", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-28T16:41:53Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "How to determine most accurate approximation", "created": "2024-01-28T01:35:37Z", "content": "I've noticed from lectures, as well as the written homework, that I have trouble determining the most accurate approximation method given a graph. Does it require memorization of certain rules (ie when trapezoidal is better or worse than midpoint), or is there a trick I can use to understand the reasoning behind the accuracy of each method (without having to derive it every time)? I understand the basics (ie. when left- and right-point Riemann sums are overestimate vs underestimate), and when I read the PCE's, I understood the reasoning, but when it comes to determining a situation on my own, I get very confused and don't know how to decide, especially if it's between trapezoidal vs midpoint. Are there any tricks to figuring this out?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 122, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-28T16:41:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-28T16:41:53Z", "content": "

I believe for overestimations it is something like

- midpoint => concave down

- trapezoid => concave up

- left endpoint => decreasing

- right endpoint=> increasing

(flip for underestimations)

generally you should prefer the first two to the latter two as their error bound is proportional to $$\frac{1}{n^2}$$ rather than $$\frac{1}{n}$$. however there are certain cases where a function is both concave up and down so it is unclear which of the first two to use, in which case you might want to pick a left/right endpoint. as a special case you should use trapezoidal for linear functions since it matches exactly.

instead of memorizing the list you could always visualize them against say $$y=\sin x$$ which both increases, decreases and has both concavities.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 78, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-28T18:54:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-28T18:54:00Z", "content": "

The error is in the 5th line; you've eliminated the absolute value operation without justification ($$\\ln|p-50|=0.5t+C\\implies|p-50|=e^{0.5t+C}$$).

\n

\n

With this equation, when we substitute $$p(0)=49$$, we arrive at $$|49-50|=e^{0.5(0)+C}\\implies|-1|=e^C\\implies 1=e^C$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 308, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-28T21:57:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm17re22zwt4vm", "data": "lry1jvsc3x057x", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-28T21:57:06Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "data": "lry1ssuc14p483", "to": "lry1jvs2yuo57v", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-28T22:04:02Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "data": "lry1t6c0hsv42u", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-28T22:04:19Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "data": "lry1tu7jn3f65q", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-28T22:04:50Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "data": "lry1votlz3w72u", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-01-28T22:06:17Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm17re22zwt4vm", "subject": "B2 PCE", "created": "2024-01-28T21:57:06Z", "content": "

The example in PCE shows that if g(t) is a constant, the ODE is separable, as shown in the picture below

But I want to ask that if h(y) is a constant and g(t) is a function, will this kind of ODE be separable?

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 87, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-28T22:04:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Isabella Lu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm17re22zwt4vm", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-28T22:06:17Z", "content": "Yes, a separable ODE is any equation that can be written in the form: $$y'=g(t)h(y)$$"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-28T22:04:50Z", "content": "A separable ODE is any equation that can be written in the form: $$y'=g(t)h(y)$$"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-28T22:04:19Z", "content": "A separable differential equation is any equation that can be written in the form: $$y'=g(t)h(y)$$"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-28T22:04:02Z", "content": "A separable differential equation is any equation that can be written in the form: $$y^'=g(t)h(y)$$"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm17re22zwt4vm"], "children": [], "id": "lry1ssu4lzf482", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lry1jvs2yuo57v", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173180107, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 309, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-29T04:38:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 1, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ul3zp3ny43p", "data": "lryfvlidebgjs", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-29T04:38:07Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lrygumnp4dy7nh", "to": "lryfvlho373jo", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-29T05:05:21Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lryfvlho373jo", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-29T22:00:54Z", "cid": "lrzh4mpoisd40u", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_2", "to": "lryfvlho373jo", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-31T02:19:24Z", "cid": "ls15swv8zsx3ax"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ul3zp3ny43p", "subject": "B1 PCE", "created": "2024-01-29T04:38:07Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sophia Alexanian ", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6unadbfxc6rw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 81, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-29T05:05:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Razan Farraj", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3zp3ny43p", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-29T05:05:21Z", "content": "

While Bob has a faster initial learning rate, he has less learned overall when they start (Alice has a 30% head start). 

When Bob learns up to what Alice learned, his learning rate is slowed... Bob has the same learning rate pattern as Alice, just delayed. Therefore he won't catch up, since he will never overcome Alice's initial head start.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kjvi78x7tda2lo", "lm7ul3zp3ny43p"], "children": [], "id": "lrygumnig9x7nf", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Also, i suppose its important to mention since I was confused at this part too. Hey! quick question, how did they get 7/4 when integrating (I got -2e^(-2t)) for that term). The 7/4 was weird for me.

For a -- the important phrase is "...increases at a rate proportional to the product of the number of zombies and the number of humans." That is, the derivative of $$Z$$ equals the product of itself, the number of humans, and a constant factor (the latter is called the proportionality factor, and is always present when we have a proportionality relationship). So we have $$\frac{dZ}{dt}=aZ(1000-Z)=\frac{Z(1000-Z)}{100}$$.

For c -- The 50% rate means that every day, half the zombies become human, so the rate of change is linked to the value of $$Z$$ -- specifically half.

You can think of it in terms of almost like a "vector", in which the order you add the numbers don't actually matter so long as the idea is conveyed. In this scenario it is guaranteed that rate at which salt leaves the tank is smaller than that of the rate at which it enters, as initial has smaller concentration (note that it is 5 kg/100 L = 0.05 kg/L vs 0.25 kg/L, and furthermore, 0.25*4 = 1. 1 kg of salt enters per minute, versus 0.05*4 = 0.2 kg salt exiting per minute). I'm too lazy to understand fully why it's not going to be "unsolvable" if the rates aren't equal, but my guess is that the contents of the tank aren't constant, meaning that it'll just be that much more complex to set it up. Because then the rate at which the salt flowing in affects the total concentration will change, as well as how the salt water flowing out affecting the concentration will also change. .\u00a0

Hello, I am confused on how we determined the interval of validity for ODEs during today's lecture.

I understand that dividing by t to create standard form means t can't equal 0 in our specific case. However, why did we rule out all t values less than 0 too?

Similarly, in this question, 2t + 5 can't equal 0 if we are creating standard form, but why was the valid time interval t > -5/2?

Plugging t = -5/2 back into the actual original ODE also doesn't cause any issues, so could we undo this restriction at the end and say t can be -5/2?

Thanks in advance for any answers on this.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Alex Guo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukx0b16m3f0", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 66, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-01T04:28:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T05:08:00Z", "content": "

My understanding of the first example is that we said that based on putting it in standard form, we actually altered the ODE. It automatically "rules out" some values, namely 0. D was the only one that didn't include 0, so that's why we THOUGHT that it was the answer, due to it being the largest bound in the MCQ not including 0. However it turns out that 0 is just as valid. 

As for your second example, I'm not too sure. I'd like an instructor to clear this up. My current understanding leads me to believe that -5/2 is irrelevant in terms of finding when y(t)>0, but I'm not sure where it mentions that we're finding when y(t)>0. 

Edit: When we found the derivative of mu*y,  we also understand that if t = -5/2 then the derivative will just be 0 permanently. This is potentially a solution, but I guess it isn't as much of a use??? Idk LOL

Can someone show the specific steps to solve this problem?
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-01T04:55:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Moosa Saboor", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukzdvejp3mt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T06:29:19Z", "content": "

You first realize that this is a "separable ODE" because we can write $$\frac{dP}{dt} = 1P(1-P)$$. Rearranging, you get $$\frac{dP}{P(1-P)}=dt$$ (on suppose que $$P\ne 0,1$$). Integrate both sides, you get $$\int\frac{1}{P(1-P)}\,dP=\int1\,dt$$. Using partial fraction decomposition, you can compute $$\ln|P|-\ln|1-P|=t+C$$, hence $$|\frac{P}{1-P}|=e^{t+C}=e^te^C$$. Let $$C_1=e^C$$, then $$|\frac{P}{1-P}|=C_1e^t$$.

If we remove the absolute value operation, there are two branches and we write $$\frac{P}{1-P}=\pm C_1e^t$$. Note that the only difference between the two is the sign, and this can be combined with the multiplicative constant, so we can write $$\frac{P}{1-P}=C_2e^t$$. Since $$P\ne1$$, we have $$P=C_2e^t - C_2Pe^t$$, so $$P=\frac{C_2e^t}{1+C_2e^t}$$.

For the IVP, we assume that $$P(0)=P_0\ge0$$. There are two potential problem values $$P_0=0$$ and $$P_0=1$$. For now, we simply evaluate $$P(t)=\frac{C_2e^t}{1+C_2e^t}$$ à $$t=0$$. We have $$P_0=\frac{C_2e^0}{1+C_2e^0}$$, then $$P_0=\frac{C_2}{1+C_2}$$, then $$P_0+C_2P_0=C_2$$. Thus $$C_2=\frac{P_0}{1-P_0}$$.

Now we check that this works for $$P_0=0$$. If it does, we have $$C_2=0$$, $$P(t)$$ becomes $$P(t)=0$$. This function satisfies the differential equation, so this solution works for $$P_0=0$$.

But we're not so lucky with $$P_0=1$$ because our expression for $$C_2$$ isn't defined there. But note that $$\frac{dP}{dt}$$ is constant when $$P(t)=1$$, so we can define $$P(t)=1$$ when $$P_0=1$$.

This gives us a piecewise function dependant on the value of $$P_0$$.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T04:55:34Z", "content": "

You first realize that this is a "separable ODE". g(y) = P(1-P) and f(t) = 1. This means that dP/dt = P(1-P)*1. Rearranging, you'll get dP/(P(1-P)) = dt. Integrate both sides, you'll get integral of 1/(P(1-P)) (respect to P) is equal to integral of 1 (respect to dt). Partial decomposition, and you'll get ln|P|-ln|1-P| = t+C. |P/(1-P)| = e^(t+C). We assume that C>0, so then we can get the coefficient C1 (e^C). Now because e^t*positive constant is always positive, then there's no need for the absolute values anymore. P/(1-P) = C1e^t.

P = C1e^t * (1-P). Distributing and rearranging, we'll get P = C1e^t/(1+C1e^t). We assumed C1 does not equal 0 as we carried out these last few steps, because e^anything cannot equal 0. 

I'm not entirely sure of why we assume C>0. I outlined my guess, but I would like an instructor to clarify.

When we have a multivariate equation on the reals (or complexes), the solution set comprises all the n-tuples (where n equals the number of variables) that make the equation true upon substitution. For example, consider $$x^2+y^2=1$$. We can show that the set of solutions $$S$$ equals $$\left\{ (x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^2 : x\in[-1,1], y=\pm\sqrt{1-x^2} \right\}$$.

For equations where one of the unknown values is a function, does the same idea hold? That is, given a function and a variable, is the set of solutions equal to some subset of $$\mathbb{R}\times(\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R})$$ (tuple of numbers and functions)? If this is the case, then are there any requirements on the function for how many numbers pair with it?

As an example, consider the equation $$xf(x)=1$$, where $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$ and $$f:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ is a function. Assuming $$x\ne0$$ we have $$f(x)=\frac{1}{x}$$. So a subset of the solution set is $$\left\{ (x,\frac{1}{x}):x\in\mathbb{R}^* \right\}$$.

However, notice that this equation also holds for $$f(x)=1$$ if we only consider the domain to be $$\{1\}$$. In fact, we have that $$x\cdot x^{2n}=1$$ for all $$n\in\mathbb{Z}$$ when $$x=1$$, and that $$x\cdot x^{2n+1}=1$$ for all $$n\in\mathbb{Z}$$ when $$x\in\{-1,1\}$$.

Do we still consider these functions to be valid components to a solution (i.e. the function component of the pair) despite the extremely restricted domain? What about in the case of a differential equation?

One _could_ say that the solution to this equation for $$y:(0,\infty)\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ is $$y=\ln(x)+C, C\in\mathbb{R}$$, and they'd be correct, but this is incomplete by most standards, and you'd probably only get partial marks if you wrote down this solution on a test. The actual full solution set would be something like: $$y:\mathbb{R}^*\mapsto\mathbb{R};$$$$y(x)=\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \ln(-x)+C_1, & x<0 \\ \ln(x)+C_2, & x>0 \end{array} \right.$$

I can't talk about lecture content, but for your question about logistic functions:

\n

\n

For any logistic function $$P(t)$$ we have $$\\frac{dP}{dt}=-k(P-m_n)(P-m_x)$$, where $$k$$ is the proportionality factor, $$m_n$$ is the minimum value, and $$m_x$$ is the maximum value.

"lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T18:03:55Z", "content": "

I suggest checking openstax.

the differential logistic equation is provided as $$\frac{dP}{dt}=rP(1-\frac{P}{K})$$ where $$K$$ is the upper limit and $$r$$ is the growth rate. you can tell this works because there are two clear equilibrium solutions at $$P=0$$ and $$P=K$$ which give you the asymptotes of a logistic function. $$r$$ also scales the "aggressiveness" of the slope of the function. you may also replace the first equilibrium solution determined by $$P$$ with $$(1-\frac{P}{k})$$ if you need a different lower limit.

the integration of this function is also given in the openstax chapter which you can probably figure out yourself.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul3hccbr41t", "lm7ukyklcmy3k9", "lm7ul67t8hv4a2", "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "lm7ukbe4zq21kc", "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "lm707z2w6xl733", "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "lm7ukrjw9d22xr"], "children": [], "id": "ls3ius3j25n711", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ul3hccbr41t", "lm7ul67t8hv4a2", "lm7uksa5i342zo", "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "lm7uk96a8bm1dp"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls3hxeuhf4s5lc", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 5, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173212649, "default_anonymity": "no"}
