Also, the "not negated" part... is that saying we need to write the solution so C has to always be positive?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 126, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-01T19:34:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jessica Varriale", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukm34ttf2hc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T19:34:39Z", "content": "

It is saying that you should "merge" constant multiplicative terms into a single constant. For example, given $$2e^{t+C_1} = 2e^{C_1}e^t$$, you would define a new constant variable equal to $$2e^{C_1}$$ so that the equation is overall written as $$Ce^t$$.

Also it is not saying that $$C$$ is necessarily positive -- it means that negative signs are merged into the constant value, so $$C$$ can actually be any real number.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T19:34:28Z", "content": "

It is saying that you should "merge" constant multiplicative terms into a single constant. For example, given $$2e^{t+C_1} = 2e^{C_1}e^t$$, you would define a new constant variable equal to $$2e^C$$ so that the equation is overall written as $$Ce^t$$.

Also it is not saying that $$C$$ is necessarily positive -- it means that negative signs are merged into the constant value, so $$C$$ can actually be any real number.

You may have made an algebraic error;

$$y = e^{x+C} *e^{-ln(1-y)}$$

The form $$e^{x+C}$$ resembles $$a^{b+c} = a^ba^c$$, while $$e^{-ln(1-y)}$$ can be simplified with the rule 7 from above.

Also, keep in mind that the original question is also multiplying both $$e^{x+C}$$ and $$e^{-ln(1-y)}$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 351, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-02T16:38:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls4vcuqzbik530", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-02T16:38:03Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ls5m58xy8e21aj", "to": "ls4vcuqrx3452z", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-03T05:07:58Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "ls4vcuqrx3452z", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-03T05:13:07Z", "cid": "ls5mbv1rxb13lt"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2017 Term Test 2 - Question 9 (a)", "created": "2024-02-02T16:38:03Z", "content": "

In this question, I am getting the answer as t = (-19)/(20k) after having solved it multiple times. This would only be valid if k is a negative constant of proportionality. Hence, is that the case here, or is the answer different?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 96, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-03T05:07:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-03T05:07:58Z", "content": "

This question is a bit odd because it uses the word "speed" (scalar speed) instead of "velocity" (vector speed); assuming it's not a mistake we have that $$\left|\frac{dy}{dt}\right|=ky^2$$ rather than $$\frac{dy}{dt}=ky^2$$. If it's actually a mistake and they meant vector speed, the value of $$k$$ could be negative (meaning the speed vector is in the $$-\hat{j}$$ direction), but for my answer I'll assume the use of "speed" is intentional.

From $$\left|\frac{dy}{dt}\right|=ky^2$$ we deduce that $$k\ge 0$$ because $$y^2\ge 0$$ and the expression on the right must be positive. From here there are two possibilities: (1) $$\frac{dy}{dt}=-ky^2$$ or (2) $$\frac{dy}{dt}=ky^2$$. Integrating the two we have (1) $$y=\frac{1}{kt+C_1}$$ and (2) $$y=-\frac{1}{kt+C_2}$$.

We know that $$y(0)=20$$, so we calculate $$C_1=\frac{1}{20}$$ and $$C_2=-\frac{1}{20}$$. So we have (1) $$y=-\frac{20}{20kt+1}$$ and (2) $$y=-\frac{20}{20kt-1}=\frac{20}{1-20kt}$$.

Solving for $$t$$ when $$y=1$$:

(1) $$1=\frac{20}{20kt+1} \implies 20kt=19 \implies t=\frac{19}{20k}$$.

(2) $$1=\frac{20}{1-20kt} \implies -19=20kt \implies t=-\frac{19}{20k}$$.

Since $$t\ge 0$$ by convention we know that the second equation is impossible, so we have $$t=\frac{19}{20k}$$. (Intuitively we know the velocity should be negative since the plane is descending, so $$-ky^2$$ makes more sense.)

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ls5m58xru9v1ai", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Also a little fact for you: in French we don't have different words for "velocity" and "speed" (that answer was really annoying to write...).", "created": "2024-02-03T05:13:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls5mbv1rxb13lt", "updated": "2024-02-03T05:13:09Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls4vcuqrx3452z", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173226743, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Where did the 2x2 matrix come from?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-04T03:06:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgl49p220m", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-04T03:06:11Z", "content": "Consider two complex numbers (a+bi) and (c+di). You can represent both as a 2x1 vector where the second dimension represents the coefficient of i. Multiplying these numbers out, you get ac+(ad+bc)i-bd. Now instead you represent (a+bi) as the matrix. Try multiplying the vector \u00a0(c, d) with the given matrix. You get (ac-bd, ad+bc) which is the same as what you get by multiplying them out, just in vector form.\u00a0"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ls6x8h0y71z3al", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls6ni1jsro74pc", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173240832, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "note", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 119, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "When you are asked for value of P is P' the largest, you may consider the graph of P' against P which you have got correctly in the first part. What type of graph is it and how can you find the maximum value of P'?", "created": "2024-02-04T01:07:59Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jenny Chung", "endorser": {"lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1706843588}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I've spent a little more time thinking about it, but I'm still lost and I don't really know where I went wrong:

I've found the maxima for P''(x), for each scenario (0.45M for 5% and -0.25M for 75%). Both graphs of P'(x) are also concave down parabolas.

For the 5% scenario, the maxima of P'(x) (0.45M) occurs in a valid interval ( 0<= P <= M) so the information would be spreading fastest at P = 0.45M.

For the 75% scenario, the maxima of P'(x) (-0.25M) is not in a valid interval, so the information would be spreading fastest at P = 0, since the graph is concave down.

Could you please point out where I went wrong?

", "created": "2024-02-04T01:34:40Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ls6tyst1iw12bv", "updated": "2024-02-04T01:34:41Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I believe that your approach by using the second derivative is valid (I have not tried that but your calculations appear correct), but it is incorrect to replace kP(M-P) with k(P+0.75M)(M-(P+0.75M)). Let's assume M=100 and your P would equal 75. In your case, you replaced P with (P+0.75M). That is like saying 75 people who have the info + another 75% of the population (assume M = 100 in my example) now know. Now you've made P equal to (75+75) which isn't correct. So I would recommend simple taking the second derivative of kP(M-P) and that should give you the right answer!", "created": "2024-02-04T16:54:19Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jenny Chung", "endorser": {"lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1706843588}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1bsu483t3", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ul1bsu483t3"], "id": "ls7qtgpa7st1bp", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-04T18:51:15Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I got the right answer- I was overthinking the problem. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork"], "nr": 372, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-04T22:00:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls81rmsl9vu37s", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-04T22:00:49Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ls8eejsw4xm2y6", "to": "ls81rmsd68l37q", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-05T03:54:34Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "webwork 4 problem 7 a) and b)", "created": "2024-02-04T22:00:49Z", "content": "

For part a): why is the answer P=0? When i took the derivative of dP/dt=k(M-P) and set it to 0 to find the max/mins of dP/dt, I got -k=0. But I don't know how to proceed with that

For part b), I'm honestly completely lost and don't know what to do:

Here's my attempt (I tried solving the ODE by separating it and using PFD, but I don't think It got me anywhere.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 114, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T03:54:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Youssef Rachad", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T03:54:34Z", "content": "

For a) there's probably an error in your solution; treating $$\frac{dP}{dt}=kP(M-P)$$ as a function of $$P(t)$$ (call it $$f$$) gives $$\frac{df}{dP}=k\left[M-P+PM\right]$$, a linear equation.

For b) you made a mistake in the 4th line, the equation should be $$\int\frac{1}{PM}+\frac{1}{M^2-PM}\, dP=kt+C$$. Remembering that $$M$$ is constant we can also write $$\frac{1}{M} \int\frac{1}{P}+\frac{1}{M-P}\, dP = kt+C$$, and then you can find an expression for $$P(t)$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ksaailfs7ix4ne"], "children": [], "id": "ls8eejspdiw2y5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls81rmsd68l37q", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173249530, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I have a quick question. For problem 2 in written homework 2, when it says "find H(t) which keeps the temperature inside the cabin fixed at 20 degrees over the 6 hours", are we looking for a function H(t) or a constant H(t) that satisfies the differential equation? Attached is the screenshot of the question for easier context. Thanks.

It's hard to answer your question without giving away the whole answer to the problem. But think about this way: there is enough context given in the question to derive T'(t), A(t), and T(t) each as either a constant or function, within the entire 6-hour interval. Thus, you can substitute these expressions into the given ODE directly and thus solve for H(t).

Hope this helps!

I solved it a bit earlier, but thanks for tip! 

To Anon. Mouse: v(t) is given as such but we are required to convert it to v(x)- it's just a task they decided to give us along the way to solving the ODE.

My suggestion is writing the chain rule out in leibniz notation.

", "created": "2024-02-06T02:36:53Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ls9r2hxp5h2711", "updated": "2024-02-06T02:36:53Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

when I differentiate v(t) with respect to t, I get $$\frac{d}{dt}(v(t))=\frac{d}{dt}(\frac{dx}{dt})=\frac{dv}{dx}\cdot \frac{dx}{dt}= \frac{dv}{dx}\cdot v(t)=\frac{d^2x}{dt^2}$$ 

Is there something I'm missing or a rule i'm not following?

Looking at Anon. Mouse's comment above we see how to rewrite velocity as a function of x We have the derivative of v wrt t and we recall that v is in fact the derivative of x wrt to t so effectively we have v(x(t)). When we apply the chain rule, we have to take the derivative of v wrt x and multiply it by the derivative of x wrt t. Does this mean we can assume that the internal temperature remains constant at T(t)=20? This would make the question quite simple.

Which is the correct interpretation?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 388, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T05:05:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls9we5svkk54uu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-06T05:05:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ls9wj33uyug10m", "to": "ls9we5smfh64us", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-06T05:09:45Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ls9we5smfh64us", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-06T19:16:21Z", "cid": "lsaqru3qpto7ek", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "to": "ls9we5smfh64us", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-06T21:00:21Z", "cid": "lsauhko9pu3q0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ls9we5smfh64us", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-08T21:27:40Z", "cid": "lsdqce7a7lzm5", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "to": "ls9we5smfh64us", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-09T23:47:16Z", "cid": "lsfarsgvzzx73p"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ls9we5smfh64us", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-10T15:25:39Z", "cid": "lsg8ajz28bb1s6", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Homework 2 Question 2 Uses T'(t) In Two ODEs", "created": "2024-02-06T05:05:55Z", "content": "

Hello, Question 2 uses T'(t) and T(t) in two separate ODEs. However, their relation is a little unclear. Mathematically, it is impossible for T'(t) and T(t) to be the same between both ODEs unless H(t) = 0, which obviously isn't the case. Thus, there follows two interpretations of the question:

1. T(t) is the same in both ODES, but T'(t) is different. 

2. T(t) and T'(t) in ODE 1 are different to the T(t) and T'(t) in ODE 2.

I was wondering if I could get confirmation on which interpretation is correct, as each interpretation could lead to a different solution.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Keaton Bailie", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukotj9jp2qd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 202, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T05:09:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-06T05:09:45Z", "content": "The purpose in adding a heater was to change the behaviour of T and T’ so that a constant temperature is maintained. "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ls9wj33ojop10l", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "If we followed the logic within the student answer (the second line of thinking), the question becomes extremely simple. We would ignore the first ODE and take T(t) as a constant function in the second ODE. Subsequently, finding H(t) would be a two line solution, which doesn't make sense given that we're provided 2 pages to answer. Therefore, I believe the first line of thinking proposed is correct since it would actually involve solving an ODE. I would like instructor input to clarify this confusion.", "created": "2024-02-06T19:16:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Let's think about this physically: In the first ODE, we are told that the temperature changes proportionately to the difference between the current temperature and the ambient temperature. In the second, the temperature changes similarly but with an additional input. So we can see that T'(t) is different in both ODEs already. Suppose we are at ambient temperature (at mathematical equilibrium), meaning that T(t) = A(t), then in the first ODE the change in temperature is 0 and will remain 0 (do you see how this is true?). However, in the second ODE the change in temperature becomes the heater's input H(t) so we may still have changes. From a purely mathematical perspective, we say that the first equation is homogeneous and that the second is not homogeneous. Lastly, note that the question brings your focus on the second ODE where there is (thankfully) a heater in the cabin.", "created": "2024-02-06T21:00:21Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Keaton Bailie", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukotj9jp2qd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukotj9jp2qd"], "id": "lsauhko9pu3q0", "updated": "2024-02-07T17:11:46Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Sorry but I still don't really understand. If T(t)=A(t) that would mean the temperature is changing. But this would also mean T'(t)=0, which implies there is no temperature change. I think I'm having difficulty understanding how T'(t) and T(t) relate in this question.", "created": "2024-02-08T21:27:40Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rithvika Kathroju", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lly6utysh6g2ms", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lly6utysh6g2ms"], "id": "lsdqce7a7lzm5", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-09T15:51:04Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "T(t) and T'(t) are related in Newton's law of cooling by the way that the change in temperature depends on the current temperature (and a reference temperature we call "ambient"). If T(t) = A(t) then the temperature is following the ambient temperature and only implies that T'(t) is 0 if A(t) is a constant value. In this exercise, you are asked to consider an ambient temperature that varies linearly as the day goes by and to describe how a heater can be adjusted to ensure a temperature T(t) of 20 degrees is maintained.", "created": "2024-02-09T23:47:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Keaton Bailie", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukotj9jp2qd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukotj9jp2qd"], "id": "lsfarsgvzzx73p", "updated": "2024-02-10T15:25:02Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Thank you so so much for your response! When you use integration by substitution to replace one variable with another, you must replace all instances of the first with the second. In your solution there is a $$x$$ in the differential term for $$a$$. Using your substitution, the correct method is:

$$a=\ln(2x) \Rightarrow e^a=2x \Rightarrow = \frac{e^a}{2}=x$$

$$da=\frac{2}{2x}dx=\frac{1}{x}dx \Rightarrow x\,da=dx \Rightarrow \frac{e^a}{2}\,da=dx$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk1byd3xly"], "children": [], "id": "lsajcgtvvoj5mf", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls9yws6uexk6wj", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173267979, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I am a bit confused; I believe my answers up until now are more or less accurate as they are straight forward to me.

I came to this ODE here: 

$$2(\frac{F}{m}x+C)=v(x)^2$$

After solving v(0) = V as the question asks in Part (3). I am struggling to conclude how we can show velocity decreases with x:

$$2(\frac{F}{m}x+\frac{V^2}{2})=v^2$$

My only sound reasoning is that F is acting in the opposite direction to V, and therefore should be negative hence multiplying by x would result in a subtraction from the initial velocity which over distance (x increases) the current velocity of the rocket decreases. But continuing with this equation results in negative answers for what should be positive like in Part (4) (granted, I could make the same argument stating F is acting in the opposite direction and should be negative, but I am unsure). 

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated, thank you! 

Just had a realization, what if we are supposed to set the equations (newly modified one and the -GMm/(x+R)^2) together?

I am a bit confused; I believe my answers up until now are more or less accurate as they are straight forward to me.

I came to this ODE here: 

$$2(\frac{F}{m}x+C)=v(x)^2$$

After solving v(0) = V as the question asks in Part (3). I am struggling to conclude how we can show velocity decreases with x:

$$2(\frac{F}{m}x+\frac{V^2}{2})=v^2$$

My only sound reasoning is that F is acting in the opposite direction to V, and therefore should be negative hence multiplying by x would result in a subtraction from the initial velocity which over distance (x increases) the current velocity of the rocket decreases. But continuing with this equation results in negative answers for what should be positive like in Part (4) (granted, I could make the same argument stating F is acting in the opposite direction and should be negative, but I am unsure). 

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated, thank you!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam", "other"], "nr": 395, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T18:30:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsap4p76j215w6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-06T18:30:22Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "data": "lsav3804zhv6yi", "to": "lsap4p6en5e5w3", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-06T21:17:11Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsepyoxz6833ji", "to": "lsap4p6en5e5w3", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-09T14:04:46Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Integration question:", "created": "2024-02-06T18:30:22Z", "content": "I have a question about the concept of integration. 

I have seen this happen a few times in different subjects: IMG_5712_2024_02_06.jpeg


But what fundamental laws of calculus allow this to happen? Like, why can we integrate both sides of the equation? 
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 89, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T21:17:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-06T21:17:11Z", "content": "The rigourous mechanisms behind this are a bit beyond the scope of this course but I can try to offer some intuition. Let's say I have some rectangle in a 2D plane. If I cut it up into very small rectangles, then I can sum up those rectangles to recover the original area. Now notice that I can achieve the same result if I instead cut up very small triangles (or just a different shape) and integrate it all back together. In later engineering applications, you might find that this way of thinking is useful for instance if you have some small volume $$\mathrm dV$$ and you instead want to express it as a small length times a small area $$\mathrm dl\mathrm dA$$ so you can write something similar to $$\int\mathrm dV = \int\mathrm dl\mathrm dA$$ and make the problem on the left easier to solve. To be clear, this is beyond the course but learning maths is fun!"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsav37zzxoj6yh", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-09T14:04:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-09T14:04:46Z", "content": "

This site gives the best explanation I could find: https://math.stackexchange.com/a/2873736.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0103"], "nr": 396, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T18:38:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsapfikldmm4ks", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-06T18:38:47Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsaqi5nkl7i6at", "to": "lsapfikcnv94kr", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-06T19:08:50Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsapfikcnv94kr", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-06T19:17:18Z", "cid": "lsaqt1v3myr5n0", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "lsapfikcnv94kr", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-06T19:20:39Z", "cid": "lsaqxcmr8cs3wy"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Divergence and odd function", "created": "2024-02-06T18:38:47Z", "content": "

This question is taken from lecture 0103 for A5-2. I understand that if we split it into 2 sides, each side is divergence. However, since the function is an odd function, may I know would the 2 sides cancel out and become 0?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 84, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T19:08:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Michael Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukyo3net3km", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-06T19:08:50Z", "content": "

When you have diverging limits you can't cancel them; their difference is an indeterminate form because of the definition of a limit (see A). So the improper integral itself is still undefined. But there's another value, called "Cauchy Principal Value" (PV for short), defined for integrals in this form. For this question:

$$\displaystyle \text{PV}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{x}{x^2+1} \, dx = \lim\limits_{R\to\infty} \int_{-R}^R \frac{x}{x^2+1} \, dx = \lim\limits_{R\to\infty} \frac{1}{2} \left[ \ln\left|x^2+1\right| \right]^R_{-R}$$

$$\displaystyle =\frac{1}{2} \lim\limits_{R\to\infty} \ln\left|R^2+1\right|-\ln\left|(-R)^2+1\right| = \frac{1}{2} \lim\limits_{R\to\infty} \ln\left|\frac{R^2+1}{R^2+1}\right| = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 0 = 0$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukyo3net3km"], "children": [], "id": "lsaqi5ncnem6as", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Thanks! But based on what you did how is it different from the regular way of evaluating improper integral? Is it in Cauchy Principal Value you can have the limit on both the upper and lower bound (whereas in the regular way the limit can only be applied to either the upper or lower bound)?", "created": "2024-02-06T19:17:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Chris Mak", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1695815518, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1705340166, "global": 1705340166, "lr51f0oibsv66y": 1705923949}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Exactly -- an improper integral can normally have only one open bound, but with Cauchy Principal Value we can have two open bounds.", "created": "2024-02-06T19:20:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsaqxcmr8cs3wy", "updated": "2024-02-06T19:21:17Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukqff3d82v1"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsaqt1v3myr5n0", "updated": "2024-02-06T21:25:29Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsapfikcnv94kr", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173275576, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PCE-complex numbers", "created": "2024-02-06T19:30:40Z", "content": "I don't understand the underlined section, I've reread it a few times. could someone explain/reword it"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T21:46:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-06T21:46:14Z", "content": "Recall from the trig functions you've already studied that $$\sin(2\pi*n+x) = \sin(x)$$ and similar relations. We say that sine and cosine are $$2\pi$$ periodic for example. This can pose a challenge when we move into complex functions because now I have some function that potentially returns infinitely many values for a given input. To remedy this, we say that our arguments (the $$\theta$$ variable) has to be inside some interval of length $$2\pi$$ and here we've picked a fairly standard choice of $$(-\pi;\pi]$$ (can you see why one of the ends is open and the other is closed?). Now our functions can return infinitely many outputs but we only choose the one that lies in the agreed interval and say that we only consider "the principal argument". Hope this clears up the definition,"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsaw4kif3kk4bg", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Thats very helpful thank you!", "created": "2024-02-07T13:26:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsbtq7cy46l5jl", "updated": "2024-02-07T13:26:55Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsara8pkm4g7b2", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173277742, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Not quite, I personally am stating that x will now be 0. So v(0) = Vfinal. 

If you state v(0) = 0 that is implying there is no velocity upon impact. 

Since v(0) = Vf and v(0) = V will be the exact same equation, I think perhaps we are trying to justify V = Vf, which we know from dynamics.

Hello,

I would suggest taking the absolute value.

Recall from MIE100 that speed is a scalar. It is impossible for speed to be negative because speed doesnt contain a direction.

Two objects with velocities x m/s [away from origin] and x m/s [towards origin] both have a speed of x.

you can use l'hopital's after this manipulation

$$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to0}\log(\sqrt{x})\sqrt{x}=\lim_{x\to0}\log(\sqrt{x})\sqrt{x}\times\frac{\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}}$$

and so on...

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 415, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-08T16:51:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsdghgrqkq72g9", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-08T16:51:40Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "data": "lsdylw0xl6v2is", "to": "lsdghgrized2g8", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-09T01:18:59Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Midterm confirmation about notation", "created": "2024-02-08T16:51:40Z", "content": "

In the midterm, when solving an ODE by separation would writing:

$$\frac{dy}{dx} = f(x) \longrightarrow dy = f(x)dx \longrightarrow \int dy = \int f(x)\,dx $$

instead of writing

$$\frac{dy}{dx} = f(x) \longrightarrow \frac{dy}{dx}\,dx = f(x)\,dx  \longrightarrow \int \frac{dy}{dx}\,dx = \int f(x)\,dx $$

lose me points because it's "technically wrong"?

I'm hyper paranoid of pointlessly losing out on marks from the exams of Calc1

false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-09T02:51:12Z", "content": "

T(0)=20 is always true because the initial condition applies to both scenarios.

T(t) varies with time. The temperature in the room is going to increase or decrease as time increases. 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk8faaan1b5"], "children": [], "id": "lse1wh77e2g7ms", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "In reply to the student answer: But doesn't the question state that T(t) will be constant at 20 degrees? So how will it vary with time?", "created": "2024-02-09T03:49:08Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

In my understanding, the "constant 20 degrees" is achieved only after the work done by the heater. T(t) itself isn't constant, but H(t) does something that makes T(t) becomes constant. Keep in mind that H(t) is a part of T'(t) and not T(t). 

T(t) still varies with time, and our job is to find a H(t) that will counter the change in T(t) that makes the overall temperature constant

true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-09T14:06:16Z", "content": "

" if ans and process is right why do we need to write paragraphs on it."

This is a very good question. Indeed understanding 1) why you need to do this  AND 2) how to do this are both among the learning objectives of this course and the other first-year math courses. Your tutorial and HW feedback are designed to help you see where you can improve this skill.  A major difference between mathematical expectations in high school and university lies in communication skills.

Math communication is an important skill for you as a future engineer. As an engineer, you will work as a part of a group and will apply your mathematical knowledge to various applied contexts. However, not everyone in yoru group has the same background knowledge as you do. Imagine yourself pitching a solution to various admin and management levels of your company. It is not enough to say I have the correct final answer. Your report should convince your reader (who may have little math knowledge) that you know what you are doing. Writing so that someone who knows the problem agrees that you had the correct idea is not the goal here. Your writing should be in such a way that it leaves no room for doubting your idea. It should be bulletproof.

This is not the skill you gain in one tutorial HW, or even one course. This a continuous multi-year process. however, it is important to realize that this si the goal you are moving towards. 

As for specifics of being able to realize where and exactly what needed more explanation and why I encourage you to read the provided solution and compare your 1) writing style and 2 ) your reasoning with the solution. Some questions that you can ask yourself: is my answer formulated in full and sense-making sentences? is every step and idea I used justified? Did I clearly state every assumption I made and why I had to make it. 

After this exercise you maybe able to answer your own question. If not, bring your work to the teaching team and we will be happy to help you find where are the areas of improvement.

Hi, 

I understand the need for good communication in mathematics, and see merit in having course work reflect this learning standard. 

I was just wondering whether an instructor could direct me to a good resource with which I may better understand both what constitutes good communication in mathematics (common practice, what is necessary to be explained etc.), and through which means I should communicate this (common short-hand symbols which may reduce the time required to write out plain english). 

Thanks for your advice.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Grace Lin", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul4axlho44n", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T01:46:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T01:46:34Z", "content": "

This is a good question. Below is a list of resources that serve as good math communication examples in our course and those that do not. 

Good examples:

Pre class readings
Textbook examples 

The solution to written HW problems

Solutions to tutorials (although these are written very minimally, and in some instances can be improved)

Bad examples:

lecture notes (during lectures, we focus on communicating the main ideas and not on writing everything clearly and correctly. Lecture notes should not be used as examples of good writing).

Well I think you can always reference previous parts. But using v(0)=V isn’t technically correct. Since V is the initial velocity, we are looking for x_max. You’d have to consider V(x_max).

(What is velocity at max height? <- Hint)

", "created": "2024-02-09T17:26:18Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I'm a bit confused. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tutorials"], "nr": 438, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T00:19:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsfbx1iuaupdo", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T00:19:21Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lsfdzklctnl1ds", "to": "lsfbx1inrx0dn", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T01:17:18Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Error Bound Question", "created": "2024-02-10T00:19:21Z", "content": "Can anyone explain how they got the upper bound of f'(x) < 6 and upper bound for f''(x) < 34? I tried using triangle inequalties but am not sure how to estimate the bounds."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tutorials"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T01:17:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T01:17:18Z", "content": "

this is generally just an optimization question from mat186 where you solve for the global maximum on the interval, which is (obviously) the definite upper bound, and replace $$e$$ with $$2$$ or $$3$$ depending on which gives the largest value.

\n

\n

the solution manual also gives an easier but less precise solution, where you separate the terms into their individual maximums and multiply them. for example, the maximum of $$xe^x$$ over $$[0,3]$$ is $$3$$ for $$x$$ and $$3^3$$ for $$e^x$$ giving an upper bound of $$3\\times3^3$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsfdzkl6i171dr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsfbx1inrx0dn", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173321139, "default_anonymity": "no"}

For this question, 

> Part (A): My ODE for T1' is in terms of both T2(t) and T1(t), and it is simply flipped for T2'. Is this okay? In other words, can I write the ODE of this in terms of both T1 and T2? 

I do this because for the rate out you need T1, and for the rate in you need T2 unless I am misunderstanding this question

> Part (B): The follow up to this is that in this part, I cannot seem to eliminate t at all or rewrite it in terms of T1. 

I was able to rewrite T2 in terms of T1 due to the nature of the setup and initial salt content. But eliminating t has me stumped (is it even possible?). 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "HW2 Q3 General Questions", "created": "2024-02-10T02:19:40Z", "content": "

For this question, 

> Part (A): My ODE for T1' is in terms of both T2(t) and T1(t), and it is simply flipped for T2'. Is this okay? In other words, can I write the ODE of this in terms of both T1 and T2? 

I do this because for the rate out you need T1, and for the rate in you need T2 unless I am misunderstanding this question

> Part (B): The follow up to this is that in this part, I cannot seem to eliminate t at all or rewrite it in terms of T1. 

I was able to rewrite T2 in terms of T1 due to the nature of the setup and initial salt content. But eliminating t has me stumped

$$\displaystyle ab\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left(1-\cos\left(2x\right)\right)dx$$

$$\displaystyle ab\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\sin\left(2x\right)\right)_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}$$
$$\displaystyle ab\left(\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{1}{2}\sin{(\pi)}\right)-\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{1}{2}\sin{(-\pi)}\right)\right)$$
$$\displaystyle ab\left(\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)-\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T04:34:02Z", "content": "

Why does the below answer include "- theta" inside tangent? Shouldn't the conversion be from sec^2 - 1 to tan^2, with the angle remaining the same? I think it has something to do with the bounds of integration but I'm not sure how that is calculated or derived, so an explanation would be helpful.

Thank you

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lec A2 Question", "created": "2024-02-10T15:37:30Z", "content": "Why does the below answer include "- theta" inside tangent? Shouldn't the conversion be from sec^2 - 1 to tan^2, with the angle remaining the same?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 66, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T15:41:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Kia Salehzadeh", "endorser": {"lr51f0oibsv66y": 1705011281}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk2nchjopf", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T15:48:32Z", "content": "

We intentionally transformed $$\tan^2(\theta)$$ to $$\sec^2(\theta)-1$$ because we know the primitives of $$\sec^2(\theta)$$ and $$1$$.

$$\displaystyle 4\int\sec^2(\theta)-1\,d\theta = 4\left[\int\sec^2(\theta)\,d\theta+\int\,d\theta\right]=4\left(\tan(\theta)+\theta\right)+C$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T15:42:06Z", "content": "

The second $$\theta$$ is not inside $$\tan$$ in the answer.

$$\displaystyle 4\int\sec^2(\theta)-1\,d\theta = 4\left[\int\sec^2\,d\theta+\int\,d\theta\right]=4\left(\tan(\theta)+\theta\right)+C$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T15:41:43Z", "content": "

Le deuxième $$\theta$$ n'est pas à l'intérieur de $$\tan$$ dans la réponse.

$$\displaystyle 4\int\sec^2(\theta)-1\,d\theta = 4\left[\int\sec^2\,d\theta+\int\,d\theta\right]=4\left(\tan(\theta)+\theta\right)+C$$

Hello all,

Just a wording confusion:

The instructions say "Note that the dependence of v is on x. I think what it means to say is "Hey, just so you know, we wrote our initial value in v(x) for your convenience. Enjoy."

But I can't help but interpret as "Oh, just so you know, we wrote this in terms of v(t), so you're gonna have to figure out how write in terms of x instead."

I have no issues with the computation, but I'm just wondering if we should interpret v(0) = V as v(t) = V, t = 0; OR v(x) = V, x = 0.

Cheers.

----------------------

I just came back 30 seconds after posting this and realized it wouldn't matter. Since v(x) depends on x (obv) then if it's t=0, x=0, since we launch from Earth, and thus v(0) would be just plug in x=0. 

And if it's x = 0, then obviously you just plug in and get the same thing.

Did I answer my own question or should I still be confused?

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 460, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T18:51:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgfn6kpcyx1f8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T18:51:26Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgfogfxzix4br", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-10T18:52:25Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lsgkru1kr3n6cr", "to": "lsgfn6kg9ty1f4", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T21:15:01Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lsgkt2zcbj5173", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-10T21:15:59Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lsgku2mo2s52tb", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-10T21:16:45Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lsgkv76g7i650e", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-10T21:17:38Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WH2 Q1 (a)", "created": "2024-02-10T18:52:25Z", "content": "

While working through Question 1 (a), I found that:

d^2x/dt^2 = dv/dt = dv/dx * dx/dt

∴ v'(x) * v(t) = -GM/(x(t)+R)^2    (knowing that dx/dt = v(t))

At this point, this equation does not appear to be a function of v & x only, because x & v are still described in terms of t.

However, according to https://piazza.com/class/lqvcjvs6s457j1/post/376_f2, this equation should only be in terms of x & v (and thus be a solution to the question). I'm struggling to understand why this is the case, or if I'm misunderstanding this comment entirely. Any help would be appreciated.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WH2 Q1 (a):", "created": "2024-02-10T18:51:26Z", "content": "

While working through Question 1 (a), I found that:

d^2x/dt^2 = dv/dt = dv/dx * dx/dt

∴ v'(x) * v(t) = -GM/(x(t)+R)^2    (knowing that dx/dt = v(t))

At this point, this equation does not appear to be a function of v & x only, because x & v are still described in terms of t.

However, according to https://piazza.com/class/lqvcjvs6s457j1/post/376_f2, this equation should only be in terms of x & v (and thus be a solution to the question). I'm struggling to understand why this is the case, or if I'm misunderstanding this comment entirely. Any help would be appreciated.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nolan Young", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llybf3v7jvw6eu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Zain Azam", "endorser": {"lm9adkj19uo1ed": 1702067024, "llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1702910533, "global": 1702949437, "lr51f0oibsv66y": 1704997524, "lr1jp5yrvb87hx": 1707418143, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1707455183}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 146, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T21:15:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T21:17:38Z", "content": "

it does not really matter. $$v$$ can be a function of $$t$$, $$x$$, and plenty of other things, as long as the variables are codependent. when you evaluate the ODE at any point, all that matters is the current value of $$v$$ which can be evaluated through any means.

it happens that, since $$x$$ and $$t$$ are dependent on each other, saying $$v(x(t))$$ is equivalent to $$v(t(x))$$ (the functions are different, of course, but they represent the same value). if they were two independent variables, it would be $$v(x,t)$$ in which case I expect what you said would actually be a problem.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 464, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T19:38:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsghbfeplcl34z", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T19:38:16Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lsghfyes2mt5ju", "to": "lsghbfeia3g34y", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T19:41:48Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Trig sub question", "created": "2024-02-10T19:38:16Z", "content": "If you have an integral that requires you to use trig sub, specifically the trig identity $$sin^2(x) + cos^2(x) = 1$$, if your integral is of the form $$a^2 - x^2$$, how do you know whether to isolate sine or cosine from the Pythagorean identity? You could end up with $$sin^2(x) = 1 - cos^2(x)$$, as well as $$cos^2(x) = 1 - sin^2(x)$$. I ran into this issue during homework 1, and I'm still unsure. Does it even matter?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 76, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T19:41:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T19:41:48Z", "content": "From the leture notes, the recommended substitution is $$a\\sin\\theta$$. Note that you will also have to subsitute $$dx=a\\cos\\theta d \\theta$$, and so your choice to substitute either $$\\sin\\theta$$ or $$\\cos\\theta$$ will depend on what else is in the integral."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lk8wg65xh3c3qq"], "children": [], "id": "lsghfyekl605jt", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsghbfeia3g34y", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173349355, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 465, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T19:59:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgi2kfvdtt65d", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T19:59:23Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgikoyrhcb4p4", "to": "lsgi2kfmrdv65c", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T20:13:28Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsgi2kfmrdv65c", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-10T20:48:47Z", "cid": "lsgju3s3ygm511", "uid_a": "a_2"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WH2 Question 1 (5)", "created": "2024-02-10T19:59:23Z", "content": "

I'm a little confused on how to evaluate the integration constant because I have 2 different ideas of what the initial condition might be.

1. Can we assume v(0) = vf because of one of the previous parts of the question, which stated the initial speed of the rocket was v(0) = V. However, this was the initial speed as the rocket travelled upwards, so I'm unsure of its validity since we're measuring the rocket's journey downwards now.

2. or should the initial velocity of the rocket's path downwards be assumed to be V(xmax), because at Xmax the velocity is 0, before the rocket begins its descent downwards

Any tips would be much appreciated!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Victoria Sing", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ktd52oyt3un1q5", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 179, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T20:13:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T20:13:28Z", "content": "I was a bit confused about this as well. If I have the wrong idea, someone please correct me, but I'll explain what I did. To re-evaluate the integration constant, we must flip the integral by setting a new initial x-value (hint: you already have this value). Using that, we can re-solve for the integration constant and use that to find the final speed of the rocket. Essentially, you must prove that your assumption for the final speed is correct. "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsgikoyk4v54p3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Personally OP, I have tried using v(xmax)=0 and I get the exact same C constant as I had before. Which ultimately forces you to bring up the fact v(0) = Vf to continue. 

I ultimately ended up using v(0) = vf and do get the same constant as I had before but in terms of Vf instead of Vi. And since that was the case, you can conclude the rest.

Specifically, the function integrating to $$\\ln|x|$$ is $$\\frac{1}{x}$$, but here we have $$\\frac{1}{1-x}$$. If you write $$\\ln|1-x|$$ the derivative is $$\\frac{-1}{1-x}$$, which is not what you had originally, so this cannot be the primitive.", "created": "2024-02-10T23:35:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Youssef Rachad", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["ksaailfs7ix4ne"], "id": "lsgpsqcdyix6mf", "updated": "2024-02-11T04:10:33Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 1, "id": "lsgpabsx5cu3w3", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-10T23:35:41Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgjo7ye7hq161", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173351526, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tutorials", "webwork"], "nr": 467, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T21:18:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgkvy7dwgz3gn", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T21:18:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "data": "lsgzywh8oj836t", "to": "lsgkvy72jcb3gd", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-11T04:20:25Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Reevaluating a constant of integration", "created": "2024-02-10T21:18:13Z", "content": "Hello all,

I have encountered this problem time after time after time and I think we should clarify this: when is it ok to reevaluate a constant of integration if it's just a bunch of constants bunndled together? Is it always ok when we just have constants?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tutorials", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 107, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T04:20:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Justin Fang", "endorser": {"lmebuo1hd0t46v": 1698703109}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm75necjjjm23z", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ksaailfs7ix4ne", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T04:20:25Z", "content": "Good question, we often reuse C as a constant to mean "some constant is needed here" instead of defining $$C_1, C_2, C_3, \dots$$ which can get tedious and doesn't let us see the core idea of the solution. An example you've likely seen many times would go as follows $$\int\frac{\mathrm dy}{y} = \int t\mathrm dt$$ $$\ln(y) = t + C$$ $$y = Ce^t$$ Now I'll write it out in full and you'll see the difference: $$\int\frac{\mathrm dy}{y} = \int t\mathrm dt$$ $$\ln(y) + C_1 = t + C_2$$ let $$C_3 = C_2 - C_1$$ then $$\ln(y) = t + C_3$$ $$y = e^{t+C_3} = e^t\cdot e^{C_3}$$ finally let $$C_4 = e^{C_3}$$ then $$y = C_4e^t$$ The fact that I've defined 4 constants doesn't make my solution any better and it's harder to follow for someone reading through. Hence why we can (1) define a constant of integration for one of integral (2) redefine said constant from an additive one to a scaling one by the laws of exponents and (3) write $$C = C_1\cdot C$$ = $$C = C + C_1$$ to shorten notation. And to your second point - yes, this only works if you have arbitrary constants."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm75necjjjm23z"], "children": [], "id": "lsgzywh25uw36s", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgkvy72jcb3gd", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173352611, "default_anonymity": "no"}

It's written that we used chain rule but i don't understand how we used it here.\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0102", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 81, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T00:57:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lea Akzam", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk2xg3dmq4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T00:57:25Z", "content": "unless otherwise stated, $$y$$ is really a function $$y(t)$$, so when we find the derivative of $$f(y)$$, we are really finding $$f(y(t))$$. writing it like this makes it more obvious that we need to use chain rule.

for your particular question, the function is $$f(y)=5y(1-y)$$. then, after applying chain rule, it's $$f'(y(t))\\times y'(t)$$."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T00:57:14Z", "content": "unless otherwise stated, $$y$$ is really a function $$y(t)$$, so when we find the derivative of $$f(y)$$, we are really finding $$f(y(t))$$. writing it like this makes it more obvious that we need to use chain rule.

for your particular question, the function is $$f(y)=5y(1-y)$$. then, after applying chain rule, this is $$f'(y(t))\\times y'(t)$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk2xg3dmq4"], "children": [], "id": "lsgspmfm9b06qo", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgmum32ct6hn", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173356952, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0103"], "nr": 473, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T22:53:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgoa7ww8kr5yf", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T22:53:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsgp38qn91y52b", "to": "lsgoa7wna2m5ye", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T23:15:51Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsgoa7wna2m5ye", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-10T23:29:33Z", "cid": "lsgpkuuuqof4pe", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "lsgoa7wna2m5ye", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-10T23:43:20Z", "cid": "lsgq2kv2n663na"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsgoa7wna2m5ye", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-10T23:57:41Z", "cid": "lsgql180t2246d", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "to": "lsgoa7wna2m5ye", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-11T00:42:24Z", "cid": "lsgs6j565p14r9"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsgoa7wna2m5ye", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-11T00:56:37Z", "cid": "lsgsot80olq1vt", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A4-1 midpoint rule question", "created": "2024-02-10T22:53:17Z", "content": "

In lecture, we found the equation of the tangent line at the midpoint of a function. However, I don't understand how the x-value used in part c) is $$x-\frac{b}{2}$$, when we previously defined $$x=\frac{b}{2}$$. Why don't we just use $$\frac{b}{2}$$?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 76, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T23:15:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T23:15:51Z", "content": "The equation $$y=f'(b/2)(x-b/2)+f(b/2)$$ is the tangent line to $$(b/2, f(b/2)$$) -- remember that when we want to center a function around a specific x-value ($$x_0$$, for example), we use $$(x-x_0)$$ not $$(x+x_0)$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lk8wg65xh3c3qq"], "children": [], "id": "lsgp38qhhd5529", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Thank you for responding. I understand that Mn uses $$\frac{x-x_{0}}{2}$$ as the specific x-value, but in this case, wouldn't it be $$\frac{b-0}{2}$$, which is just $$\frac{b}{2}$$? If we defined x as equal to $$\frac{b}{2}$$, why are we subtracting $$\frac{b}{2}$$ from x? Wouldn't that result in 0?

With this thought process, the equation I would have written is $$f(x) = f'(\frac{b}{2})(\frac{b}{2}) + f(\frac{b}{2})$$. Why wouldn't this work?

", "created": "2024-02-10T23:29:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The equation you're looking at is for part b) not c); here we specifically want to take the integral of the approximation by a tangent line, nothing to do with $$M_n$$ (that link comes in the next section).", "created": "2024-02-10T23:43:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lk8wg65xh3c3qq"], "id": "lsgq2kv2n663na", "updated": "2024-02-11T00:56:46Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Oops, my bad, I meant part b). What you're saying about the integral makes sense, thank you for clarifying. I'm still a bit unsure why the substituted x-value in part b) (highlighted in red) is $$x-\frac{b}{2}$$, rather than $$\frac{b}{2}$$. Wouldn't the former example simply result in $$f(0)$$? Apologies for the confusion.", "created": "2024-02-10T23:57:41Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsgql180t2246d", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-10T23:57:41Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "it's a simple case of slope intercept form, $$(y-y_0)=m(x-x_0)$$. in this case, the slope is $$m=f'(\frac{b}{2})$$ and the point of interest is $$(x_0, y_0)=(\frac{b}{2}, f(\frac{b}{2}))$$. if you substitute these you'll get the resulting function.", "created": "2024-02-11T00:42:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lk8wg65xh3c3qq"], "id": "lsgs6j565p14r9", "updated": "2024-02-11T00:56:41Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Ohh I see that makes sense, thank you both so much!", "created": "2024-02-11T00:56:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsgsot80olq1vt", "updated": "2024-02-11T00:56:37Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgpkuuuqof4pe", "updated": "2024-02-11T00:56:56Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgoa7wna2m5ye", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173359125, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 475, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T23:42:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgq14yrkna1fy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T23:42:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsgqj3joo9cu", "to": "lsgq14yk4w51fx", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T23:56:11Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsgqjg4j90eu6", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-10T23:56:27Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice question: 2020 Term Test 1", "created": "2024-02-10T23:42:13Z", "content": "How would I approach this question? Instinctually I feel like it converges since 1/root(x) and root(10-x) both converge but how should I show this? Should I take apart the integral and analyze the limits separately? If two of the parts converge and e^(cosx) diverges does the integral it converge?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T23:56:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hannah Schmidt", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukdf56c21pt", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mahreen Naila", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uklh38no2ft", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T23:56:27Z", "content": "First note that $$\\frac{1}{e}\\le e^{\\cos(x)}\\le e$$ since $$-1\\le\\cos(x)\\le 1$$, so we know that $$\\frac{\\sqrt{10-x}}{\\sqrt{x}}e^{\\cos(x)}e\\le \\frac{\\sqrt{10-x}}{\\sqrt{x}}e$$. Also, we know that the maximum value of $$\\sqrt{10-x}$$ on $$[0,10]$$ equals $$\\sqrt{10}$$, so $$\\frac{\\sqrt{10-x}}{\\sqrt{x}}e\\le\\frac{e\\sqrt{10}}{\\sqrt{x}}$$."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T23:56:11Z", "content": "First note that $$\\frac{1}{e}\\le e^{\\cos(x)}\\le e$$ since $$-1\\le\\cos(x)\\le 1$$, so we know that $$\\frac{\\sqrt{10-x}}{\\sqrt{x}}e^{\\cos(x)}e\\le \\frac{\\sqrt{10-x}}{\\sqrt{x}}e$$. Also, we know that the maximum value of $$\\sqrt{10-x}$$ on $$[0,10]$$ equals $$\\sqrt{10}$$, so $$\\frac{\\sqrt{10-x}}{\\sqrt{x}}e\\le\\frac{e\\sqrt{10}}{\\sqrt{x}}$$. In the formula sheet the error bound for a right hand riemann sum is (b-a)^2/2n * the maximum value of the derivative. I know the derivative of the function is 2xcos(x^2) but how do I find the maximum value of that function over the interval (0,sqrt(pi/2))? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hayden Wonnacott", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk8faaan1b5", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 113, "children": [{"history_size": 7, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T05:27:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Thariq Pasha", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llgvmh92g6u612", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Hayden Wonnacott", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk8faaan1b5", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T06:02:00Z", "content": "

with hint 1, you'll need to recognize that the function they gave you shares the same zeroes as $$y''$$, like so:
$$\left(2x\cos\left(x^{2}\right)\right)'=0$$
$$2\cos\left(x^{2}\right)-4x^{2}\sin\left(x^{2}\right)=0$$
$$1-2x^{2}\tan\left(x^{2}\right)=0$$
$$2x^{2}\tan\left(x^{2}\right)-1=0$$ (note that we multiplied by $$-1$$ here)


so, it's clear that $$z_1$$ is a critical point for the derivative. additionally, we know that $$\tan{x}$$ is a strictly increasing function over $$(0, \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}})$$. usually if the function crossed from negative to positive, it's a local minimum, but since we multiplied by $$-1$$, we know it's a local maximum. with that out of the way, you can reasonably say that $$\cos{(x^2)}\le\cos{(z_1^2)}=0.8$$ and correspondingly $$x=z_1=0.8$$ on that interval. putting that together, the upper bound is $$2\times0.8\times0.8$$.

in my opinion hint 2 is way easier, but also less accurate. it shows that the upper bound for $$x$$ is just $$\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}\le1.3$$. you can then also use the fact that $$\cos(x)\le1$$. putting that together, the upper bound is $$2\times1.3\times1$$

Do we need the concavity or is it sufficient enough to base our answer off increasing/decreasing? ", "created": "2024-02-12T21:41:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7uk1byd3xly", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

it's intentionally made difficult to find the zeroes in this problem, which is why it's actually given to you (albeit in a different equation). unless by second derivative you meant third derivative... trippy... in which case...

it doesn't really matter how you prove local max as long as you prove it. personally finding the third derivative is a bit overkill especially if, as you said, it's difficult to find the zeroes. both work, but in this context increasing/decreasing is much easier.

"created": "2024-02-11T03:54:22Z", "content": "

It's hard to give advice that works in general, but here are a few useful facts.

Inequalities (assuming $$a,b\in\mathbb{R}$$ and that $$a,b > 0$$)

  • $$a
  • $$a < ab$$
  • $$a > a-b$$
  • $$a < \frac{a}{b}$$
  • $$ a > a^b$$ when $$a < 1$$ and $$a < a^b$$ when $$a>1$$.

More useful, suppose we have a function $$f$$ which we know has an upper bound, call it $$M$$. Then

  • $$a+f(x)\le a+M$$
  • $$af(x)\le aM$$

If we instead have that the lower bound of the function is $$L$$, then

  • $$a+L\le a+f(x)$$
  • $$aL \le af(x)$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T03:50:52Z", "content": "

  • $$a

  • $$a > a-b$$

More useful, suppose we have a function $$f$$ which we know has an upper bound, call it $$M$$. Then

When you substitute x = 4tan(theta) I believe your dx is incorrect. It should be 4sec^2(theta). 

As for trig sub I think you would have to know the derivative of arctan to solve this question quickly.

Generally for trig I look for opportunities to substitute either tan, sec, or cos depending on the +/- and constant. I think there is a general rule on the trig sub slides you can follow.

I remember in lecture section 0103 where Professor Mandelis and Karmianpour said that we can't treat infinities as "numbers". They said that if anything evaluates to "infinity" in an expression then it's automatically divergent at least in the scope of our course. When I was doing this question then, I had the expression (lim t --> + inf) ln(x^2 + 1) (Evaluated from -t and t). Do I automatically state that it's divergent then, even though algebraically the ln terms can be "subtracted" out to 0?
