I believe it should say $$e^x + x^2\ge e^x+1$$ in the 2nd line of the solution.

They skipped a step between the 2nd and 3rd line: $$e^x+x^2\ge e^x+1 \implies \frac{1}{e^x+x^2}\le \frac{1}{e^x+1}$$, where taking the inverse is justified because $$e^x+1$$ and $$e^x+x^2$$ are greater than $$0$$ and the inverse function is decreasing on $$(0,\infty)$$. Moreover, we know that $$e^x>0$$ for all $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$ so we can multiply both sides of the inequality by $$e^x$$ to get to the 3rd line.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T07:18:19Z", "content": "

I believe it should say $$e^x + x^2\ge e^x+1$$ in the 2nd line of the solution.

Ils ont sauté un étape entre le 2e et 3e ligne : $$e^x+x^2\ge e^x+1 \implies \frac{1}{e^x+x^2}\le \frac{1}{e^x+1}$$, où prenant l'inverse est justifié parce que $$e^x+1$$ et $$e^x+x^2$$ sont plus grand que $$0$$ et la fonction inverse est décroissante sur $$]0,\infty[$$. De plus on sait que $$e^x>0$$ pour tout $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$ donc on peut multiplier les deux côtés d'inégalité pour arriver à la 3e ligne.

i often have trouble visualizing composite functions/product of functions without the use of desmos: does anyone have any advice on how to do this?

for example: sin(x^2), or (x^2)cosx, or (e^x)sinx

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "visualizing functions", "created": "2024-02-11T19:05:52Z", "content": "

i often have trouble visualizing composite functions/product of functions without the use of desmos: does anyone have any advice on how to do this?

for example: sin(x^2), or (e^x)sinx

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brian Tobing", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk5qionkxj", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Inara Ezers", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm40xv1qonh3xt", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 53, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T21:10:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T21:16:19Z", "content": "

for a lot of functions (and specifically the ones you've listed), you can use the ideas of "horizontal stretch and compression" that you learned in high school.

for example, in $$\sin{(x^2)}$$, you can remodel this as $$\sin{(ax)}$$ with some $$a$$ for which $$x^2=ax$$, meaning it's always growing. so you can consider this a "horizontal compression" of the function that continues to grow larger, and of course, that's what it looks like (also note that there's a reflection in the y-axis when $$x$$ changes sign).

the same thing applies for vertical compression. for $$x^2\cos{(x)}$$ you have a scaling factor of $$a$$ on $$ax\cos{(x)}$$ that continuously grows. so you can expect a vertical stretch which also grows (again, there's a reflection in the x-axis when $$x$$ changes sign). the same applies to $$e^x\sin{(x)}$$, although the function obviously looks much different than $$x^2$$, so I'll leave that up to you to consider.

when it comes to addition of functions it gets more complicated. in these cases you probably want to find the critical points, intercepts etc.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T21:13:40Z", "content": "

the same thing applies for vertical compression. for $$x^2\cos{(x)}$$ you have a scaling factor of $$a$$ on $$ax\cos{(x)}$$ that continuously grows. so you can expect a vertical stretch which also grows (again, there's a reflection in the x-axis when $$x$$ changes sign). the same applies to $$e^x\sin{(x)}$$ (this does not reflect!)

when it comes to addition of functions it gets more complicated. in these cases you probably want to find the critical points, intercepts etc.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T21:12:38Z", "content": "

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 99, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T19:19:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angelina Zhu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgfqdy6208", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_2", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T19:22:56Z", "content": "The function is not actually concave up throughout the entirety of that interval. expand it, and there is a pattern.

after this, you can treat the approximation for $$T_2$$ as an upper bound, $$T_4$$ as a lower bound, and draw pretty much whaterver you want, as long as your function is in between and intersects all the necessary points. in the below picture, $$T_2$$ is red, $$T_4$$ is blue, $$f(x)$$ is green.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T22:43:10Z", "content": "the approximations are only evaluated at specific points. before drawing the graph, you can draw out the key points that will be used in the calculation of each approximation. of course, you want $$T_2>T_4$$, so make sure the y-coordinates of the points for $$T_4\\le T_2$$. also connect them with a line to visualize the approximations.

after this, you can treat the approximation for $$T_2$$ as an upper bound, $$T_4$$ as a lower bound, and draw pretty much whaterver you want, as long as your functions intersects all the necessary points. in the below picture, $$T_2$$ is red, $$T_4$$ is blue, $$f(x)$$ is green.

When it looks like there's only one function and we have to use integration by parts, we can think of the integrand as $$1\cdot f(x)$$, and we integrate $$1$$ because it's easier. In this question :

$$\displaystyle \int\sqrt{1-x^2}\,dx=\int 1\cdot\sqrt{1-x^2}=x\sqrt{1-x^2}-\int x\left(\sqrt{1-x^2}\right)'\,dx$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T07:12:00Z", "content": "

Quand il semble qu'il y a seulement une fonction est on doit utiliser l'intégration par parties, on peut penser de l'intégrande comme $$1\cdot f(x)$$ est intégrer $$1$$ parce que c'est plus facile. Dans cette question :

$$\displaystyle \int\sqrt{1-x^2}\,dx=\int 1\cdot\sqrt{1-x^2}=x\sqrt{1-x^2}-\int x\left(\sqrt{1-x^2}\right)'\,dx$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["k07ghb5kyi669r"], "children": [], "id": "lsiljfexhdy43r", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7uk89v8yl1an", "lm7uksa5i342zo", "lm7uk8uze41ca"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsi16z66noh4sa", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173396019, "default_anonymity": "no"}

for a), i said it's false because the bottom only converges for s>1, not s>0. but I don't know if you can just split an integral like that and say that if one part of the function diverges, then an integral containing the product of that function and another function diverges.

The value that 4(a) is asking for is called the _Cauchy Principal Value_, and is related to but **not the same** as the improper integral from $$-\infty$$ to $$\infty$$. A useful explanation of why this is the case can be found on this Math Stack Exchange post: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/637516/why-int-infty-infty-x-dx-neq-0 For 4(a), evaluating the indefinite integral $$\int\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx$$ gives $$\frac{1}{2}\ln(x^2+1)+\arctan x + C$$. Then, if you plug in the bounds and evaluate from $$-t$$ to $$t$$, you will get $$2\arctan t$$. Taking the limit as $$t\to\infty$$, you will get the answer of $$\pi$$. This value is called the _Cauchy Principle Value (PV)_. **However**, for the second integral in 4(b) **which is not the same as 4(a)**, you **cannot** use the same method as you did in part (a). This integral diverges and the easiest way to show this is to see that $$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx=\int_{-\infty}^{0}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx+\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{1+x}{1+x^2}dx$$ and seeing that both terms diverge when evaluated using the antiderivative. Tl;dr: $$\lim\limits_{t\to\infty}\int_{-t}^{t}f(x)\ dx \neq \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f(x)\ dx \equiv \lim\limits_{a\to-\infty}\lim\limits_{b\to\infty}\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\ dx$$."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T03:47:43Z", "content": "You need to understand that the answer in 4(a) and (b) are not the same. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tutorials"], "nr": 514, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T00:27:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsi73h11ux253t", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-12T00:27:41Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lsiamgcqopsub", "to": "lsi73h0ur5i53r", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-12T02:06:26Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "lsian1vimj11zv", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-12T02:06:54Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "TUT3 Q3", "created": "2024-02-12T00:27:41Z", "content": "Hey everyone, just curious if doing a limit comparison to 2/sqrt(x) is also sufficient here. The solution decides to use a lower bound (cos(1)/sqrt(x)) instead of the upper bound which I am suggesting. I feel that the upper bound is more useful as it can prove convergence as well. Let me know if that makes sense...
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tutorials"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 94, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T02:06:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T02:06:54Z", "content": "there is nothing that proves convergence "as well." if an upper bound is divergent, then the behavior of functions beneath it is indeterminate. likewise, if a lower bound is convergent, the behavior for functions above it is indeterminate. you can only draw conclusions from the other 2/4 cases."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T02:06:26Z", "content": "there is nothing that proves convergence "as well." if an upper bound is divergent, then the behavior of the function beneath it is indeterminate. likewise, if a lower bound is convergent, the behavior for functions above is is indeterminate. you can only draw conclusions from the other 2/4 cases."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsiamgcknjuua", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsi73h0ur5i53r", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173403627, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hi, I just wanted to compare some answers for the 2021 Midterm 1 and 2 with what others got since we don't have a key. Feel free to point out any mistakes I have.

I also had 3 questions that I was kind of stuck on and wanted to ask about;

Test 1 Q5, in my work I initially changed the bounds from x=-1 and x=-1/rt2 to theta=2pi/3 and theta=3pi/4 respectively, but my answer kept coming out to be the negative of the answer, but then I changed the bounds to the negatives of these and it works out fine. I chose the positives first cuz the integral is taking the values from quadrant 2, and so that means I should be using angles in the same quadrant, but it wouldn't work, so then I used the angles of the other quadrant where cos is negative and it worked. Could I get some clarification on how to work around that because I am kind of confused.

Test 2 Q1, I don't know how to start it entirely

Test 2 Q5, I am not sure what function to compare to? I initially compared it to 1/rtx^9, since it is always greater in the interval, but it only proved that 1/x^9/2 function diverges but not the question, and I can't seem to find something else to compare it to to ensure it either converges or diverges.

mat187-2021-test1.pdf

mat187-2021-test2.pdf

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 105, "children": [{"history_size": 8, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T04:48:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T05:20:21Z", "content": "For Test 2 Q1, notice that the series looks like a Riemann sum. Try to convert it into a definite integral. **SPOILERS AHEAD** ... Note that the sum can be written as $$\lim\limits_{n \to \infty}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\sqrt{1-(\frac{i}{n})^2}\ \frac{1}{n}$$. The $$\frac{i}{n}$$ term looks a lot like our $$x_i$$'s and the $$\frac{1}{n}=Δx$$ term tells us that the length of the interval is 1. Using the fact that $$x_i=a+iΔx$$ for a right-endpoint Riemann sum it is not hard to see that our bounds of integration is from 0 to 1. Thus, our definite integral is $$\int_0^1 \sqrt{1-x^2}\ dx$$, which is the area of the quarter circle of radius one centered at the origin. Thus, the value we are looking for is $$\frac{\pi}{4}$$.
Alternatively, you could use trig sub to compute this integral but since this question is literally only worth 2 marks, I wouldn't waste time doing that."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T05:19:57Z", "content": "For Test 2 Q1, notice that the series looks like a Riemann sum. Question Nº2 is about approximation errors of an integral; you have to use the rules you learned in class (let $$I$$ be the true value of $$\int f(x)\,dx$$):

  • $$L_n\le I\le R_n$$ if $$f$$ is increasing on the integration interval (the reverse if $$f$$ is decreasing)
  • $$M_n\le I\le T_n$$ if $$f$$ is convex on the integration interval (the reverse if $$f$$ is concave).

We also have error bounds, which you can find in the A4 slideshow (on Quercus).

Question Nº3 is also about approximation errors, so use the $$R_n$$ error bound and solve for $$n$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T06:16:34Z", "content": "

Question Nº2 is about approximation errors of an integral; you have to use the rules you learned in class (soit $$I$$ le vrai valeur de $$\int f(x)\,dx$$):

  • $$L_n\le I\le R_n$$ si $$f$$ est croissante sur l'intervalle d'intégration (le revers si $$f$$ est décroissante)
  • $$M_n\le I\le T_n$$ si $$f$$ est convexe sur l'intervalle d'intégration (le revers si $$f$$ est concave

On a aussi des bornes d'erreur que vous pouvez trouver dans le slideshow A4 (sur Quercus).

Question Nº3 s'agit aussi d'erreurs d'approximation, il faut utiliser le borne d'erreur de $$R_n$$ et résoudre pour $$n$$.

You can't have discontinuities in the integration interval, so you have to separate the integral where they are. We can deduce that $$\frac{1}{\sin(x)}$$ is discontinuous when $$x\in\left\{t\in\mathbb{Z} : \pi|n\right\}$$. In the interval $$[-2,5]$$ there are two values where the function is discontinuous -- $$x=0$$ and $$x=\pi$$ -- so the integral must be separated there.

Furthermore, you may have at most one discontinuous bound in an integral.

How would I approach this question?

Given the initial values, Y' =0, but how do I determine if it's a max or min?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 100, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T06:37:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David Basil", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T06:37:03Z", "content": "

Question 3 is about the length of an arc, not the area under a curve, so we can eliminate option A because it doesn't become more precise when we leave $$n\to\infty$$ (it remains constant, but the length of each arc is different). Also, we want a simple shape, so we don't use C or D. The only option left is B.

In question 5, the last three options are linked to the second derivative. Option E is obvious (inflection point), and for options C and D we can determine whether a critical point is a maximum or minimum by finding the convexity there (if convex it's a minimum and if concave it's a maximum).

In the second HW2 question, we were given two differential equations:

(1) $$T'(t)=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)$$

(2) $$T'(t)=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)+H(t)$$.

The first is Newton's cooling law, which describes only the cooling rate. If there are no other sources of heat or cooling it equals the net change, but in the question we have an external source: the radiator $$H(t)$$. Because of this, I assumed we had to ignore the first equation and used only the second.

I assumed the question asked us to find $$H(t)$$ where $$\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)+H(t)$$ would have equilibrium when $$T=20$$, so I wrote the equation $$0=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-20\right)+H(t)$$ and then arrived at $$H(t)=\frac{40}{3}-\frac{8}{9}t$$ (since $$A(t)=\frac{4}{3}$$).

So, was the first equation useless?

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "Est-ce qu'on a dû utiliser le loi de refroidissement dans question 2, HW2?", "created": "2024-02-12T14:55:41Z", "content": "

In the second HW2 question, we were given two differential equations:

(1) $$T'(t)=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)$$

(2) $$T'(t)=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)+H(t)$$.

The first is Newton's cooling law, which describes only the cooling rate. If there are no other sources of heat or cooling it equals the net change, but in the question we have an external source: the radiator $$H(t)$$. Because of this, I assumed we had to ignore the first equation and used only the second.

I assumed the question asked us to find $$H(t)$$ where $$\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-T(t)\right)+H(t)$$ would have equilibrium when $$T=20$$, so I wrote the equation $$0=\frac{2}{3}\left(A(t)-20\right)+H(t)$$ and then arrived at $$H(t)=\frac{40}{3}-\frac{8}{9}t$$ (since $$A(t)=\frac{4}{3}$$).

So, was the first equation useless?

After we do this substitution, we can use the $$1- \sin^2 = \cos^2$$ rule and integrate $$\cos^2$$ by parts if we treat it as just $$\cos$$ times $$\cos$$. (Though, if you know all your double angle identities, this isn't the only way to do it)"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["llgvml3fbza6rd"], "children": [], "id": "lsj410nsl1a4bt", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-13T02:22:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-13T02:22:16Z", "content": "

$$\sqrt{1-f^2(t)}f'(t)$$

$$\sqrt{g^2(t)}f'(t)$$

$$g(t)*f'(t)$$

$$f'(t)=g(t)$$

$$g^2(t) = RHS$$

Two monkeys are placed on an island. After 5 years there are 8 monkeys and the capacity of the island is 25. When does the population of monkeys reach 16 monkeys?

How do I approach this question? I know y(0)=2 and y(5)=8 and the lim(y) as t--> infinity is 25. Not sure what to do with this information tho

Looking online I see a "logistic growth equation", am I meant to just memorize that or is there a more intuitive way to do it

(the growth equation as given by the textbook)

There's not really a more intuitive way than this. The textbook attempts to describe the intuition behind the equation in the next paragraph, though.

Hi, 

This may not be the exact answer you want, but the logistic equation you aim to memorize can be derived from looking at birth rates (B) and death rates (D) for a given population (P), in addition to some constant of proportionality k over time T

In general, the population dP = k (B*P*dT - D*P*dT).  --> dP/dT = kP(B-D). The logistic equation is derived by grouping some constants together and giving these groupings meanings based on their physical meanings. I guess in this case you would need to memorize the logistic equation given that the question uses terms like 'capacity' which I think is code for M in the logistic equation dP/dT= kP (M-P). In other cases when given birth and death rates, it may serve to start from scratch (without the logistic equation)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 117, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "The wording of the question is a little odd but from what I understand, this is the scenario. You are right in saying that we cannot find a solution where y = 0 using the separable method. Therefore, I think the separable method will always find a solution but not all the solutions, so I believe it is C", "created": "2024-02-12T17:53:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsj8gwgdog052b", "updated": "2024-02-12T23:25:18Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T18:08:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T18:08:50Z", "content": "

You're right that y cannot be zero, and that is the solution that we find by using the separable method. So, this is a case where the method does not find a solution. But of course, we've seen cases in class where it does. Thus, we say B, sometimes finds a solution.

\n

Also, a good way to show that we don't find a solution is, after we separate and integrate, we have $$y = \\frac{-1}{x + c}$$ which means $$0 = \\frac{-1}{0 + c}$$ which is of course impossible, so no c exists, so no solution exists\u00a0

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsj903sjje02i4", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsj7pgyyvcsyu", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173427492, "default_anonymity": "no"}

you need to evaluate it without splitting the integral. when the integrated terms are within the same limit, you are able to cancel them out before taking the limit, which removes the problematic terms.

when doing the second part, you need to divide it into two added limits and evaluate them before performing arithmetic with the terms. of course, this results in arithmetic with infinity which is the issue you are facing in part 1.

For the after-class practice, can someone show how separation of variables yield the same result? When I do separation of variables, I get something different. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T20:36:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T20:37:16Z", "content": "

Without your work I can't tell you where you went wrong, but I present my solution:

$$\displaystyle y'=-e^ty \Rightarrow \frac{y'}{y}=e^t \Rightarrow \int\frac{1}{y}\,dy=-\int e^t\,dt \Rightarrow \ln|y|=-e^t+C_0$$

$$\displaystyle\Rightarrow |y|=e^{-e^t+C_0}$$, soit $$C_1=e^{C_0}$$

$$\displaystyle\Rightarrow y=C_1e^{-e^t}$$, en combinant la signe de valeur absolu avec $$C_1$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T20:36:54Z", "content": "

Sans votre travail je ne peux pas vous dire où vous vous êtes trompés, mais je vous présente ma solution :

$$\displaystyle y'=-e^ty \Rightarrow \frac{y'}{y}=e^t \Rightarrow \int\frac{1}{y}\,dy=-\int e^t\,dt \Rightarrow \ln|y|=-e^t+C_0$$

$$\displaystyle\Rightarrow |y|=e^{-e^t+C_0}$$, soit $$C_1=e^{C_0}$$

$$\displaystyle\Rightarrow y=C_1e^{-e^t}$$, en combinant la signe de valeur absolu avec $$C_1$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsjeaixfvuh699", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsjd8176e8b6vv", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173436172, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Not really sure if my answers are right\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nigel Fang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk9rwnwe1fn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T20:59:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ryu Lee", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uka7j2511gs", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T20:59:26Z", "content": "For Q3a, each day the number of supporters increases by 3 percent of the voter population (0.03 * [number of voters]), and decreases by 5 percent of its current value (0.05 * M). The net change is therefore the sum of these two values. But M is the percentage of the population supporting Magenta, so we have to divide by a constant to calculate it. To integrate it, notice that it is a linear differential equation. For part b, use the initial condition $$M(20)=0.5$$ (in 20 days, you need to have at least 50 percent to win)."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uka7j2511gs"], "children": [], "id": "lsjf3igsfl22cj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 546, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T21:04:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 1, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsjf9vzusrb5yy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-12T21:04:24Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "lsjgj6zcosx75i", "to": "lsjf9vzkxy95yw", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-12T21:39:38Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsjf9vzkxy95yw", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-12T21:43:04Z", "cid": "lsjgnm62r837go", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "to": "lsjf9vzkxy95yw", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-12T21:49:09Z", "cid": "lsjgvg4r8133ef"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2017 Term Test 1 Q11", "created": "2024-02-12T21:04:24Z", "content": "For Q11 part b from 2017 term test 1 I got the function 1/x sqrt(1-1/x^2). How do I prove this function diverges from 1 to infinity?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-12T21:39:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-12T21:39:38Z", "content": "Notice that the integral from 1 to infinity is the same as the integral from 1 to 2 and 2 to infinity

Note that from 2 to infinity, the square root thing is between 1 and root of a half, so that's a constant you can take out. Then 1/x diverges."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsjgj6z58kr75h", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "But aren’t we evaluating the integral? How can I just take the square root thing out as a constant?
 
", "created": "2024-02-12T21:43:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

So, what we see is that 

$$\int \frac{1}{x \sqrt{1}} \leq \int f(x) \leq \int \frac{1}{x \sqrt{0.75}}$$

$$\int \frac{1}{x} \leq \int f(x) \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{0.75}} \int \frac{1}{x }$$

And both of those diverge.

How did you try to find the maximum of it. If you look at the first derivative and it isn't clear what the maximum is, there are a couple things you can do. For one, you can find the second derivative, because the max of the first derivative will happen when the second derivative is zero.

or, in this case, since the first derivative is (tell me if you got something else because I might be wrong) $$\u22122e^{\u2212sin^2(x)}cos(x)sin(x)$$ We can find the upper bound of the magnitude of each of these parts separately. So, $$|-2| \\leq 2$$ and $$e^{-\\sin^2(x)} \\leq e$$ and $$|\\sin(x)| \\leq 1$$ and $$|\\cos(x)| \\leq 1$$, and we can take that together, though this will be a slightly less accurate bound"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lmrrcro0rhmpp"], "children": [], "id": "lsjhfzhk44m7pc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "wouldn't the upper bound of e^-sin^2(x) be 1? cause the square of sin cannot be negative so -sin^2(x) max value will be 0 so e^0 will be 0? On the other hand, starting at 0.2, we know we're also going to go to 1, which means increasing. But, the derivative, when y = 0.2 will be 5(0.2)(0.8) whereas at y=0.5 it'll be faster at 5(0.5)(0.5). $$\int f'(x)(2x + 2) = \int 2x f'(x) + 2 \int f'(x)$$ 

Then, we can integrate by parts $$\int 2x f'(x)$$

We won't be taking the integral of $$f(x)$$ in the end, I think you'll find, just of $$f'(x)$$

And note the function is odd! 

Does that clear it up?

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-13T00:32:55Z", "content": "

$$\int f'(x)(2x + 2) = \int 2x f'(x) + 2 \int f'(x)$$ 

Then, we can integrate by parts $$\int 2x f'(x)$$

We won't be taking the integral of $$f(x)$$ in the end, I think you'll find, just of $$f'(x)$$

And note the function is odd!

the average is the sum of $$n$$ y-values over $$n$$. to get all values linear interpolated between $$a$$ and $$b$$, you can do $$\sum_{i=1}^{n}f((b-a)\frac{i}{n}+a)$$. this is because $$\frac{i}{n}$$ is the "percentage" of the distance you've crossed, $$b-a$$ is the "distance" and $$a$$ is the "starting point." so you'll need to pick one that fits this form, which leaves two choices.

finally, we need to average all the values by dividing by $$n$$. $$\frac{i}{n}$$ doesn't make sense unless it was a riemann sum, so we need $$\frac{1}{n}$$.

Alternatively, if you prefer to start with the integral and then find the Riemann sum:

$$\displaystyle\int_1^{10}\frac{(x+1)^2}{9}\,dx = \lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{\left(\frac{9i}{n}+1+1\right)^2}{9}\cdot\frac{9}{n} = \lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{9i}{n}+2\right)^2\cdot\frac{1}{n}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-13T01:40:15Z", "content": "

Instead of stucking to h(1/x), what if we integrate h(x) from 1/inf to 1/1? when we sub in 1/inf and 1/1 into h(x) its essentially still h(1/x) from inf to 1. ", "created": "2024-02-13T00:56:44Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsjnkohtsj27ch", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-13T00:56:44Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsjn35bwou7lk", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-13T00:56:44Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-13T00:53:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David Basil", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-13T01:00:16Z", "content": "

q1 is indeterminate (explained below).

for q2, the square of the upper bound $$\frac{1}{x^2}$$ converges, so $$h(x)$$ converges since it's beneath a convergent function.

for q3, notice that $$\displaystyle\lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{1}{x}=0$$. $$e^0=1$$ which is a lower bound of the function, so the limit to infinity is at least $$1$$, which is greater than the constant function $$y=1$$, a divergent function.

Since $$x\mapsto x^2$$ is increasing on $$[1,\infty)$$ we know that it preserves inequalities, so $$e^{-2x}\le\left(h(x)\right)^2\le \frac{1}{x^2}$$.

Also, since $$\frac{1}{x}\in(0,1]$$ for all $$x\in[1,\infty)$$ the inequality is still valid so we can substitute $$\frac{1}{x}$$ into the expression.

Well your logic about it being none of the above never being an answer doesn't really hold value lol. Even if you got 90, that isn't listed, and you overshot it too. The selection seems to be quite precise, but the phrasing is weird. 

They say "which of the following" which might just mean to pick the least of the given options, but they also say "smallest number of intervals" if you picked 101 that would not be the smallest number of intervals. 

The safest answer is probably none of the other options.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tutorials"], "nr": 575, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-13T04:50:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsjvwnxjxa6xq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-13T04:50:00Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "lskggk2mhfa2hx", "to": "lsjvwnx9m6g6xo", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-13T14:25:21Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Danger of division by 0", "created": "2024-02-13T04:50:00Z", "content": "

\n

But sometime, when we manipulate our ODE into standard form, we also create a scenario where the division of 0 may occur, and the found solution will be invalid at a point. How should we deal with this in the mid-term? Specifically what would be the approach if we have an invalid point of our solution?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tutorials"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 118, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-13T14:25:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-13T14:25:21Z", "content": "If you find a scenario where division by zero occurs from putting your equation into standard form, the division by zero wouldn't be dependent on y (because of the layout of standard form). So, this would mean there are some values of t where the ODE is invalid.\u00a0

So, in that case, if they ask when the ODE isn't valid, you talk about that. They probably won't give you an ODE and ask you to solve it as a trick question, though"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lskggk2gpcd2hw", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsjvwnx9m6g6xo", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173469814, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I can't find them on Quercus.", "created": "2024-02-18T03:20:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsqxwiisfjt1xf", "updated": "2024-02-18T03:20:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lskm90pfgue29z", "updated": "2024-02-18T03:20:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-18T03:20:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-18T03:20:20Z", "content": "

For level three, a piecewise function must be used because the rate of fluid loss is not constant. Specifically, during the first 100 minutes the expression for fluid volume is $$V(t)=50+t$$, but after 100 minutes it is $$V(t)=150$$ because that is the reservoir capacity (it cannot be exceeded). Moreover, after 100 minutes, the amount of fluid leaving the reservoir equals 3 L/min, not 2 L/min. So the initial value problem is

$$\displaystyle y'(t)=\begin{cases}30-\frac{2y(t)}{50+t} &t< 100\\ 30-\frac{3y(t)}{150} &t\ge 100\end{cases}$$

$$y(0)=100.$$

For part (b), just take the second branch. For part (c), note that the behavior of the first branch does not affect the behavior of the limit when $$t\to\infty$$, so only the second branch should be considered.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsqxwldt3x522h", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsjzufxd66f6l0", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173472267, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 64, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-15T14:29:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hayoung Roh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f17l9xmw1oh", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-15T14:29:39Z", "content": "

Using Euler's formula with $$e^{(2-3i)t}$$, we calculate $$e^{2t}\\cdot e^{-i(3t)}=e^{2t}\\left(\\cos(-3t)+i\\sin(3t)\\right)=e^{2t}\\cos(3t)-ie^{2t}\\sin(3t)$$. With the definitions of $$y_1(t)$$ and $$y_2(t)$$, we can write $$e^{(2-3i)t}=y_1(t)-iy_2(t)$$. Since $$e^{(2-3i)}t$$ is a linear combination of $$y_1(t)$$ and $$y_2(t)$$, it can be included in the general solution.

\n

\n

Regarding your second question, we know that both terms are equal to zero because we already know that $$z(t)$$ is a solution to the differential equation, so we have $$z''(t)-4z'(t)+13z(t)=0+0i$$. Using the method of equating coefficients, we deduce that both terms must be equal to zero.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l79f17l9xmw1oh"], "children": [], "id": "lsnbhsnzsr6x9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsmxyatq1wa4m4", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173485275, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0102"], "nr": 594, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-16T15:48:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsotqtc1dm61a7", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-16T15:48:19Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "l5lpb0fj1l4165", "data": "lsous3ha7zs1um", "to": "lsotqtbtm2r1a6", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-16T16:17:19Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Module B1 question", "created": "2024-02-16T15:48:19Z", "content": "In the lecture given for module B1, it\u2019s stated that when we find a solution to a first-order differential equation there is practically always a constant C in the solution.\u00a0

I\u2019m unsure as to why this is the case.\u00a0
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0102", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-16T16:17:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Matthew Desmarais", "endorser": {"k3t0tl7krg32to": 1579115969, "k52y9qu3rg41mr": 1584116403, "global": 1587066490, "k38wsyi5wxb1hz": 1587254389, "ktdwmksib25673": 1634571238, "kt03zgk52gf2vz": 1634684358}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l5lpb0fj1l4165", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-16T16:17:19Z", "content": "If you take the derivative of a function with a constant term, that goes away. If you have to integrate that derivative, you don\u2019t know what that constant is anymore. When you solve ODEs and have to integrate, you don\u2019t know if the integral has a constant at the end or not, so you put C as a placeholder for some unknown constant.\n\n$$\\begin{gathered}\\frac{d}{dx} x^{2}+1=2x\\\\ \\int 2x\\ dx=x^{2}+C\\end{gathered}$$"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["k07ghb5kyi669r"], "children": [], "id": "lsous3h161j1ul", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsotqtbtm2r1a6", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173490699, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 3, "folders": ["other", "webwork"], "nr": 595, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-16T19:32:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsp1qkx3l0x1um", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-16T19:32:05Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsp1u1dpb4i2sd", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-16T19:34:46Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsp1qkwtc7d1ul", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-16T19:34:50Z", "cid": "lsp1u4ed8zb2fn", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "lsp1qkwtc7d1ul", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-16T19:35:58Z", "cid": "lsp1vkxlm2g6f0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsp21sa7lwg4aq", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-16T19:40:48Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "A method for finding the particular solution of a non-homogeneous ODE", "created": "2024-02-16T19:40:48Z", "content": "

Sometimes we get non-homogeneous differential equations where it's not obvious how to find the particular solution $$y_p$$ -- take for example the equation $$y''+2y'-15y=e^{3x}$$. If we try $$y_p=ke^{3x}$$ ($$k$$ constant), we'd calculate $$(ke^{3x})''+2(ke^{3x})'-15ke^{3x}=e^{3x} \implies 9k+6k-15k=1 \implies 0=1$$, a contradiction.

Here, the error occurs because the coefficients of the $$e^{3x}$$ term are equal, so we need to find a function with several terms. The product rule will help us with this task -- let $$f,g:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ be differentiable at least twice, thus

  1. $$(fg)'=f'g+fg'$$
  2. $$(fg)''=(f'g+fg')'=f''g+f'g'+f'g'+fg''=f''g+2f'g'+fg''.$$

Substituting it into the differential equation, we have

$$f''g+2f'g'+fg''+2f'g+2fg'-15fg=e^{3x}$$. We know that either $$f(x)=ke^{3x}$$ or $$g(x)=ke^{3x}$$, but we assume that $$f(x)=ke^{3x}$$ (we can change the names if necessary). Thus:

$$9ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)+6ke^{3x}\cdot g'(x)+ke^{3x}\cdot g''(x)+6ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)+2ke^{3x}\cdot g'(x)-15ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)=e^{3x}$$

$$\implies 9kg(x)+6kg'(x)+kg''(x)+6kg(x)+2kg'(x)-15kg(x)=1$$

$$\implies g(x)\left[9k+6k-15k\right]+g'(x)\left[6k+2k\right]+kg''(x)=1$$

$$\implies 8kg'(x)+kg''(x)=1$$.

If we choose $$g$$ where $$g''(x)=0$$ and $$g'(x)=1$$ is constant, we arrive at $$8k=1 \implies k=\frac{1}{8}$$. The function that satisfies this condition is $$g(x)=x$$, so we deduce that $$y_p(x)=\frac{1}{8}xe^{3x}$$. Thus, we find that the family of functions is in fact $$Axe^{3x}$$, not $$Ae^{3x}$$.

(I can add more details if asked in the comments)

(Update n.1: Translated the document to English

Update n.2: Fixed LaTeX error)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "A method for finding the particular solution of a non-homogeneous ODE", "created": "2024-02-16T19:34:46Z", "content": "

Sometimes we get non-homogeneous differential equations where it's not obvious how to find the particular solution $$y_p$$ -- take for example the equation $$y''+2y'-15y=e^{3x}$$. If we try $$y_p=ke^{3x}$$ ($$k$$ constant), we'd calculate $$(ke^{3x})''+2(ke^{3x})'-15ke^{3x}=e^{3x} \implies 9k+6k-15k=1 \implies 0=1$$, a contradiction.

Here, the error occurs because the coefficients of the $$e^{3x}$$ term are equal, so we need to find a function with several terms. The product rule will help us with this task -- let $$f,g:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ be differentiable at least twice, thus

  1. $$(fg)'=f'g+fg'$$
  2. $$(fg)''=(f'g+fg')'=f''g+f'g'+f'g'+fg''=f''g+2f'g'+fg''.$$

Substituting it into the differential equation, we have

$$f''g+2f'g'+fg''+2f'g+2fg'-15fg=e^{3x}$$. We know that either $$f(x)=ke^{3x}$$ or $$g(x)=ke^{3x}$$, but we assume that $$f(x)=ke^{3x}$$ (we can change the names if necessary). Thus:

$$9ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)+6ke^{3x}\cdot g'(x)+ke^{3x}\cdot g''(x)+6ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)+2ke^{3x}\cdot g'(x)-15ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)=e^{3x}$$

$$\implies 9kg(x)+6kg'(x)+kg''(x)+6kg(x)+2kg'(x)-15kg(x)=1$$

$$\implies g(x)\left[9k+6k-15k\right]+g'(x)\left[6k+2k\right]+kg''(x)=1$$

$$\implies 8kg'(x)+kg''(x)=1$$.

If we choose $$g$$ where $$g''(x)=0$$ and $$g'(x)=1$$ is constant, we arrive at $$8k=1 \implies k=\frac{1}{8}$$. The function that satisfies this condition is $$g(x)$$, so we deduce that $$y_p(x)=\frac{1}{8}xe^{3x}$$. Thus, we find that the family of functions is in fact $$Axe^{3x}$$, not $$Ae^{3x}$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "Une méthode pour trouver la solution particuliere d'une ED non homogène", "created": "2024-02-16T19:32:05Z", "content": "

Parfois on reçoit des équations différentielles non homogènes où ce n'est pas évident comment trouver la solution particulière $$y_p$$ -- prends par exemple l'équation $$y''+2y'-15y=e^{3x}$$. Si on essaye $$y_p=ke^{3x}$$ ($$k$$ constante), on calculerait $$(ke^{3x})''+2(ke^{3x})'-15ke^{3x}=e^{3x} \implies 9k+6k-15k=1 \implies 0=1$$, une contradiction.

Ici, l'erreur se produit parce que les coefficients du terme $$e^{3x}$$ s'égalent, donc on doit trouver une fonction avec plusieurs termes. La règle de produits nous aidera avec ce tâche -- soient $$f,g:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ différentiables au moins deux fois, ainsi

  1. $$(fg)'=f'g+fg'$$
  2. $$(fg)''=(f'g+fg')'=f''g+f'g'+f'g'+fg''=f''g+2f'g'+fg''$$.

En le substituant dans l'équation différentielle, on a

$$f''g+2f'g'+fg''+2f'g+2fg'-15fg=e^{3x}$$. On sait que soit $$f(x)=ke^{3x}$$ soit $$g(x)=ke^{3x}$$, mais on suppose que $$f(x)=ke^{3x}$$ (on peut changer les noms si nécessaire). Ainsi :

$$9ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)+6ke^{3x}\cdot g'(x)+ke^{3x}\cdot g''(x)+6ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)+2ke^{3x}\cdot g'(x)-15ke^{3x}\cdot g(x)=e^{3x}$$

$$\implies 9kg(x)+6kg'(x)+kg''(x)+6kg(x)+2kg'(x)-15kg(x)=1$$

$$\implies g(x)\left[9k+6k-15k\right]+g'(x)\left[6k+2k\right]+kg''(x)=1$$

$$\implies 8kg'(x)+kg''(x)=1$$.

Si on choisi $$g$$ où $$g''(x)=0$$ et $$g'(x)=1$$ est constante, on arrive à $$8k=1 \implies k=\frac{1}{8}$$. La fonction qui rempli cette condition est $$g(x)$$, donc on déduit que $$y_p(x)=\frac{1}{8}xe^{3x}$$. Ainsi, on trouve que la famille de fonctions est en fait $$Axe^{3x}$$, pas $$Ae^{3x}$$.

(Je peux ajouter plus de détails si on me demande dans les commentaires)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-18T22:58:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-18T22:58:58Z", "content": "

When solve for the characteristic equation, you get:

$$e^{rt}(r+9) = 0$$, which when solved yields:

$$r = ±3i$$, which is expressed in the form $$0±3i$$ where $$a=0$$ and $$b=3$$.

So, you know that your characteristic equation is: $$y_c = e^{0t}(c_1\cos{3t} + c_2\sin{3t}) = c_1\cos{3t} + c_2\sin{3t}$$.

This should have tipped you off initially that your particular solution cannot just be of the form $$y_p = k\sin{3t}$$, as that would equate to zero. Rather, you should be using something that when differentiated behaves very similar to it.

Try using a solution of the form $$y_p = kt\sin{3t}$$ and solving from there.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul3hccbr41t", "lm7ukrjw9d22xr"], "children": [], "id": "lss40bruguz6y2", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Thank you, but can you please clarify what you mean by “your particular solution cannot just be of the form yp=ksin⁡3t, as that would equate to zero”? I can’t see how it would equal to zero.", "created": "2024-02-18T23:02:58Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Sorry I should have been more specific. Essentially, your particular solution must solve the ODE as well. So if you have $$y'' + 9y = -24\sin{3t}$$ and your particular solution is $$y_p = k\sin{3t}$$, then you have:

$$y' = 3k\cos{3t}$$ and $$y'' = -9k\sin{3t}$$

Now you can substitute this into your ODE:

$$y'' + 9y = -24\sin{3t}$$

$$-9k\sin{3t} + 9(k\sin{3t}) = -24\sin{3t}$$

$$ 0 = -24\sin{3t}$$, which is invalid statement.

Note that $$\sin{3t}$$ was also one component of your complementary equation, which is why this happened. Instead, if we use $$y_p = kt\sin{3t}$$, we can solve for $$k$$ without the left side of the equation cancelling to zero. I'll leave that to you to prove (otherwise I'd solve the question lol).

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork"], "nr": 610, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-20T17:27:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsun1xpa6du3b6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-20T17:27:38Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lsuniacgdki2zx", "to": "lsun1xozg6p3b4", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-20T17:40:21Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lsuonuwhdg917p", "to": "lsun1xozg6p3b4", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-20T18:12:40Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Webwork 6 Problem 9", "created": "2024-02-20T17:27:38Z", "content": "How do we determine our initial guess for the particular solution? I'm honestly confused how to formulate it."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 123, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-20T17:40:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tharinsa Withanage", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm2n795hd584e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-20T17:40:21Z", "content": "There are two things to consider:
1) As you plug your guess function in the ODE new terms are generated by taking the derivatives. Hence the derivatives of the force function (the function on the right) should show up in the summands of the guess solution.\u00a0
2) If the terms of your guess function also appear in the complementary solution, then they can not serve as a particular solution. Typically, multiplying by a linear factor solves this issue.\u00a0 \u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm2n795hd584e"], "children": [], "id": "lsuniac91a82zw", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-20T18:12:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-20T18:12:40Z", "content": "Typically for a problem like this one your initial guess would be something of the form $$A\\sin(kx)+B\\cos(kx)$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsuonuwduet17n", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsun1xozg6p3b4", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173508053, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 3, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 612, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T16:58:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukwuxn063eb", "data": "lsw1giixyrf2p9", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-21T16:58:39Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lsw22msl51i7df", "to": "lsw1giiqdwx2p8", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-21T17:15:51Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsw1giiqdwx2p8", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-21T17:16:42Z", "cid": "lsw23qbblue4dy", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lsw24x37d8r77g", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-21T17:17:37Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukwuxn063eb", "data": "lsw253bxr9a7is", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-21T17:17:45Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukwuxn063eb", "subject": "PCE E1 Approximating Error Question", "created": "2024-02-21T17:17:45Z", "content": "

How did we get the equation they said in the below when the function is e^x? I get the first part, but the third taylor polynomial doesnt make sense to me. Isnt it supposed to be in the form of f^n(a)/n! times (x-a)^n?

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PCE E1 Approximating Error Question", "created": "2024-02-21T17:17:37Z", "content": "

How did we get the equation they said in the below when the function is e^x? I get the first part, but the third taylor polynomial doesnt make sense to me. Isnt it supposed to be in the form of f^n(a)/n! times (x-a)^n?

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukwuxn063eb", "subject": "PCE E1 Approximating Error Question", "created": "2024-02-21T16:58:39Z", "content": "

How did we get the equation they said in the below when the function is e^x? I get the first part, but the third taylor polynomial doesnt make sense to me. Isnt it supposed to be in the form of f^n(a)/n! times (x-a)^n?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 57, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T17:15:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-21T17:15:51Z", "content": "You're right that each term of the Taylor series is of the form $$\frac{f^{(n)}(x)}{n!}\left(x-a\right)^n$$. In this example we use $$a=0$$ (the approximation centers on $$x=0$$) and $$f(x)=e^x$$, so the 3rd term equals $$\frac{(\exp)'''(0)}{3! }\left(x-0\right)^3=\frac{\exp(0)}{3!}x^3=\frac{x^3}{3!}$$ because the derivative of $$\exp$$ is itself and $$\exp(0)=1$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsw22msdw257dd", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Ohhhhhhhhh, okay yeah that makes sense. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork"], "nr": 617, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T22:22:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lswd0tze9wr5gq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-21T22:22:22Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lswdebypxys5io", "to": "lswd0tz6qv15go", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-21T22:32:52Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question about Characteristic polynomial in the method of undetermined coefficients", "created": "2024-02-21T22:22:22Z", "content": "

I was wondering why we would ever even need to find the characteristic polynomial when doing the method of undetermined coefficients when all you need is to take the original equation and plug into its y values the formula that you are using to guess. 

e.g./ for y'' -4y' -5y = 5t^2 - 2t

all you do is just try y = At^2 + Bt + C (1)

then y' = 2at  + b

then y'' = 2a

and you just sub and solve for the a b and c values and then put that back into (1) and then you have your particular solution. 

is finding the characteristic polynomial and characteristic solution even necessary?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 92, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-21T22:32:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-21T22:32:52Z", "content": "

Let's say you're given the ODE: $$y''-4y'-5y=3e^{5t}$$. Say you skip finding the complementary solution and directly guess $$y(t)=Ae^{5t}$$, you'll find that at the end you have $$0=3e^{5t}$$. Now you have to go back and complete the whole process again with $$y(t)=Ate^{5t}$$.

If you had found the characteristic equation first, you would have gotten:

$$r^2-4r-5=0 \to (r-5)(r-1)=0\to r=5, r=1$$. 

This makes your complementary solution $$c_1e^{5t}+c_2e^{t}$$. Now for some reason that I do not fully recall, because your original guess is actually part of the complementary solution, you should end up with the above invalid statement. But essentially, this is why we check the compementary solution regardless.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kjvi78x7tda2lo"], "children": [], "id": "lswdebyi8405im", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lswd0tz6qv15go", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173515650, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I'm having trouble with this question. I set up my differential equation to be 3/16 x'' + 24x = 8sin(4t) with x(0) = 1. However, I'm not sure how to solve this differential equation without x'(0)"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 86, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-23T21:18:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-23T21:19:05Z", "content": "

(I have no expertise with US customary units so I can't verify the accuracy of your equation, but I can tell you how to solve it.)

The differential equation $$\frac{3}{16}x''+24x=8\sin(4t)$$ is second-order, non-homogeneous and linear, so we can use the method of particular solutions.

Substituting $$y_p=k\sin(4t)$$ into the equation we get $$-3k\sin(4t)+24k\sin(4t)=8\sin(4t)$$, hence $$k=\frac{8}{21}$$ and $$y_p=\frac{8}{21}\sin(4t)$$.

Using the characteristic polynomial (let $$x=e^{kt}$$) we get the general solution, thus the final answer is the sum of the particular and characteristic solutions.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-23T21:18:13Z", "content": "

(I have no expertise with US customary units so I can't verify the accuracy of your equation, but I can tell you how to solve it.)

The differential equation $$\frac{3}{16}x''+24x=8\sin(4t)$$ is second-order, non-homogeneous and linear, so we can use the method of particular solutions.

Substituting $$y_p=k\sin(4t)$$ into the equation we get $$-3k\sin(4t)+24k\sin(4t)=8\sin(4t)$$, hence $$k=\frac{8}{21}$$ and $$y_p=\frac{8}{21}\sin(4t)$$.

Using the characteristic polynomial (let $$x=e^{kt}$$) we get $$\frac{3}{16}k^2+24=0$$, thus $$k=\pm8\sqrt2\cdot i$$ and $$y_c=C_1\cos(8\sqrt2 t)+C_2\sin(8\sqrt2 t)$$.

Hi this isn't necessarily related to any in-course items, but I didn't do as well on the first midterm as I had anticipated, and calculus happens to be one of my weaker subjects. 

I just wanted to use this platform to ask what study techniques I should use going forward that helped those who were initially struggling to improve, or to those who are already strong in this subject.

What I did to study for the first midterm was re-reading the in-class slideshows & doing those examples on my own, textbook questions, going over written homework and then doing past exams. Is there anything else I should be doing?

"", "created": "2024-02-24T21:23:48Z", "content": "

I can't give you useful advice without the specific area that's causing you problems, but I will present some options depending on which part of math is the greatest struggle.

Calculation/Computation

If you find that you can set up equations but struggle to get the right answer, I can think of two additional practice methods (the only way to improve this is practice)

  1. Go backwards in a sense -- start with an answer and then generate a problem that produces the answer using the technique you struggle with. This gives you a sense of patterns that will emerge in constructed (exam) situations, but I only recommend this if you are already strong with the subject.
  2. Generate random problems -- if you really want to you can download the WebWork software to generate problem sets on your own: https://openwebwork.org/. Otherwise, just write down random equations that should be solvable with the desired technique and try to get an answer (using sites such as WolframAlpha to verify)

Theorem Application/Conceptual Questions

If you struggle to use theorems, I would suggest reading and working through the exercises contained in an introduction to proofs book/course. I will say this takes a lot of effort (it took me 6 months to get through a full course), but it is very good for developing your mathematical logic. Some books that I used that I found useful:

  • Proofs and Fundamentals -- A First Course in Abstract Mathematics (Ethan D. Bloch, Birkhäuser 2000)
  • Book of Proof (Richard Hammack, online http://www.people.vcu.edu/~rhammack/BookOfProof/)
  • Basic Analysis: Introduction to Real Analysis (Jiří Lebl, online https://www.jirka.org/ra/) -- This one is more advanced but if you feel comfortable with set theory already it's a good exercise

Word Problems

I would recommend doing physics textbook exercises that involve calculus (there are some in the ECE textbook). I don't really have much advice for this (d'habitude je lis et je travaille en français donc les questions qui comprennent l'interpretation des phrases causent des problèmes pour moi).

I believe the correct answer was a specific equation; the rubric refers to a substitution to eliminate $$T_2$$ using that $$T_1+T_2$$ is constant. I think the following is the correct answer:

$$T_1'=4C_{in}-2C_{out}=4\frac{T_2}{100-2t}-2\frac{T_1}{100+2t}$$; since $$T_1+T_2=10$$ it follows that $$T_2=10-T_1$$ hence $$T_1'=4\frac{10-T_1}{100-2t}-2\frac{T_1}{10+2t}$$.

I used a second-order derivative and lost the point on the exam. I don't know if you did something similar.

I specifically use the substitution cos(theta) = 3/sqrt((x-1)^2 + 9) and dx = (3 * sec^2(theta)) * dtheta. Hence, I obtained by final answer in the arccos format as arccos(3/sqrt((x-1)^2 + 9)) / 3 + C.

Looking forward to clarification on the same!

", "created": "2024-02-27T01:44:21Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 1, "id": "lt3pfudrkss6e6", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-02-27T01:44:22Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T04:12:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-27T13:24:14Z", "content": "

(Response to a comment) Your primitive is not exactly correct; taking the derivative we get $$\frac{x-1}{|x-1|(x^2-2x+10)}\ne\frac{1}{x^2-2x+10}$$ because the former is not defined at $$x=1$$, but the original function is defined there.

The error occurs because the substitution $$\theta(x)=\arccos\left(\frac{3}{\sqrt{(x-1)^2+9}}\right)$$ violates the hypothesis of the theorem that allows us to make a change of variables. Recall the full statement:

Suppose $$g:[a,b]\mapsto I$$ is a differentiable function with a continuous derivative, where $$I\subseteq\mathbb{R}$$ is an interval. Furthermore, suppose $$f:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ is continuous on $$I$$. Then $$\int_a^b (f\circ g)(x)\cdot g'(x)\,dx=\int_{g(a)}^{g(b)} f(u)\,du$$.

Note that $$\frac{d}{dx}\arccos\left(\frac{3}{\sqrt{(x-1)^2+9}}\right) = \frac{3(x-1)}{|x-1|\left((x-1)^2+9\right)}$$, a non-continuous function at $$x=1$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-27T04:12:31Z", "content": "

(Response to a comment) Your primitive is not exactly correct; taking the derivative we get $$\frac{x-1}{|x-1|(x^2-2x+10)}\ne\frac{1}{x^2-2x+10}$$ because the former is not defined at $$x=1$$, but the original function is defined there.

(I will post an explanation of why this happens tomorrow)

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0101"], "nr": 642, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-26T01:53:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lt2abon5kmt5ds", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-26T01:53:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lt2ccjgrorl5if", "to": "lt2abomyqv65dr", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-26T02:50:06Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Second Order ODE behaviour (D3 PCE, D2 LEC)", "created": "2024-02-26T01:53:27Z", "content": "I am confused on what the graph of a second order solution is supposed to indicate? For example, is it supposed to indicate something for specific time points? What do the oscillations mean? How are we supposed to graph them?

Thanks for any help."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ethan Wang Jan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukhvugp424e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 119, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-26T02:50:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-26T02:50:06Z", "content": "

Typically when we say graph of the solution, we mean a particular solution (note that there are infinitely many solutions to any ODE).

\n

\n

For the second-order ODE, in D1 and D2 we discussed everything that could happen in terms of the roots of the characteristic polynomial. We also discussed what the general solution looks like. In one of the cases, where the characteristic polynomial has no real roots, you will get a linear combination of sin and cos in the general solution. These are oscillating functions. That means your solution will oscillate.\u00a0

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0101"], "nr": 648, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T04:14:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lt3utbxg4pf67v", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-27T04:14:49Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lt4gf7hdlcipr", "to": "lt3utbx8zol67t", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-27T14:19:41Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Euler's Formula", "created": "2024-02-27T04:14:49Z", "content": "

Hello, can someone explain how this works?

I thought in this example, we should have two e^(rts), one having +i and the other having -i, thus having TWO sets of cosine and sine. How did our profs "shrink" it into only one cosine and one sine?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 138, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T14:19:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jaewon Shon", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukwctwd63cu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-27T14:19:41Z", "content": "

They combined the constants, starting with $$\alpha\exp\left(i\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)+\beta\exp\left(-i\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)$$, we can write $$\alpha\cos\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right) + \alpha\cdot i\sin\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right) + \beta\cos\left(-\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right) + \beta\cdot i\sin\left(\sqrt{-\frac{k}{m}}t\right)$$ by Euler's formula.

Since $$\sin(-\theta)=-\sin(\theta)$$ et $$\cos(-\theta)=\cos(\theta)$$ we can therefore write $$\cos\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)\left[\alpha+\beta\right] + \sin\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)\left[i\alpha-i\beta\right]$$. Let $$c_1=\alpha+\beta$$ and $$c_2=i\alpha+i\beta$$, therefore $$c_1\cos\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right) + c_2\sin\left(\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}t\right)$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukwctwd63cu"], "children": [], "id": "lt4gf7h61uvpq", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lt3utbx8zol67t", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173549266, "default_anonymity": "no"}
