{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["logistics", "written_homework", "other"], "nr": 666, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-29T01:36:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lt6k1y4amaw5er", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-29T01:36:54Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk8pqa2d1bw", "to": "lt6k1y41n235ep", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-29T05:41:00Z", "cid": "lt6srvskcys4cw"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "to": "lt6k1y41n235ep", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-29T22:09:19Z", "cid": "lt7s2ujkyri5f9"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lt6k1y41n235ep", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-01T04:35:08Z", "cid": "lt85v0h49432o0", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "This note addresses a recent post made on piazza", "created": "2024-02-29T01:36:54Z", "content": "

We should begin by bringing everyone up to date.

For those who did not see what happened: there was a post created last night in which a student voiced their displeasure about the marking of Written Homework 1.  To outward appearances, the post looked like it was deleted quickly.

There are three issues here that should all be addressed.  This is a long post.  For the TL;DR version, just read the parts in bold font.

The Original Post

We did not delete the post.  Instead, we changed its visibility to private so that the original poster and the instructors could see it, but not everyone else.  It is still there and we communicated with the student directly through email.

The reason to make the post private was that its tone was quite inappropriate for this forum.  A civil discussion about how we grade in this course would be great to have, but an attack on how the course is run does not contribute to any positive result.  We welcome the opportunity to be more transparent and will be glad to have a proper dialogue about the course, but this post was not looking for a back-and-forth.  In the rest of this reply we have some of the important points that have driven our philosophy of this course.

We certainly understand the original poster’s frustration about their mark, and more so about the poor manner in which the regrade request was handled by our team, but we stand by the decision that the post did not meet the level of civility that is needed for a class discussion board.

The Importance of Solutions

The process of writing solutions is a very delicate matter.  Entering first year, almost every math course in this university asks for carefully written solutions.  What that means, though, is different for each course.

The original post made the claim that what is important about math is its correctness, rather than the ability of others to comprehend it.  Almost every first-year student – and especially first-year math students, such as your professors were a couple of years ago – has this belief.  Unfortunately, experience proves it to be incorrect.

As just one example, let’s look at Fermat’s Theorem.  This is the one that said that any formula of the form $$x^n+y^n=z^n$$ with integer $$n>2$$ has no solution among the positive integers.  The theorem is correct, but whatever Fermat thought was the proof was wrong.  We know this because it took four hundred years for us to show the theorem and then the most cutting-edge mathematics of the 1990’s was needed to finally show that this is true.  To this day, math departments around the world routinely get letters from people who claim to have found a proof or a simple proof to Fermat’s Theorem and each department has some poor soul who looks through the letter, finds where the attempted proof has division by zero, and then replies to the letter.

Why is this important?  Because Fermat’s Theorem was always true.  It was true before Fermat figured it out and remained true for the four centuries until a real proof appeared, but we did not know that.  There was always the suspicion that something might go wrong if we try to use it as fact and it was right of us to be wary of it.  Until the proof appeared, Fermat’s Theorem was magic – something we liked to believe in, but that we knew we could not trust.  A lot of people, including some great mathematicians, wrote what they thought were proofs of the theorem and they all ended up being wrong. 

Here’s the issue, though.  When you have a proof of something, not only is the theorem correct, but the argument is correct.  If parts of it are applied to other situations (like taking a piece of code you wrote for one program and using it in another), then they can be used as parts of a new proof.  If someone takes a theorem that is correct, but has a proof that is wrong, and then applies the proof’s thinking to other statements, that will lead to conclusions that we are certain are right, but are actually incorrect.  That may not seem like a big deal within mathematics, but if you build a bridge using math that is wrong, or create a self-driving car powered by an algorithm that is essentially flawed, then lives are in danger.

The Marking

So, until we are sure that a solution is correct, the math cannot be used.  Unfortunately, there is a huge amount of depth and complexity to mathematics and the correctness of a solution has to be determined relative to the audience.  The level of writing, the detail of explanation, the assumed knowledge of the reader will be different depending on who you are talking to.  You have all seen this in your ESP courses and it is one of the most important lessons in your entire degree: it really, truly does not matter how smart you are if no one listens to what you say.

A solution that states “it is easy (or trivial or obvious…) to see that <conclusion>” is not going to work as a proof.  We don’t recommend actually doing this, but take the next presentation you need to make to your ESP clients and justify anything that you think is trivial by just saying “Obviously, this is true.”  Just imagine how well that will go.  Next, imagine doing this as fully trained engineers meeting with a client.  A lot of people are confident.  A lot of people claim that what they are proposing is clearly true.  Some of these people are right, but not many.  As engineers, though, it is your responsibility not simply to say this, but to show it.

With this course, as with MAT 186 and 188, a part of the goal is to teach how to use mathematics in your justifications to clients.  This needs to be done in a way that they can follow and that will convince them.  Having the right numbers is a vital first step, but you do need to be able to demonstrate that those numbers are correct.

Learning to write math for an audience is very tricky.  There are no good resources out there.  More importantly, the audience is ever-changing.  Different TAs/profs/courses will have different interpretations of what does and does not work as a justification.  It is subjective.  Math may not be subjective, but writing proofs in it definitely is.  That’s not a comforting fact, but it is better to be aware of it.  We wish it was more clear-cut, but communications in mathematics can be about as challenging as communications in natural language. 

We practice and learn math writing through success and failure.  The marks given in the course are not random, but they do represent something that is often far more subjective than most people realize when first encountering higher mathematics.  This leads to challenges in adapting to writing proofs that are meant not for others who are at the same level, but to those who know less of the material.

 

We hope that this helps everyone see why we took the actions we took and also why the course is taught the way it is.  Again, we welcome an open, respectful dialogue about any element of this course.  If you have any questions or comments, let us know and we’ll continue this discussion.

~MAT187 Teaching Team

0, "subject": "

Thank you for addressing the post. I do believe it is important to give reasonings in a mathematical writing, and understand it is one of the emphasis of the course. That's why I also believe that some standards for an expected justification, with more specifications, and that are more reasonable, should be established. We students have various mathematical backgrounds and knowledge base, thus the meaning for an appropriate justification would vary greatly among individuals. We did not know to what extent do the grading TAs expect us to elaborate our argument, and could only guess the standards up to now. So hopefully we can have a clearer instructions for an expected justification level. 

Considering that written assignments and tutorial worksheets weigh up to 20% of our total grades, I think their grading schemes and rubrics should also be more reasonable, and less subjective. As important as a reasoning justification is, it is still more helpful that an engineer would come up with a valid number than not getting results (this is trivial, see civil engineering; this is also because engineers will only use theorems proved by either mathematicians and physicists to do calculation, which most likely guarantee correctness as long as the calculations are)(The Fermat's example, which I will discuss later, isn't appropriate as I think). Thus, I believe if we students have come to correct solutions using a mathematically approved method, even lacking of a few lines of explanation in sentences, the majority marks of a question should be given, rather than grading heavily based on justification (based on the rubrics released for 1.2, WH1, only 1 out of 5 marks are given for correct answers, where the rest are all given based on justifications)

Also, I have slightly different opinions regarding the example of Fermat's Theorem. By correctness I meant for mathematically rigorous, that a statement has a proof (in the cases of our assignments, we might use a conclusion that has been used and proved for thousands of times elsewhere, even if we did not provide justification, we know it is correct for there obviously is a proof), not any so-claimed guesses that seem correct. This is different from the "correct" used in your Fermat's case as there wasn't and hadn't had before a proof. Didn't Fermat never come up with a proof for his theorem, only leaving a note that he believed to have a proof that was "too large to fit in the margin"? In other words, Fermat's Theorem had always been a conjecture until it was proved later after hundreds of years (using Galois' theories that Fermat never could have understanding of, which means he never proved it in the first place). So he was neither correct nor providing comprehension. Who would say Goldbach conjecture is correct even though it is for any natural numbers known by human? No one, because it's not proved, and that's why it is a conjecture, as was Fermat's Theorem before proved.

There are also several cases in mathematics where mathematicians came up with intuitive "proofs",had convinced their peer workers, yet to be disproved by future mathematicians. Even Euler, the greatest mathematician of all time, made mistakes which nobody was able to spot, when he was proving the Basel Problem. He used a division that is so intuitive that any straightforward comprehension wouldn't spot his mistakes, until Cauchy and Riemann introduced the heavily notation based proving Real Analysis system, that the division would be found inaccurate and lacked rigors when dealing with infinite series.

For decades, mathematicians also believed that a continuous function can only have a non-dense set as its non-differentiable points, to "prove" it using sentences is so trivial that there must be a somewhat curve which is differentiable connecting the two adjacent non-differentiable points, until Weierstrass introduced his Weierstrass Function.

On the other hand, when Einstein published his writings of relativity, "Only three people in the world understand relativity", said Max Planck, because the ideas were too abstract to comprehend, Einstein didn't use the "fabric-to-represent-spacetime", or the"Matter tells spacetime how to curve, spacetime tells matter how to move" way of understanding, instead he used heavily on tensor analysis and abstract geometry, (which are actually correct compared to Fermat's "proof"). Not explaining to an intuitively understandable by common-mind levels didn't fail Einstein to be one of the greatest physicists of all time.

While I agree engineering math is different and requires reasoning, math (and physic) in general still prioritizes correctness over comprehension. Because comprehension requires intuitiveness, which can often be wrong, and math notation doesn't. (Luckily for engineering maths, all the functions are nice with good properties, thus can be comprehended by intuition)

Thanks for sharing your thoughts! There are many things to discuss about mathematics and the philosophy of mathematics. It's a really interesting topic (and one that is a topic of active research not just in math but also in adjacent fields).

The only thing I wanted to mention is that many people would disagree that Euler is "the greatest mathematician of all time" :) Besides the usual discussions like "Is it Euler or Gauss" or similar names pitted against each other, note in particular that mathematics, like many other disciplines, has the tendency to "over-spotlight" the contributions of European's to the field. Historically, Europeans loved to name things after themselves (or after each other) which is why - often for very sad reasons - their names are plastered all over the world.

Without diminishing Euler's absolutely exceptional achievements, a lot of the most important math, in particular the foundations upon which the most elementary mathematical operations rest, have been discovered and formed by people whose identity is forever forgotten.

That's why it is always tricky to say that there is someone who is the greatest/the best/the one and only.

I just want to share a bit of my experience at this university.  I have been here for nearly 30 years and it seems like every negotiation is taken down to the wire.  A few do end in strikes (I think about three or four during my entire time here), but almost all of them get resolved on the last day or two.

My recommendation is to think of Monday as Schrodinger's Day - it will be both a strike and not a strike until the moment you check your email upon waking up that morning and finding out which one it has become.

I am aware of UofT’s history of averting strikes at the last minute. 

However, this year is the first round of negotiations after Bill 124 repeal, and judging from the bargaining updates, management has not been constructive at the table. It’s still worthwhile to consider the possible of a strike, and how students can show solidarity to unionized workers/learn about labour rights regardless.

Still, I will take your advice… do all of my work as if there is no disruption happening on Monday.

For students considering what union typically represents engineers in Ontario - that would be the Society of United Professionals, a local of the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers (IFPTE). 

For students looking to go on PEY and work at Toronto Hydro, Ontario Power Generation, IESO, etc… those workplaces all have union presence! Keep that in mind… you’re closer to a union than you think!

I think it is an informal way to say that the Taylor polynomial at that point will have the same value for each derivative as the function it is trying to model (depending on how many derivatives you want, which denotes the accuracy). 

In general, the Taylor polynomial will be more accurate around for example x=0 when it is set up to model the original function at x=0 when it has more derivatives. However, as you move away from that point, then your Taylor polynomial generally (and quickly) becomes a worse approximation.

Here is a video I found helpful for visualizing: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3d6DsjIBzJ4

The complementary soln. is 

and the particular is 

Would there ever be "shared solns", or perhaps more so "shared values" no matter what A, B, c1, and c2 are? My idea is that they are quasi periodical, so there might be same values given a same t. What would they mean? In my mind that would imply the "solution spaces" of the complementary and particular would overlap at some points, but then what would THAT mean? Alternatively, would the IVP "take over" here and ensure that such a thing never happens? OR another line of thinking I have is when solving for A and B, the ODE's nature itself would show that it is impossible for such "shared values"?

The complementary solution is teh screenshot you included. However, the particular solution is not what appears in the screenshot. That gives you a general form for a guess for a particular solution. $$x_p$$ is then found by plugging in this guess into the ODE and finding A and B.

Any function in the general solution generates 0 when plugged into the left side of the ODE. Any particular solution solves the ODE with an external force. So these will never coincide. Geometrically, the space of complementary and particular solutions make parallel planes.

Uodate: I can confirm that there will be no strike and the union secured a deal!



Generally, contract negotiations always go down to the wire. This means that even if there is a deal (in which case there won't be a strike), that deal will be reached in the last minutes. Negotiations are still ongoing and it is quite likely that they will continue until midnight. This also means that no one (literally no one, not even the president of the union or the president of the university) will know until shortly before midnight if there is a strike or not.

 

We very much understand that this is a stressful and anxious situation for students to be in. We sincerely wish we would know more, but unfortunately we (the professors) do not have any particular inside knowledge. Unfortunately, we know just as much (or as little) about this as you.

"Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-04T12:08:48Z", "content": "

Update: I can confirm that there will be no strike and the union secured a deal!



[Edit: Over writing all this, I forgot to answer the actual question. The poster you are sharing is about a protest that was advertised independent of the actual strike happening or not. The poster is not a confirmation of a strike.]

 

We recommend the following for all your classes:

  • Plan for the upcoming week under the assumption that there will NOT be a strike, i.e. assume that all lectures, all tutorials, all assessments etc. are running as usual, that there will be no new deadlines, no changes, no extensions.
  • Before heading out to class tomorrow morning, check your email inbox and the Quercus pages for all your courses for updates.
  • Even if a strike is happening, note that this does NOT necessarily mean that everything is cancelled. This depends a lot on individual situations. Unless you get an announcement that something is cancelled, assume that it is not cancelled.

Also, regarding the midnight deadline, note that in previous negotiation rounds this deadline was sometimes extended into the early morning, so we might need to wait longer than midnight (I vaguely recall a few years ago where it took until 4am or something). Furthermore, even if a strike is called at midnight, it's unlikely that there will be any clear announcements within the first hours (since we will - hopefully - be asleep by then). That's why I wouldn't recommend "hitting the refresh button nonstop at midnight in the hope of an update".

 

I think the most important thing at this moment is to be aware of two things:

  1. We are all humans and we will navigate this whole situation in a way where we help each other out. Everyone has their understandable causes and goals (students, TAs, professors, ...) but it's important to keep in mind that in the end, everyone is doing their best to act in good faith to make this learning experience here at U of T as good as possible, both in the short run, and in the long run.
  2. Sometimes, things in life are out of your control and the best is to try to not lose your mind (or your sleep) over this. It's easy to go down the spiral of "what if..." and "it's going to be so bad if ..." and so on.

I am by no means trying to dismiss your concerns, your anxiety, or your worries. I know and we know that - even without a possible strike looming - March is always a tough time at university since the term has been going on for so long and a lot of high stakes assessments are happening. We see that and hear that! I am just trying my best here to recommend taking your mind off of this whole thing and just wait until it happens (or not).

 

In my professional opinion, the best thing to do tonight (once you are done with your usual coursework of course) is to watch a few episodes of your favourite TV show, or to hang out with some friends, and get a good nights sleep. If someone is questioning you, tell them "my prof told me to watch TV/to hang out with my friends" :)

That's why I wouldn't recommend "hitting the refresh button nonstop at midnight in the hope of an update".

I think the most important thing at this moment is to be aware of two things:

  1. We are all humans and we will navigate this whole situation in a way where we help each other out. Everyone has their understandable causes and goals (students, TAs, professors, ...) but it's important to keep in mind that in the end, everyone is doing their best to act in good faith to make this learning experience here at U of T as good as possible, both in the short run, and in the long run.
  2. Sometimes, things in life are out of your control and the best is to try to not lose your mind (or your sleep) over this. It's easy to go down the spiral of "what if..." and "it's going to be so bad if ..." and so on.

I am by no means trying to dismiss your concerns, your anxiety, or your worries. I know and we know that - even without a possible strike looming - March is always a tough time at university since the term has been going on for so long and a lot of high stakes assessments are happening. We see that and hear that! I am just trying my best here to recommend taking your mind off of this whole thing and just wait until it happens (or not).

In my professional opinion, the best thing to do tonight (once you are done with your usual coursework of course) is to watch a few episodes of your favourite TV show, or to hang out with some friends, and get a good nights sleep. If someone is questioning you, tell them "my prof told me to watch TV/to hang out with my friends" :)

Hi,

I was able to complete Q6 of Webwork 8 by guess and checking the factorial with my calculator. But, on an exam without a calculator, is there a way to algebraically solve an equation that has x! where x is to be found? 

Thanks

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sophia Alexanian ", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm6unadbfxc6rw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 128, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-06T03:46:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1709259422}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ieint2yvunh486", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-06T03:46:11Z", "content": "In general, solving $$\frac{1}{n!}\leq 1/100000$$ (or something similar) is quite tricky. It is concerned with the next degree after your minimum, if you're using it to calculate the reminder of cos(1) at degree 7 it would use degree 8. So if the error is less than 4 decimal places for degree 8, degree 7 is the minimum.\u00a0

Here the answer for degree 7 just happens to be the same as degree 6, however if you were to calculate the error at degree 6 it would be above 4 decimal places.\u00a0

TLDR: degree 6 would be the "true" answer but you can't verify it using the remainder formula.\u00a0

Here the answer for degree 7 just happens to be the same as degree 6, however if you were to calculate the error at degree 6 the error bound would be above 4 decimal places.\u00a0
"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-06T05:24:38Z", "content": "If degree 6 is too low and degree 7 is the same as degree 6, then the minimum degree must be higher than 7"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltfctxqq8qgeh", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I put 8 and it was wrong so I just kept 7. There is a technical issue with this question that is looked at to be fixed at the moment.

If the question asks for tan(59), then for some students (but not all students, it depends highly on the seed) WeBWorK still expects an answer for tan(61) instead.

So in short, try answering the question under the assumption that you should approximate tan(61), then it should work.

As said this only affects some students. For some, the question asks for tan(59) and this is the answer that will work.

Sorry for the trouble. We've forwarded this concern and hopefully it will be fixed soon.

ay'' + by' + cy = f(t)

Is there a reason for this? I understand we obtain the homogenous equation using force balancing, but I don't understand how the external force is applied here. Does it oppose the other forces? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yousuf Khan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm15xdyfa1i7c0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 94, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-07T05:26:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yaying Luo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llgvml3fbza6rd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Matthew Desmarais", "endorser": {"k3t0tl7krg32to": 1579115969, "k52y9qu3rg41mr": 1584116403, "global": 1587066490, "k38wsyi5wxb1hz": 1587254389, "ktdwmksib25673": 1634571238, "kt03zgk52gf2vz": 1634684358}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Inara Ezers", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm40xv1qonh3xt", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Deena Abrari", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukrjw9d22xr", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-07T05:26:58Z", "content": "

The meaning of each term:

  • $$ay''$$ is the net force
  • $$by'$$ is the force that depends on the object's current speed
  • $$cy$$ is the force that depends on the object's current position
  • $$f(t)$$ is the force that is independent of the object -- it's an external force applied with a value unrelated to position or velocity, only to time.

Due to the definition of $$f(t)$$ it can either oppose or augment the other two forces, it depends on what exactly the external force is (since this is a fairly broad catch-all)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-07T05:26:13Z", "content": "

Student answer explains the salient points quite well. One of Netwon's law states that the net forces on an object can be related to it's acceleration as

$$\vec F_{net} = m \vec a$$. Since we know that acceleration is the second derivative of position, we can rewrite this as $$\vec F_{net} = m \frac{d^2 \vec s}{dt^2}$$, where $$\vec s$$ is the position. 

So if we find all the net forces (spring force, damping, gravity, etc.), we can set up an ODE like the student above explained.

The question asks for us to estimate for a three decimal place accuracy. 

Let's suppose  we want to guarantee our estimation rounds to 1.503:
If our error $$R<0.001$$, then if our estimation $$c$$ would be $$1.502If our error $$R<0.0005$$, then our estimation $$c$$ would be $$1.5025

Thus, do the quasiperiod and period have the same values for an oscillation?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 111, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T00:58:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mazen Ismail", "endorser": {"lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1709164117, "lqck4qp2w431en": 1709176118}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukdbn6w71pk", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T00:59:08Z", "content": "

For a function $$f$$ to be periodic, we require that $$f(x+T) = f(x) $$ for all x in the function's domain.  Here, $$T$$ represents the period.

However, consider a function which we have discussed a lot in this course:

$$f(t) = e^{rt} \sin t$$

This function seems periodic in the sense that the time it takes to go from peak to peak is constant, but it fails to meet the definition of periodic above ($$f(x+T) \neq f(x) $$). We call this function quasi-periodic, and we can find the quasi period by finding the time between successive peaks. 

If we find the time between successive peaks for a $$\sin$$ function, it is $$2\pi$$, so it's 'quasi-periodic' with period $$2\pi$$. We also know that $$\sin(x+2\pi) = \sin(x)$$ for any x, so $$\sin$$ is periodic by the definition I laid out in the beginning.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T00:58:49Z", "content": "

For a function $$f$$ to be periodic, we require that $$f(x+T) = f(x) $$ for all x in the function's domain.  Here, $$T$$ represents the period.

However, consider a function which we have discussed a lot in this course:

$$f(t) = e^rt \sin t$$

This function seems periodic in the sense that the time it takes to go from peak to peak is constant, but it fails to meet the definition of periodic above ($$f(x+T) \neq f(x) $$). We call this function quasi-periodic, and we can find the quasi period by finding the time between successive peaks. 

If we find the time between successive peaks for a $$\sin$$ function, it is $$2\pi$$, so it's 'quasi-periodic' with period $$2\pi$$. We also know that $$\sin(x+2\pi) = \sin(x)$$ for any x, so $$\sin$$ is periodic by the definition I laid out in the beginning.

For a function $$f$$ to be periodic, we require that $$f(x+T) = f(x) $$ for all x in the function's domain.  Here, $$T$$ represents the period.

However, consider a function which we have discussed a lot in this course:

$$f(t) = e^rt \sin t$$

This function $$\emph{seems}$$ periodic in the sense that the time it takes to go from peak to peak is constant, but it fails to meet the definition of periodic above ($$f(x+T) \neq f(x) $$). We call this function quasi-periodic, and we can find the quasi period by finding the time between successive peaks. 

If we find the time between successive peaks for a $$\sin$$ function, it is $$2\pi$$, so it's 'quasi-periodic' with period $$2\pi$$. We also know that $$\sin(x+2\pi) = \sin(x)$$ for any x, so $$\sin$$ is periodic by the definition I laid out in the beginning.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ella Thompson", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk8nza1i1bs", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Grace Chang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukndc1aa2m0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 124, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-09T01:06:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ella Thompson", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk8nza1i1bs", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T01:06:21Z", "content": "

For the functions given in the question, it is possible to calculate an explicit formula for the nth derivative of a function.

For example, if we have the function $$f(x)=\frac{1}{2x}$$, we can write the n-th derivative as $$f^{(n)}(x)=\frac{n!(-1)^n}{2x^{n+1}}$$ (I advise you to verify why this formula works).

You need to do something similar for your answer to question 4.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk8nza1i1bs", "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "lm7uk96a8bm1dp"], "children": [], "id": "ltjdxbtd1zd65a", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-09T20:21:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T20:21:51Z", "content": "The best approach is to write the first 4 or 5 derivatives and then look for any pattern that merges. Then guess the $$n-$$th derivative based on your observation. Write your guess down and then cross-check it with the derivatives you already wrote. If it matches, use it to predict the next derivative.

For the functions in this question, you will see a pattern that makes it feasible to write the general $$n$$-th derivative. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk96a8bm1dp"], "children": [], "id": "ltkj7bsztm777i", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "lm7uk8nza1i1bs", "lm7ukndc1aa2m0"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltj4cdbi2ec4hn", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173634952, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I am so lost. I know that we should be using the error formula and that the error should be less than 0.0005, but I don't know how to actually solve for the min degree taylor polynomial. Thanks so much

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 126, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-09T16:40:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T16:45:09Z", "content": "

The remainder theorem for Taylor polynomials states that the remainder between a function and it's n'th Taylor polynomial centred for x in some interval centred at a is 

$$R_n(x) \leq \frac{|f^{(n+1)}(x^*)|}{(n+1)!}|x-a|^{n+1}$$

... where here $$x^*$$ is the point in the interval which maximizes $$|f^{(n+1)}(x^*)|$$. 

Technical jargon aside, if you could use this estimate to find the largest value of $$|x-1|$$ for which the remainder is less than the error tolerance we need, you'd have your interval.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 733, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-09T06:01:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltjogntqeu334c", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-09T06:01:19Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltkbqsfutyf22b", "to": "ltjogntijil34b", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-09T16:53:02Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltkbrubfpww324", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-09T16:53:52Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltkbv7tp7fp6s9", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-09T16:56:29Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltkbzm6kgic3kh", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-09T16:59:54Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltkbzsvid7y3q6", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-09T17:00:03Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltkc0a9gtet4zz", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-09T17:00:25Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltkc8qhlt7a1em", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-09T17:07:00Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WH3 Q3 part 1", "created": "2024-03-09T06:01:19Z", "content": "Q3 part 1 asks for the upper error bound for the nth degree. Typically, Taylor error is calculated for a given degree.  Do we rely on the fact that the 0th degree polynomial would have the most error? Or do we somehow find an upper bound for the derivative (which is infinite if n isn't given?)?

Side note, I did parts b and c fine and got an exact error formula there. However, I don't feel like the closed form expression of Pn is supposed to be used for A. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 189, "children": [{"history_size": 7, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-09T16:53:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T17:07:00Z", "content": "

Taylor polynomials have a lot of moving parts, so let's restate the question quickly:

Consider $$f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}$$, and it's n'th Taylor polynomial centred at $$a=0$$,

$$P_n^a(x) = \sum_{i=0}^n \frac{f^{(i)}(a)}{i!}(x-a)^i$$

You have been given a theorem for estimating the error between $$f(x) - P_n^a(x)$$ which would be quite helpful in finding an upper bound for this error. This error will probably depend on which Taylor polynomial you use to estimate the original function (i.e. which $$n$$ you choose for the Taylor polynomials $$P_n^a(x)$$). All that needs to be done is find how the error depends on $$n$$.

Hope this helps!

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T17:00:25Z", "content": "

Hello, can someone please tell me where I am going wrong with this question? The question is:

I got the first two right, but the last two parts are marked wrong. Here are my steps for the third part:

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{f''(c)}{2!}(x-c)^2$$

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{\frac{-1}{(-3+4)^2}}{2}(x+3)^2$$

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{-1}{2}(x+3)^2$$

This is what I have, but it's marking me wrong. Any help would be appreciated!

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WeBWork 8 Question 1", "created": "2024-03-09T18:33:02Z", "content": "

Hello, can someone please tell me where I am going wrong with this question? The question is:

I got the first two right, but the last two parts are marked wrong. Here are my steps for the third part:

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{f''(c)}{2!}(x-c)^2$$

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{\frac{-1}{(-3+4)^2}}{2}(x+3)^2$$

$$\displaystyle P_2(x)=\frac{-1}{2}(x+3)^2$$

This is what I have, but it's marking me wrong. Any help would be appreciated!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 105, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-09T18:48:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llyi7s8ecap62t", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T18:48:32Z", "content": "

$$\displaystyle x+3+\frac{-1}{2}(x+3)^2$$

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 740, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T00:19:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 1, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltkroygtf7una", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-10T00:19:31Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltlonlyouot3qm", "to": "ltkroygjimfn8", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-10T15:42:15Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "data": "ltlotwjjedh2o4", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-10T15:47:09Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltkroygjimfn8", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-10T19:18:30Z", "cid": "ltlwdpocqvb2t9", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "to": "ltkroygjimfn8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-14T02:27:36Z", "cid": "ltqm137mm2a1la"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question 1 part 2 - use of undetermined constant coefficients (c1, c2, etc)", "created": "2024-03-10T00:19:31Z", "content": "Question 1 part 2 asks for a particular solution and a single solution to the homogenous system given information about the characteristic polynomial. In other words, we are finding the particular and complementary solutions. I just wanted to check if our final solutions are allowed to have undetermined coefficients (ie c1, c2, etc)? Are both the complementary and particular solutions allowed to have them? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 162, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T15:42:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Keaton Bailie", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukotj9jp2qd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T15:47:09Z", "content": "

In part a), we show that if $$y_p(t) = A(t)e^{\alpha t}$$ is a particular solution to our differential equation, then we need to solve a different ODE for $$A(t)$$ such that

$$\frac{P''(\alpha)}{2} A''(t) + P'(\alpha) A'(t) + P(\alpha) A(t) = 1 $$

What does this mean exactly? Well, $$P$$ is the characteristic polynomial for the original mass spring system. $$P(\alpha)$$ and it's derivatives are just constants for the sake of the ODE since they don't depend on $$t$$. This means that this ODE describes the behaviour for $$A(t)$$. If we can find $$A(t)$$, then we know what our particular solution will be. 

Good luck!

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kemxfqx3ord1go", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T15:42:15Z", "content": "

In part a), we show that if $$y_p(t) = A(t)e^{\alpha t}$$ is a particular solution to our differential equation, then we need to solve a different ODE for $$A(t)$$ such that

$$\frac{P''(\alpha)}{2} A''(t) + P'(\alpha) A'(t) + P(\alpha) A(t) = 1 $$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukotj9jp2qd"], "children": [], "id": "ltlonlyh8283ql", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I was also wondering what it means by a " single solution to the homogenous system". We say that a series converges if it's sequence of partial sums converge. The partial sum for this series is 

$$S_k = \sum_{i=0}^k (-1)^i = 1 - 1 + 1 -1 + ... $$

You have correctly identified that if $$k$$ is even then $$S_k = 1$$ and if $$k$$ is odd then $$S_k = 0$$. Now let's take a step back and just think of $$S_k$$ as a members of a sequence which I will call $$b_k$$. 

$$b_k = \{S_k\}_0^{\inf} = \{1, 0, 1, 0, 1, ... \}$$

Does this sequence $$b_k$$ converge to some number? Hope this helps.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 125, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-11T04:51:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukdbn6w71pk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-11T04:53:23Z", "content": "

Find the Cn coefficients, where n is 0,1,2,3,4. You will need the derivatives of f(x) = 5/1+x for those.

A Maclaurin polynomial just means it is centered at x = 0, so a = 0.

Construct your pn(x) for each n from 0 to 4 using the appropriate coefficients, and then generalize your solution using a sum notation for any n.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukdbn6w71pk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-11T04:51:56Z", "content": "

Find the Cn coefficients, where n is 0,1,2,3,4. You will need the derivatives of f(x) = 5/1+x for those.

A Maclaurin polynomial just means it is centered at x = 0, so a = 0.

Construct your pn(x) for each n from 0 to 4, and then generalize your solution using a sum notation for any n.

Only continue reading if you are having trouble with WW8 question 5. 

WW8 question 5 has a bug for a subset of you. If you are asked to find tan of an angle $$\theta$$ less than 60 (for example 59.2), read the question as if it asks for tan of $$60+(60-\theta)$$ (for example $$60.8$$). If this does not help, leave the question empty. It will not affect your grade. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "Webwork 8 Question 5", "created": "2024-03-11T06:03:47Z", "content": "

WW8 question 5 has a bug for a subset of you. If you are asked to find tan of an angle $$\theta$$ less than 60 (for example 59.2), read the question as if it asks for tan of $$60+(60-\theta)$$ (for example $60.8$). If this does not help, leave the question empty. It will not affect your grade.

Hello,

I attempted finding the particular solution by:

1. Finding alpha (in terms of k,u and m) using the conditions given (P(alpha) = 0 and P'(alpha) = 0)

2. And plugging it into the differential equation/ODE given in part 1 (which I rewrote by plugging in the ODE)

However, that does not work because the alpha has an imaginary number i in it (since the model is a sinusoidal motion). So, is there a different approach I can take? 

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WH3 Question 1 Part 2", "created": "2024-03-12T06:20:59Z", "content": "

Hello,

I attempted finding the particular solution by:

1. Finding alpha (in terms of k,u and m) using the conditions given (P(alpha) = 0 and P'(alpha) = 0)

2. And plugging it into the differential equation/ODE given in part 1 (which I rewrote).

However, that does not work because the alpha has an imaginary number i in it (since the model is a sinusoidal motion). So, is there a different approach I can take?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0103"], "nr": 768, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-13T05:17:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltpcnu88mkd6g3", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-13T05:17:35Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltptrk5c4tu5w1", "to": "ltpcnu80pgx6g2", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-13T13:16:22Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lecture D3 question", "created": "2024-03-13T05:17:35Z", "content": "

Sorry I forgot what my table group discussed during this lecture, but why must we take mu >= 0 here? I'm struggling to understand the arithmetic done on the bottom. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-13T13:16:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-13T13:16:22Z", "content": "

The differential equation comes from Newton's second law (the case of rectilinear motion):

$$ma=F \Rightarrow mx''=-\mu x'-kx+f(t)$$

where $$k$$ is the spring constant and $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of resistance.

The negative sign in front of the term $$\mu x'$$ is necessary because we know that this force (a resistive force like friction or air resistance) opposes motion (given by $$x'$$) instead of helping. To maintain this relationship with motion, it is necessary to take $$\mu\ge0$$, otherwise the term becomes positive and loses its physical meaning (a force in the same direction of motion is not a resistive force).

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltptrk5475e5w0", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltpcnu80pgx6g2", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173679459, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork"], "nr": 770, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-13T15:42:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltpyznyj94545n", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-13T15:42:39Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltq2lpa4wn61p1", "to": "ltpyznxth5j45l", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-13T17:23:46Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltq79mlxu8y73u", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-13T19:34:20Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "data": "ltq7c7ihtp852q", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-13T19:36:21Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WeBWorK 9, Problem 8", "created": "2024-03-13T15:42:39Z", "content": "

I understand that we can solve for B using the sum of a geometric series, but how can we solve for A?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 159, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-13T17:23:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-13T19:36:21Z", "content": "As the question suggests, the infinite series A is in the form of a Taylor series -- this can be made more obvious by replacing $$5$$ with $$x$$: $$\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{(2n)!} = 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-\frac{x^6}{6!}+\cdots$$ So if we can find the function to which the series converges, we can evaluate it at $$x=5$$ to find the value of the series. Hint: consider the Taylor series of the trigonometric functions."}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-13T19:34:20Z", "content": "As the question suggests, the infinite series A is in the form of a Taylor series -- this can be made more obvious by replacing $$5$$ with $$x$$: $$\displaystyle 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-\frac{x^6}{6!}+\cdots +\frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{(2n)!}$$ So if we can find the function to which the series converges, we can evaluate it at $$x=5$$ to find the value of the series. Hint: consider the Taylor series of the trigonometric functions."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-13T17:23:46Z", "content": "

As the question suggests, the integer series A is in the form of a Taylor series -- this can be made more obvious by replacing $$5$$ with $$x$$:

$$\displaystyle 1-\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^4}{4!}-\frac{x^6}{6!}+\cdots +\frac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{(2n!)}$$

So if we can find the function to which the series converges, we can evaluate it at $$x=5$$ to find the value of the series.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul3hccbr41t"], "children": [], "id": "ltq2lp9w7ym1p0", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltpyznxth5j45l", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173681629, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 773, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-13T18:21:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltq4o995a2j3mg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-13T18:21:44Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "data": "ltqllpf2urpt", "to": "ltq4o98xryu3mf", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-14T02:15:38Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WH3 Question 1 Part 3 Characteristic Equation", "created": "2024-03-13T18:21:44Z", "content": "

The question is asking for a general solution $$y_p(t) + y_c(t)$$.

To find find $$y_c(t)$$ we'll need the roots of the characteristic equation $$P(r) = 0$$.

We know $$P(\alpha) = 0$$ but it is unclear if that is a double root or only one of the roots.

After solving for $$y_p(t)$$, as a part of the solution I got two unknown coefficients in front of the $$te^{\alpha t}$$ and $$e^{\alpha t}$$ terms. Lets say $$c_1$$ and $$c_2$$.

For $$y_c(t)$$, I assumed two distinct roots from $$P(\alpha) = 0$$ and had another two unknown coefficients, lets say $$c_3$$ and $$c_4$$, in front of $$e^{r_1t}$$ and $$e^{r_2t}$$. 

When I put them together, the exponentials don't match so I cannot combine the terms together to have only 2 unknown coefficients for my general solution. If $$P(\alpha) = 0$$ was a double root, $$y_c(t)$$ would be in the correct form to be able to combine the unknowns in front of the same terms in the general solution and have only 2 unknowns.

Am I missing something I don't think its good to leave it with 4 unknowns considering this is a second order equation.

Should I assume $$P(\alpha) = 0$$ is a double root? But then what is the point of asking "single solution of the homogenous system" in the previous part. There I assumed $$P(\alpha) = 0$$ was only one of the roots and it was asking for one part of the homogenous solution which corresponded to the root $$\alpha$$.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Boris Potapov", "endorser": {"lq1r9f49qpr3p": 1706191519}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llyhj9awro63lb", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 202, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T02:15:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T02:15:38Z", "content": "You can see whether $$\alpha$$ is a double root or not from the given conditions. What worked for me is that I chose an n0 first, then constructed my general form. I recommend choosing an n0 that we have seen often in examples from lectures and tutorials.

I would look at the relation between the powers of each numerator in the term, and how they relate to your chosen n0, whatever it may be. In this case, that would be 3,6,9,12...

The (x-6) is constant in each term, so it will likely be (x-6) raised to some exponent that is dependent on n. This will give you your numerator.

I would also look at the denominator as a product of two parts that depend on n, for example, it looks like your denominator is some power of an exponential with base 2 (2^0, 2^1, 2^2...), multiplied by a factorial that increases by 1 each term. This should help you write a general form for the denominator that is dependent on n, starting at your chosen n0.

Then combine the general forms of the numerator and denominator.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukdbn6w71pk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T02:19:23Z", "content": "

Let $$ a= \frac{x}{1-x}$$ Case 1: $$a = 1$$ In this case $$a^n$$ = 1 regardless of the value of n. Case 2: $$a > 1$$ In this case $$a^{(n+1)}$$ > $$a^n$$. i.e it is increasing and the limit will tend to infinity. Case 3: $$a < 1$$ In this case $$a^{(n+1)}$$ < $$a^{n}$$. i.e each term is decreasing (eg. $$(0.5)^2$$ < $$(0.5)^{1})$$, and so the limit of this term as n--> $$\infty$$ will be 0."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T16:59:17Z", "content": "There are three possibilities. Let $$ a= \frac{x}{x-1}$$ Case 1: $$a = 1$$ In this case $$a^n$$ = 1 regardless of the value of n. Case 2: $$a > 1$$ In this case $$a^{(n+1)}$$ > $$a^n$$. i.e it is increasing and the limit will tend to infinity. Case 3: $$a < 1$$ In this case $$a^{(n+1)}$$ < $$a^{n}$$. i.e each term is decreasing (eg. $$(0.5)^2$$ < $$(0.5)^{1})$$, and so the limit of this term as n--> $$\infty$$ will be 0."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltrh62o66772y0", "config": {"editor": "plain"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm3jvdndgox4kg"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltqhx9yu4ii7bk", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173689369, "default_anonymity": "no"}

It is a Maclaurin series, so it is centered at x = 0, your sigma notation for f(x) will just be the numerator you have there because you would always substitute x = 0 when finding the constants (Cn) using the derivatives. With your new general form, you can determine the correct interval.

You essentially find the value of the derivatives at x = 0, you do not keep the general derivative for all x in your polynomial, which is what you have here, use the derivatives to find the constants:

Zero is the "a" value, or your center of approximation. The x in the numerator is where you would substitute the x in f(x).

When you arrive at a limit of the form $$\lim\limits_{t\to 0}\frac{A}{t}$$ where $$A\in\mathbb{R}^*$$, you need to take limits on each side (i.e. $$\lim\limits_{t\to0^+}$$ and $$\lim\limits_{t\to0^-}$$).

EDIT : It may be easier to not use limit properties to split up the function. Two of the three terms in the function have the same denominator so you can easily turn the entire function into one rational function.

EDIT 2: Just use L'Hopitals rule to be safe. No need to split the limit, that causes unneccessary work.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llyi2597g6x21b", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T15:43:41Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0102"], "nr": 784, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T15:00:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltrcwscpovm6z4", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-14T15:00:05Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltrehvv57nl1ey", "to": "ltrcwscfzkq6z2", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-14T15:44:29Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltrf1fv0h2g1qr", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-14T15:59:41Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltrcwscfzkq6z2", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-14T16:08:06Z", "cid": "ltrfc8utlj07h0", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "ltrcwscfzkq6z2", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-14T16:44:04Z", "cid": "ltrgmimbf7v3lz"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "to": "ltrcwscfzkq6z2", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-14T20:55:54Z", "cid": "ltrpmdf26sp38p"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Series convergence question.", "created": "2024-03-14T15:00:05Z", "content": "In PCE E2 (please correct me if I\u2019m wrong) I think it states that if the partial sum of an infinite series converges, we know that the infinite series converges.\u00a0

Why is this true?\u00a0
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0102", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 109, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T15:44:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Matthew Desmarais", "endorser": {"k3t0tl7krg32to": 1579115969, "k52y9qu3rg41mr": 1584116403, "global": 1587066490, "k38wsyi5wxb1hz": 1587254389, "ktdwmksib25673": 1634571238, "kt03zgk52gf2vz": 1634684358}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T15:59:41Z", "content": "

This fact follows from the definition; an infinite sum is said to converge if $$\\lim\\limits_{k\\to\\infty}\\sum_{n=1}^k a_n$$ (the sequence of partial sums). In other words, an "infinite sum" refers to this limit, not a "process" of repeating addition.

\n

\n

We use this definition because it's impossible (usually) to talk directly about infinity; as you can't reach it by counting normally, it is difficult to have any intuition about it. (I will expand this discussion later)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T15:44:29Z", "content": "This fact follows from the definition; an infinite sum is said to converge if $$\\lim\\limits_{k\\to\\infty}\\sum_{n=1}^k a_n$$ (the sequence of partial sums). In other words, an "infinite sum" refers to this limit, not a "process" of repeating addition."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["k07ghb5kyi669r"], "children": [], "id": "ltrehvuy1pu1ex", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "So would it be fair to say that the partial sum must converge because it is part of an infinite series that is also converging?\u00a0", "created": "2024-03-14T16:08:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": ""Convergence" doesn't make sense for a single partial sum (because each partial sum is an arithmetic expression and not a sequence), the word only applies in the context of a sequence of partial sums.\u00a0", "created": "2024-03-14T16:44:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltrgmimbf7v3lz", "updated": "2024-03-14T16:44:05Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "It should be the other way around - an infinite series converges if and only if the limit of its partial sums exist and converges.", "created": "2024-03-14T20:55:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lmjlbpox6863z", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltrpmdf26sp38p", "updated": "2024-03-14T20:55:54Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltrfc8utlj07h0", "updated": "2024-03-14T21:03:18Z", "config": {}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltrcwscfzkq6z2", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173696970, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0102"], "nr": 785, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T15:31:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltre143rmyc4i9", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-14T15:31:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "data": "ltrp8wik7n94wk", "to": "ltre143j56l4i6", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-14T20:45:26Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "data": "ltrp9ddrhtg5r2", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-14T20:45:48Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "data": "ltrpaa0jylf7mc", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-14T20:46:30Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "data": "ltrpao2a2l7ni", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-14T20:46:48Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "data": "ltrpbijw3tj2cb", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-14T20:47:28Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Taylor Series Convergence and Divergence Question", "created": "2024-03-14T15:31:27Z", "content": "Hi, I’m currently trying to learn why a Taylor series converges or diverges depending on its x-value and I’m having trouble doing so. 

My current understanding is that when looking at the taylor series of the form: IMG_6315_2024_03_14.jpeg

By altering x and a we are “changing” the infinite series to something that will either converge or diverge. 

I can’t help but wonder if there’s a better way of thinking about it. Is there? If so, what is it?

Looking forward to anyone's help on this!"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 161, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-15T02:51:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljqx8dmbfuv1a2", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-15T02:51:07Z", "content": "You are correct. For the D3 slides lec 103, I'm struggling to understand what exactly is going on in this image. Could someone explain/lead me through it? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Panos Triantafillopoulos", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk57b6vqw0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T20:53:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T20:53:36Z", "content": "

They first find the expression for x(t) from the characteristic polynomial, and it's $$\cos((a / \sqrt{m}) t)$$. To see what happens when they increase the mass, they increase m in that formula and see that it slows down the oscillation. Then they give a kind of physical interpretation, the idea that mass increases inertia and that's why it happens.

Then they change a in a similar way, and see that it increases instead, and gives a physical interpretation too, a stiffer spring moves faster.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["written_homework"], "nr": 813, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T22:06:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltun135n5dd6uw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T22:06:40Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgc33a41zw", "data": "lturjs9tdki1bh", "to": "ltun135fcli6uv", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T00:13:11Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Written homework question 3 part 2 - closed form", "created": "2024-03-16T22:06:40Z", "content": "I was wondering how we're supposed to use Pn(x) - xPn(x) to find a closed form for Pn(x). "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "written_homework"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Kia Salehzadeh", "endorser": {"lr51f0oibsv66y": 1705011281}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk2nchjopf", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Nivin Khan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukz2nk5k3ly", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T00:13:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David Basil", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgc33a41zw", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T00:13:11Z", "content": "

That is the process to find the closed form. In other words Pn(x) - xPn(x) = [insert telescoping series here]

Then you can isolate for Pn(x) on the LHS, yielding the closed form of Pn(x) on the RHS.  

Start by finding what Pn(x) is in terms of a series.

In my opinion:

1) Use WeBWork to practice computation and the actual solving the math.

2) Make sure you understand the tutorial questions, low key some of them are very cracked, and I like the solutions because they inherently force you to understand why you apply some of the topics and theorems rather than just plug and chug.

3) There's almost always a question from the homework or something very similar to it, so make sure you understand the process and the reasoning behind the homework solutions.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 816, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T22:47:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltuohumocsq6lo", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T22:47:42Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgc33a41zw", "data": "lturfnwylrf2nv", "to": "ltuohumgtsv6ln", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T00:09:59Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Radius of Convergence Inquiry", "created": "2024-03-16T22:47:42Z", "content": "

When we solve for the radius of convergence for a given series, we use the ratio test: $$\displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}$$. In LEC0102, we did this example:

Find the radius of convergence for the series $$\displaystyle\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^n}{n!}$$

When we do the ratio test: $$\displaystyle\frac{\frac{x\cdot x^n}{(n+1)!\cdot n}}{\frac{x^n}{n!}}$$ which becomes:

$$\displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{x}{n+1}$$ which we say that the limit goes to zero. 

So in this case, do we say that the series converges for every value of $$x$$, and that the interval of convergence is $$(-\infty,\infty)$$?

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 66, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T00:09:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Arnav Patil", "endorser": {"lr1jp5yrvb87hx": 1705601206, "lqck4qp2w431en": 1705978254, "lr51f0oibsv66y": 1706063144, "global": 1706297902, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1707154262, "lqxwl2o378b5ny": 1708145491}, "admin": false, "photo": "8de4a73f-ce91-41e2-a074-63d6d3fa9d5f_200.jpg", "id": "llyi7s8ecap62t", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/llyi7s8ecap62t/8de4a73f-ce91-41e2-a074-63d6d3fa9d5f_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Warrick Tsui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukyklcmy3k9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "David Basil", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukgc33a41zw", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T00:09:59Z", "content": "Yes. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 821, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T00:28:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltus30r743k5oy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-17T00:28:09Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "data": "ltvssk35m3543v", "to": "ltus30r0qcv5ow", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T17:35:46Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Approximating error using Taylor's Remainder Theorem", "created": "2024-03-17T00:28:09Z", "content": "I stumbled upon this question in 2021 Test 4: ![session-attachment-2024-03-16-201411.jpeg](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fllyhj9awro63lb%2F81859332ddbe241edf66f689a83a5fa52abf2ee986511b28de9a98adc0798e94%2Fsession-attachment-2024-03-16-201411.jpeg) To approach this I decided to take $$p_2(t)$$ as the approximation and use $$R_2(t)$$ together with $$g'''(t)$$ to narrow down the error boundary. However I am not sure how to properly utilize the given boundaries for $$g'''(x)$$. Since there are two distinct restrictions on $$g'''(x)$$, I am calculating two $$R_2(t)$$'s and see for which one I get smaller $$t^*$$ in $$p_2(t^*)+R_2(t^*)>0$$. Is my process correct?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Pakhi Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukk98e6a2c1", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 76, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T17:35:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Boris Potapov", "endorser": {"lq1r9f49qpr3p": 1706191519}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llyhj9awro63lb", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "David Basil", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T17:35:46Z", "content": "

it's there to help you find $$R(x)$$, since you need the maximum absolute value of the third derivative on the interval between the center and approximated point. since the absolute value reaches up to 6 between $$[1,t]$$, you should use that as the value for $$f(z)$$. I believe the 2 is simply there to throw you off if you take the maximum regular value instead of absolute.

if you check both though, you'll find the error of 6 is larger, so I guess it still works, but is not necessary.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tutorials"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 65, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T04:54:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David Basil", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T04:54:04Z", "content": "12 m/s\u00b2 is an upper bound for the absolute value of the third derivative, but it is not the upper bound for the remainder. Therefore, because |s\u2019\u2019\u2019(t)| < 12, then |s\u2019\u2019\u2019(c)|t\u00b3 /3! < 12t\u00b3/3!

Hope this makes sense.\u00a0
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kevjvelwj8x73e"], "children": [], "id": "ltv1kzo6v6p453", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Yes, but why is it less than or equal to, rather than only less than?", "created": "2024-03-17T06:51:38Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I think this is because\u00a0
if you look at the remainder theorem, M >= f^(n+1)(c), where f^(n+1)(c) is 12 m/s. It says that M should be greater or equal to f^(n+1)(c). Since the question explicitely told us that s'''(t) it stays below 12 m/s, we can let M = 12 m/s. You are finding the upper bound here, so doesn't really matter if the question states it is less than or less than or equal to. both are for the same reason. if a sinusoidal function from a second order ODE increases or decreases, it needs to do so exponentially in a way similar to $$e^x$$ since that's the "real part" that scales the rest of the function. when $$e^x$$ decreases, it decreases more at the beginning and approaches zero asymptotically. when it increases, it grows exponentially.

knowing this, we can see that A does not approach the x-axis asymptotically like $$e^{-kx}$$, and D increases linearly, which is impossible to create with $$e^{kx}$$.

the $$\frac{1}{2}$$ comes from substituting $$x=1.5$$. moving this to the denominator yields a 2 instead.

$$c=1$$ because all derivatives of $$\ln$$ are decreasing, so the lowest value of x on the interval is guaranteed to be the highest.
