"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T18:33:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Aadavan Vasudevan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukt2fxpd31m", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "David Basil", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T18:33:41Z", "content": "There is a pretty clever geometric interpretation of this series that might be easier to visualize the series 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + ... Start by drawing a square. Draw a single line that cuts the square in half, keep 1/2. Take the other half and slice it in half, keep 1/4. You'll notice that as you iterate these steps, the sum of all the sections 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + ... approaches the size of the entire box. You've just shown that 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + ... = 1. Here's a post online that may help. https://www.quora.com/How-does-1-2-1-4-1-8-1-16-till-infinity-have-a-sum-2"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukt2fxpd31m", "kevjvelwj8x73e"], "children": [], "id": "ltvuv12g1l6bv", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltvu5jsh3mw5t6", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173751239, "default_anonymity": "no"}

In that case, I'm just getting that sin(x^3) can be approximated solely as x^9. Is this right and if it isn't, what methodology could be used to find the answer for this? Looking forward to anyone's help on this!"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 88, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "You have to find the Taylor Polynomial of $$\\sin(x^3)$$, which is entirely different from that of just $$\\sin x$$. Note that this is because $$f^{(n)}(x)$$ differs for both functions due to the chain rule, so the Taylor polynomials will be different.

Also, suppose that $$x$$ is large (like a million) and $$P_n(x)$$ approximates $$f$$ very well near $$x=\\text{\u201cone million\u201d}$$. Then $$\\sin x^3$$ will be small but $$x^9$$ will be very large. Therefore, given that $$P_n(x)$$ will always approximate $$f$$ very well (because the Taylor series converges everywhere) it should make intuitive sense that $$\\sin x^3$$ does not give a good approximation of $$x^9$$ (and vice versa) at least for large $$x$$.
", "created": "2024-03-17T18:49:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "How would you proceed with finding the ninth-degree Taylor polynomial? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Gawtham Senthilvelan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul1owgej3ug", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 69, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T17:19:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David Basil", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7uk89v8yl1an", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T17:19:28Z", "content": "the equilibrium solution occurs where $$y'(t)=y''(t)=\\dots=0$$. if you derive the solution you got, the only way to make this happen is when $$c_1=c_2=0$$, since this eliminates the $$t$$ terms. that leaves you with $$y=\\frac{mg}{k}$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kevjvelwj8x73e"], "children": [], "id": "ltx7nfor5hw3dh", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ul1owgej3ug"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltvv11xgpf52pe", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173753408, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 841, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T19:58:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "data": "ltvxwi9tion6tv", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-17T19:58:49Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "ltxbm7vjza35xo", "to": "ltvxwi7pjg6tt", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T19:10:29Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "subject": "neglecting gravity when taking extension from equilibrium and external force", "created": "2024-03-17T19:58:49Z", "content": "

when we take x and extension from the equilibrium position of a vertical spring, we do not have to include the force of gravity as shown by this explanation from the textbook.

Does this also apply in the case that there is an external force (like if there is a drag coefficient or the right side does not equal 0)?

To me, it makes sense that gravity can still be neglected since it's already considered in the equilibrium position.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Warrick Tsui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukyklcmy3k9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 56, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T19:10:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sunny Wu", "endorser": {"ljajlq9tev95ta": 1690215730, "global": 1693234144, "llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699679968}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljrlqru2ii55a3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T19:10:29Z", "content": "

You can treat the force from gravity in two different ways. 

1) You can think of a vertical spring without the mass, and call the equilibrium of that system zero. Then add the mass and treat the new force $$mg$$ you introduced as an external force. In this case, your new equilibrium (equilibrium with the mass) is not at the zero anymore. 


2) Alternatively, you can think of the mass as part of the system and set the equilibrium with the mass as zero. In this case, the gravity force is already taken into account when you write your ODE. 

The difference between (1) and (2) is a change of variable. Note that you could do this because the force of gravity is constant and is applied uniformly. You can argue similarly for any other "external" constant force. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljrlqru2ii55a3"], "children": [], "id": "ltxbm7vcxas5xn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukyklcmy3k9"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltvxwi7pjg6tt", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173758828, "default_anonymity": "no"}

true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T15:12:00Z", "content": "

A function $$f$$ is bounded if there exists a number $$M\in\mathbb{R}$$ where $$|f(x)|\le M$$ for all $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$; that is, the function is never farther from axis $$x$$ than $$M$$. So a function $$g$$ is not bounded if for all $$M\in\mathbb{R}$$ we can find $$c\in\mathbb{R}$$ where $$|f(c)|> M$$; in other words the function tends to infinity.

So we can think of this question as asking us to find $$f(t)$$ for which the solution to the differential equation tends to infinity.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["webwork"], "nr": 866, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T03:37:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltweac564kp69j", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T03:37:28Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "ltx24bwv6t073g", "to": "ltweac4yalb69i", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T14:44:38Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Mass Spring ODE", "created": "2024-03-18T03:37:28Z", "content": "

\n

\n

I am confused about the directions of the ODE. When Fspring is in the process of restoring the mass to equilibrium, isnt the damping force against the direction of motion? So kx should be negative to damping constant*x'?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brian Tobing", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk5qionkxj", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 71, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T14:44:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T14:44:38Z", "content": "The damping force works against the direction of motion, yes, so it'll be $$-2x'$$, but then the restoring force works against the displacement, so $$-5x$$. But then we bring both to the other side and they're both positive.

Or to put it another way, they do have different signs. If you're farther out than the equilibrium point and we're restoring to that, $$x$$ is positive, and the direction of motion, $$x'$$ is negative. So, $$2x'$$ is negative and $$5x$$ is positive, so they do have different signs."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltx24bwmnd073e", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7uk5qionkxj"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltweac4yalb69i", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173785955, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0101", "lectures_section0102", "lectures_section0103", "exam"], "nr": 871, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T05:13:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltwhpjyhfc7w0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T05:13:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "ltx1enr3sx32ud", "to": "ltwhpjy9aipvz", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T14:24:41Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question regarding radius of convergence from lecture", "created": "2024-03-18T05:13:17Z", "content": "

From the question below, we know with context that from a centre of -2, it has at least a radius of convergence of 4. However, we don't know for a fact if the x-value at exactly 4 away, so x=2, and x=-6, will converge, since at these two points L is potentially 1. However, since we know x=2 converges, don't we also know that x=-6 is also inclusive?

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "lectures_section0101", "lectures_section0102", "lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T14:24:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Kabir Guron", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm181ffy1vrff", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Rocklen Jeong", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uktgeon332e", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T14:24:41Z", "content": "Not necessarily, an interval of convergence may include only one endpoint"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm181ffy1vrff", "lm7uktgeon332e"], "children": [], "id": "ltx1enqwfke2uc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltwhpjy9aipvz", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173791383, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 69, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T14:38:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T15:01:58Z", "content": "

From the graph, we can get a sense of the period, from which we should be able to discern beta.

The characteristic equation is $$r^2 + \alpha^2 = 0$$


As a result, we can find an expression for the solution, which I think will have $$\beta$$ being $$\sqrt{\alpha}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T14:38:47Z", "content": "

From the graph, we can get a sense of the period, from which we should be able to discern beta.

The characteristic equation is $$r^2 + \alpha = 0$$


As a result, we can find an expression for the solution, which I think will have $$\beta$$ being $$\sqrt{\alpha}$$

Taking n = 4 will mean that the Remainder Estimation Theorem will use the 5th derivative, which provides a larger interval for the value of x where the error is within the required accuracy. Taking n = 3 and subsequently using the 4th derivative in the Remainder Estimation Theorem will yield a smaller interval.

If you're interested in actual proof with numbers, you can check out Tutorial 8 Question 4. There, they have actual calculations that show that taking a higher value of n will give a larger interval where the error will not exceed a certain amount.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tutorials"], "nr": 876, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T07:06:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltwlrd3rn9c4ka", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T07:06:40Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltwmic6npq72ve", "to": "ltwlrd3jub14k9", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T07:27:38Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "ltx193brllm2dc", "to": "ltwlrd3jub14k9", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T14:20:21Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltx2kqos5gz3uk", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-18T14:57:24Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Tutorial 8 Q2", "created": "2024-03-18T07:06:40Z", "content": "

Hi there, I am wondering about question 2 part a. In the solution, how does it change from 1/n - 1/(n+1) into 1 - 1/(n+1)?

And if I remember correctly, telescoping series are discussed in the lectures, so if someone could tell me which lecture slide talks about telescoping series, that would be useful as well.

Thank you in advance.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tutorials"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 73, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T07:27:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wilbert Budhy Wibowo", "endorser": {"lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1710771645}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul7s687n4fe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T14:57:24Z", "content": "

(Le traducteur s'est cassé et c'est trop tard pour essayer le réparer maintenant, mais je traduirai cette réponse au matin.)

The change follows from the formula for the value of a telescopic series : $$\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left(a_n-a_{n+1}\right) = a_0-\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}a_n$$. In this case $$a_n=\frac{1}{n} \implies a_{n+1}=\frac{1}{n+1}$$, so the formula gives us $$\frac{1}{1}-\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}=1-0=1$$.

To your second question I can't find the exact slide where the formula is discussed, but the proof is simple using induction.

Let $$a_p$$ be a real sequence and $$S_n=\sum^n_{m=1} a_m-a_{m+1}$$ a sequence of partial sums. We want to show that $$S_n=a_1-a_{n+1}$$ pour tout $$n\in\mathbb{N}$$.

For the base case, suppose that $$n=2$$. It follows that $$S_n=a_1-a_2+a_2-a_3=a_1-a_3=a_1-a_{n+1}$$.

For induction, suppose que $$S_k=a_1-a_{k+1}$$. Notice that $$S_{k+1}=\sum_{m=1}^{k+1}a_m-a_{m+1}=\sum_{m=1}^{k}\left[a_m-a_{m+1}\right]+a_{k+1}-a_{k+2}=S_k+a_{k+1}-a_{k+2}$$. By induction hypothesis we deduce that $$S_{k+1}=a_1-a_{k+1}+a_{k+1}-a_{k+2}=a_1-a_{k+2}$$.

By induction, we deduce that $$S_n=a_1-a_{n+1}$$ for all $$n\in\mathbb{N}$$. $$\blacksquare$$

From here it's easy (take a limit) to demonstrate the case where $$n\to\infty$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T07:27:38Z", "content": "

(Le traducteur s'est cassé et c'est trop tard pour essayer le réparer maintenant, mais je traduirai cette réponse au matin.)

Le changement suit de la formule pour le valeur d'une série télescopique : $$\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left(a_n-a_{n+1}\right) = a_0-\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}a_n$$. En ce cas on à $$a_n=\frac{1}{n} \implies a_{n+1}=\frac{1}{n+1}$$, donc le formule nous donne $$\frac{1}{1}-\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}=1-0=1$$.

À votre deuxième question je ne trouve plus la diapositive exacte où on discute la formule, mais la démonstration est simple en utilisant la raisonnement par récurrence.

Soient $$a_p$$ une série réel et $$S_n=\sum^n_{m=1} a_m-a_{m+1}$$ une série des sommes partielles. On veut démontrer que $$S_n=a_1-a_{n+1}$$ pour tout $$n\in\mathbb{N}$$.

Pour l'initialisation, suppose que $$n=2$$. Il suit que $$S_n=a_1-a_2+a_2-a_3=a_1-a_3=a_1-a_{n+1}$$.

Pour l'hérédité, suppose que $$S_k=a_1-a_{k+1}$$. On note que $$S_{k+1}=\sum_{m=1}^{k+1}a_m-a_{m+1}=\sum_{m=1}^{k}\left[a_m-a_{m+1}\right]+a_{k+1}-a_{k+2}=S_k+a_{k+1}-a_{k+2}$$. Par l'hypothèse on déduit que $$S_{k+1}=a_1-a_{k+1}+a_{k+1}-a_{k+2}=a_1-a_{k+2}$$.

Par raisonnement par récurrence, on déduit que $$S_n=a_1-a_{n+1}$$ pour tout $$n\in\mathbb{N}$$. $$\blacksquare$$

D'ici il est simple (prend une limite) de démontrer le cas où $$n\to\infty$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul7s687n4fe"], "children": [], "id": "ltwmic6e3ec2vd", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T14:20:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wilbert Budhy Wibowo", "endorser": {"lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1710771645}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul7s687n4fe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T14:20:21Z", "content": "This is probably what the student answer's getting at, but $$1/n - 1/(n+1)$$ is a telescoping series. That is, most of the terms cancel out. At term $$x$$ it's $$\frac{1}{x} - \frac{1}{x+1}$$ and at the next term it's $$\frac{1}{x+1} - \frac{1}{x+2}$$ so the $$\frac{1}{x+1}$$ term gets cancelled out. So, when we look at the whole series, the only thing that doesn't get cancelled out is the first and 'last' term. The first term is 1, and the 'last' term is the limit of -1/(n+1) as n goes to infinity"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul7s687n4fe"], "children": [], "id": "ltx193bmr32da", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltwlrd3jub14k9", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173796809, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["lectures_section0103"], "nr": 881, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T14:57:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltx2kn5mjnt3xd", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T14:57:19Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltx2ltkbk905qt", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-03-18T14:58:14Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "data": "ltxiin4esvf6be", "to": "ltx2kn5c2ai3xc", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T22:23:40Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "E3 part II question", "created": "2024-03-18T14:58:14Z", "content": "

In lecture E3 part II, slide 3 has a question that asks about finding $$R_{n}(\frac{1}{4})$$. For the 3rd part of the question, I'm confused about how they found the expression for $$R_{n}$$. I'm unable to derive it using the remainder theorem. Could someone please explain? The first picture below is of the part I'm confused about (part 3), and the second picture shows the function, the nth derivative, and the nth remainder that was derived previously. Thank you!

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "E3 part II question", "created": "2024-03-18T14:57:19Z", "content": "

In lecture E3 part II, the very last question asks about finding $$R_{n}(\frac{1}{4})$$. For the 3rd part of the question, I'm confused about how they found the expression for $$R_{n}$$. I'm unable to derive it using the remainder theorem. Could someone please explain? The first picture below is of the part I'm confused about (part 3), and the second picture shows the function, the nth derivative, and the nth remainder that was derived previously. Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T22:23:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kevjvelwj8x73e", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T22:23:40Z", "content": "

Take $$\frac{1}{1-x}$$ and take derivatives of it. You get that first blue box in the second question, where for the $$n^{th}$$ derivative, you have $$n!/(1-x)^{n+1}$$, because with the chain rule we take down the power and multiply it by the derivative of the "inside" (in this case, the derivative of (1-x) is negative one) and there we go.

So, then we see at the bottom what happens if you substitute that, evaluated at c, in for the $$f^{(n+1)}$$ on the top of the remainder formula. But if you sub in the derivative evaluated at x instead of at c, you get what you see here.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltxiin46kht6bd", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltx2kn5c2ai3xc", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173802237, "default_anonymity": "no"}

1/ The way I see it is (a) does not resemble an exponential decay. B seems like e^-x zoomed out, and C is obviously decaying rapidly. A does not resemble any of those traits. 

2/ I am unsure what you are confused about here. The ODE they provided does not resemble a damped oscillator (implying limit must be zero). And it does resemble a homogenous ODE solution (in fact you can easily solve it and see its solutions). The reason the answers differ from part (a) and (b) is because the conditions are different. 

3/ Since there is no external force and a dampening effect (consider friction or air resistance) you are losing energy from the system. Which will ultimately cause the system to end up at =0.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0101"], "nr": 890, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T17:46:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltx8mr9w4dj7bc", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T17:46:56Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltxalamyxg1ij", "to": "ltx8mr9l4p17bb", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T18:41:47Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lecture Notes D3-2 part 2", "created": "2024-03-18T17:46:56Z", "content": "How would one approach this problem?
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 56, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T18:41:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Toon Craps", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1700667274, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1709259422}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukr1754d2wl", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T18:41:47Z", "content": "

The characteristic polynomial of the homogeneous system for this problem is $$r^2+2r+5$$; we can show that its zeros are equal to $$r=-1\\pm 4i$$. Thus the complementary solution $$y_c(t)=e^{-t}\\left(c_1\\cos(4t)+c_2\\sin(4t)\\right)$$ where $$c_1,c_2\\in\\mathbb{R}$$ are constants.

\n

\n

When we take $$t\\to\\infty$$ the equation of which $$y(t)$$ is the solution becomes $$y''+2y'+5y=0$$ because $$f(t)=0$$ when $$t>1$$. From our previous calculations we know that $$y(t)=y_c(t)=e^{-t}\\left(c_1\\cos(4t)+c_2\\sin(4t)\\right)$$ (because the system is now homogeneous). From here we can take the limit to determine $$\\lim\\limits_{t\\to\\infty} y(t)$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ukr1754d2wl"], "children": [], "id": "ltxalamr15s1ih", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltx8mr9l4p17bb", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173812005, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 896, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T19:11:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltxbnsi5uk26l8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T19:11:43Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltxcijrzyv82fu", "to": "ltxbnshwn6j6l7", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T19:35:38Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltxcjcoghpz4ac", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-18T19:36:15Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltxcjo7qjkb4z9", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-18T19:36:30Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "ltxcks5x3lw7ha", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-18T19:37:22Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Convergence", "created": "2024-03-18T19:11:43Z", "content": "
From what I am gathering, they say that the series converges (by alternating series).

But the <sigma>1/sqrt(n) diverges (by p-series).

So they said it converges conditionally.
I dont quite understand this; could somebody explain the logic to me? Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T19:35:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T19:37:22Z", "content": "

It depends on when you are considering the absolute value, and when you are considering with sign. 

If you notice that it converges via alternating series (where you consider the sign alternating).

You have to do another test considering the absolute (assume the sign does not alternate). If the absolute value diverges, you state the series converges conditionally. 

If your first test states it diverges, you do not need to analyze further. And if both converge, then you can state it converges absolutely. Since absolute convergence is "stronger".

Best bet is to try to mimic the function on the RHS.

Quick tips:
> if RHS has an exponential, your function should have the same exponential
> if RHS is a polynomial of degree $$n$$. Your functions lowest order derivative (usually $$y$$ or $$y'$$) should have a polynomial term of degree $$n$$
> if a guess for $$y_p$$ gave you something like $$0 = 0$$ or $$1 = 1$$, try to multiply your current guess with $$t$$. (if $$y_p(t)=\sin{t} \rightarrow y_p(t)=t\sin{t} $$). This may help.

Here is a quick cheet sheet that can help you get an idea:
     RHS (example)                                                Guess [ $$y_p(t) = ...$$ ]
            $$1 $$                                                                            $$A$$ 

            $$6t +7 $$                                                                  $$Ax+B$$

            $$t^2 + 5t - 12$$                                                       $$Ax^2 + Bx + C$$

            $$\sin{3t} $$                                                                     $$A\cos{3t} + B\sin{3t}$$

            $$\cos{4t} $$                                                                    $$A\cos{4t} + B\sin{4t}$$

            $$2e^{5t}$$                                                                       $$Ae^{5t}$$

            $$(9t+2)e^{-2t}$$                                                      $$(Ax+B)e^{-2t}$$
            $$(4t^2+2)e^{-t}$$                                                      $$(At^2+Bt+C)e^{-t}$$

            $$e^{t}\sin{2t}$$                                                                $$Ae^{t}\cos{2t}+Be^{t}\sin{2t}$$

            $$t^2\sin{4t}$$                $$(At^2+Bt+C)\cos{4t} + (Dt^2+Et+F)\sin{4t}$$

            $$te^{5t}\cos{6t}$$                            $$(At+B)e^{5t}\cos{6t} + (Ct+D)e^{5t}\sin{6t}$$

I think you get the gist. These are not full proof. These assume a linear ODE like $$c_1y''+c_2y'+c_3y=g(t)$$. These don't mention the solution for $$y_c(t)$$. All of these factors can affect what your guess for $$y_p$$ should be. 

Best thing to do is try to match/copy $$g(t)$$ in the most general sense as possible. But don't forget to make observations and guess accordingly.

I am still having issues with directions even after reading through a few piazza posts. 

it seems to me that everytime when a mass spring system is horizontal, it comes out as:

F=ma=-uv-kx

ma+uv+kx= external force. (The point is that every term ends up being positive, is this always the case ?

Also, for mass spring with gravity:

F=ma=-uv

ma+uv = mg (gravity is treated as external force) ( is this also the usual case for this kind of system?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brian Tobing", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk5qionkxj", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Will Nakatsu McCoy", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f0775a5r6op", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 82, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T22:23:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brian Tobing", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk5qionkxj", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vanessa Field", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lk8wg65xh3c3qq", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T22:28:07Z", "content": "I believe you should just think about it a certain way and stick with it for all spring questions. If you think about a spring going horizontally (no gravity). define that the mass going to the right is positive displacement. Notice how when the spring moves to the right, the spring is going to stretch out and result in a force in the opposite direction. Therefore because we can say that the spring force will act in the opposite direction when the mass goes in the positive direction, we have to put a negative sign for the spring force. Therefore we currently have ma = -kx. Say we have an external force, F, we can say that the direction of the force is out defined positive, and just imagine which way our mass will be pushed (if the spring would compress it would push to the other side and if its stretched, it would pull the mass towards itself). Generally, our force would cause the spring to stretch, and so we would have the ODE, ma = F - kx as the force acts one way but the spring acts the other way. Say we have gravity now. In this scenario the mass spring system is moving up and down (vertically). I believe it is easier to imagine the weight as the positive direction. If you release the block from rest, the block will go down (because of the weight force which we defined to be positive) and the spring will clearly want to bring the mass back up, so the spring will be negative (as it is bringing the mass in the opposite direction of the weight). Therefore we would have ma = mg - kx. "}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "l79f0775a5r6op", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T22:23:00Z", "content": "I think that since x(T) outputs displacement in a direction, the direction of the: spring force, and damping force will be given by the sign of x(T) and x’(T) output. 

Cannot confirm yet though, still a theory.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 910, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T23:33:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltxl0ft19rm3cy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T23:33:29Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lk8y3scxjzg7f8", "data": "ltxmpedhx5b7og", "to": "ltxl0fsrf5a3cx", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-19T00:20:54Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2023 Midterm Part A c)", "created": "2024-03-18T23:33:29Z", "content": "

for part c)

what would be the guess I would make for the ODE given in the question: y'' + y = cos(3t) + 3cos(t)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 120, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-19T00:20:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lk8y3scxjzg7f8", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T00:20:54Z", "content": "

I think you can guess yp= Acos(3t)+ Btsin(t). 

because for cos(3t), you can guess yp= Acos(3t) since cos(3t) has a different frequency from the homogeneous system (y''+y=0); for 3cos(t) you can guess yp= Btsin(t) since 3cos(t) has the same frequency as the homogeneous system; and the sum of those can be your yp for cos(3t) + 3cos(t). 

I solved this and got A=-1/8, B=3/2. hope this helps

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltxmped93ej7of", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltxl0fsrf5a3cx", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173833738, "default_anonymity": "no"}

You don't really need to solve the equation to be honest. You can look for quick evidence without calculations to eliminate possible answers.


1) Initially look at the homogenous equation, $$y''+y =0$$. The characteristice equation would be $$r^2+1 = 0$$ which gives $$r \in \mathbb{C}$$. So you won't have any real exponential in your solution, they'll be in the form of $$c_1\cos{t}+c_2\sin{t}$$. This eliminates options 1 and 2

2) Back to the non-homogenous equation, looking at option 4, there are two peculiar terms. $$c_2\sin{t}$$ and $$\frac{3}{2}\sin{t}$$. For the general solution why would they be given separately when the $$\frac{3}{2}$$ could easily be swallowed into the $$c_2$$? This is not very rigorous but the notation is at best wonky.

For a more rigorous evidence, look at option 4 again. If that is a sole $$\sin{t}$$ term, both $$y$$ and $$y''$$ will only have $$\sin{t}$$ terms. We need the $$t$$ in front of the $$\sin{t}$$ so that $$y''$$ can have a $$\cos{t}$$ term.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm0kpte55ju7fs", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T02:11:50Z", "content": "

You don't really need to solve the equation to be honest. You can look for quick evidence without calculations to eliminate possible answers.


1) Initially look at the homogenous equation, $$y''+y =0$$. The characteristice equation would be $$r^2+1 = 0$$ which gives $$r \in \mathbb{C}$$. So you won't have any real exponential in your solution, they'll be in the form of $$c_1\cos{t}+c_2\sin{t}$$. This eliminates options 1 and 2

2) Back to the non-homogenous equation, looking at option 4, there are two peculiar terms. $$c_2\sin{t}$$ and $$\frac{3}{2}\sin{t}$$. For the general solution why would they be given separately when the $$\frac{3}{2}$$ could easily be swallowed into the $$c_2$$? This is not very rigorous but the notation is at best wonky.

For a more rigorous evidence, look at option 4 again. If that is a sole $$\sin{t}$$ term, both $$y$$ and $$y''$$ will only have $$\sin{t}$$ terms. We need the $$t$$ in front of the $$\sin{t}$$ so that $$y''$$ can have a $$\cos{t}$$ term.

Though, I still don’t really get why there is an additional t. I figured it’s because of the repetitive roots like if the roots are 4/5 and 4/5 then it would be C1e^rt + C2*t*e^rt, so I thought this is that case. Am I missing on something important? Immediately upon seeing it, we know it should be Acost + Bsint. In what case would it be Acost + tBsint or tAcost + Bsint? The t just seems arbitrary to me. Even without solving for A and B, I know it is either 3/4th choice but no knowing why the t is there means I can’t even eliminate 4.", "created": "2024-03-19T02:57:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

For the non-homogenous solution, you can split the $$\cos{3t} + 3\cos{t}$$ into two equaitons and sum them up to get a general $$y_p$$

1) $$y_{p_1}'' + y_{p_1} = \cos{3t}$$

2) $$y_{p_2}'' + y_{p_2} = 3\cos{t}$$

$$y_p(t) = y_{p_1}(t) + y_{p_2}(t)$$

For 1) you can guess $$y_{p_1}(t) = A\cos{3t}+B\sin{3t}$$ as this would not be the same as your guess for $$y_c(t)$$. Solving this gets you $$y_{p_1}(t) = -\frac{1}{8}\cos{3t}$$

For 2) you can't guess $$y_{p_2}(t) = A\cos{t}+B\sin{t}$$ because this would be the same as your $$y_c(t)$$ guess. Thus you need to make it different from $$y_c(t)$$. Because of this you tack on a $$t$$ on both and make your guess as $$y_{p_2}(t) = At\cos{t}+Bt\sin{t}$$. Solving this gets you $$y_{p_2}(t) = \frac{3}{2}t\sin{t}$$

Combining them $$y_p(t) = -\frac{1}{8}\cos{3t} + \frac{3}{2}t\sin{t}$$
Include your homogeneous solution too and you'll get your general solution.

The reason to add the $$t$$ is similar to when a characteristic polynomial has a double root. You get your solution as $$y = c_1e^{\alpha t} + c_2te^{\alpha t}$$ and not $$y = c_1e^{\alpha t} + c_2e^{\alpha t}$$ as that is equivalent to $$y = c_1e^{\alpha t}$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 922, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-19T03:06:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltxslsx7ui75m7", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-19T03:06:04Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltxt9hm7x9o37a", "to": "ltxslswxw4b5m3", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-19T03:24:29Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltxslswxw4b5m3", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-19T04:20:48Z", "cid": "ltxv9xatk87gy", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Wording in 2023 Midterm II 1.d)", "created": "2024-03-19T03:06:04Z", "content": "

The wording here confused me a bit. I understand:
            $$\frac{dy}{dt} = \sin{y^2}$$
$$\implies \frac{dy}{\sin{y^2}} = dt$$

$$\implies \int\frac{dy}{\sin{y^2}} = t + C$$

and that now LHS is a non-elementary integral, therefore there can be no standart representation for LHS. Thus "There is no solution".

Wording here say "no solution" yet isn't the wording ambigious? There can be elementary and non-elementary solutions to ODE, no?

$$y' = e^{y^2}$$

give $$y(t)$$ in terms of the error function, which is non-elementary yet we clearly defined a function as a solution. Can't we define a non-elementary solution to $$\int\frac{dy}{\sin{y^2}}$$? $$\int\sin{y^2}dy$$ already has $$\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}S\left(\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}y\right)$$ as a defined solution.

When something like this comes up should I interpret it as "absolutely no possible $$y$$" or "no standard/elementary $$y$$"?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 105, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-19T03:24:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brayden Chan Carusone", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul6ini0p4au", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T03:24:29Z", "content": "

The phrase "there are no solutions" means that there are no solutions to the initial value problem (i.e. $$y(t)$$ satisfies the differential equation and the two given equalities).

You're right that there are non-elementary functions that are solutions to $$y'(t)=\sin(y(t)^2)$$; the reason why there is no solution is the requirement that both $$y(0)=1$$ and $$y(1)=\pi$$. There is an equilibrium solution between $$1$$ and $$\pi$$ (i.e. a zero to $$\sin(y^2)$$), namely $$y=\sqrt{\pi}$$. Since solutions cannot cross an equilibrium value, it is not possible for $$y(0)=1$$ and $$y(1)=\pi$$ to be true at the same time.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul6ini0p4au"], "children": [], "id": "ltxt9hlxckf374", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "oh wow, I seem a little stupid now.

Didn't even look down to see that they were both constraints on the function.

I just read it as $$y(0)=1$$ and $$y'(1)=\pi$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 927, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-19T04:42:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltxw278ev4z49t", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-19T04:42:47Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "ltxxm6cxcqf49u", "to": "ltxw2784uhx49s", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-19T05:26:19Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltxw2784uhx49s", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-19T05:27:19Z", "cid": "ltxxngis20b195", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "to": "ltxw2784uhx49s", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-19T05:29:17Z", "cid": "ltxxpzzq8in3i0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "E2 Ratio Test", "created": "2024-03-19T04:42:47Z", "content": "

Hi, I'm having a hard time simplifying the expression i get after using the ratio test, would someone be able to show me their work if they did this question or do the problem showing their work?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-19T05:26:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rithvika Kathroju", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lly6utysh6g2ms", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Matthew Desmarais", "endorser": {"k3t0tl7krg32to": 1579115969, "k52y9qu3rg41mr": 1584116403, "global": 1587066490, "k38wsyi5wxb1hz": 1587254389, "ktdwmksib25673": 1634571238, "kt03zgk52gf2vz": 1634684358}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T05:26:19Z", "content": "

The ratio test is actually not the best choice here, but here is the work anyways:

$$\displaystyle \lim\limits_{n\to\infty} \left|\frac{\frac{(2(n+1))!}{\left(e^{-1}(n+1)\right)^{2(n+1)}}}{\frac{(2n)!}{\left(ne^{-1}\right)^{2n}}}\right|$$

$$\displaystyle=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty} \left|(2n+1)(2n+2) \frac{\left(ne^{-1}\right)^{2n}}{\left(ne^{-1}+e^{-1}\right)^{2n} \left(ne^{-1}+e^{-1}\right)^{2}}\right|$$, splitting the exponent $$2n+2$$ into two factors to get a shared power of $$2n$$

$$\displaystyle=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{4n^2+5n+2}{n^2e^{-2}+2ne^{-2}+e^{-2}}\left(\frac{ne^{-1}}{ne^{-1}+e^{-1}}\right)^{2n}\right|$$, expanding the factors without the $$2n$$ exponent

$$\displaystyle= e^2\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{4n^2+5n+2}{n^2+2n+1}\left(\frac{n}{n+1}\right)^{2n}\right|$$, factoring out the $$\frac{1}{e^{-2}}$$ term

$$\displaystyle= e^2\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{4n^2+5n+2}{n^2+2n+1}\right|\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left|\left(1-\frac{1}{n+1}\right)^{2n}\right|$$, separating the limit and dividing the right fraction

$$\displaystyle= 4e^2\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left[\left(1-\frac{1}{n+1}\right)^{n}\right]^2$$, evaluating the left limit, applying exponent rules to rewrite and removing absolute value since always positive

$$\displaystyle= 4e^2\left[\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left(1+\frac{-1}{n+1}\right)^{n+1}\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left(1+\frac{-1}{n+1}\right)^{-1}\right]^2$$, rearranging to get the definition of the exponential function

$$\displaystyle= 4e^2\left[e^{-1}\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\frac{n+1}{n+1-1}\right]^2$$, by definition of $$\exp(-1)$$ and evaluating the reciprocal

$$\displaystyle= 4\left[\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\left(1+\frac{1}{n}\right)\right]^2$$, pulling out the $$e^{-1}$$ and simplifying the fraction

$$\displaystyle= 4[1]^2=4$$, evaluating the limit.

This series thus diverges.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lly6utysh6g2ms", "k07ghb5kyi669r"], "children": [], "id": "ltxxm6cqs8a49t", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "thank you! what would you suggest instead of the ratio test and why?", "created": "2024-03-19T05:27:19Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I would suggest using the divergence test, the summand does not approach zero as $$n\to\infty$$ so we conclude immediately that it diverges.", "created": "2024-03-19T05:29:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Om Patel", "endorser": {"llzfix7j8hc1jc": 1699977470, "llax09p5hb11ji": 1700315642, "global": 1706277223, "lqvcjvs6s457j1": 1706277223, "lq1r9f49qpr3p": 1707622747, "lqxwl2o378b5ny": 1709599913}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ukgc33a41zw", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7ukgc33a41zw"], "id": "ltxxpzzq8in3i0", "updated": "2024-03-19T14:24:22Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltxxngis20b195", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-03-19T05:35:07Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltxw2784uhx49s", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173852187, "default_anonymity": "no"}

null, "id": "lm7ul1y9ok83vg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T05:25:43Z", "content": "You cannot simply plug in/substitute $$\infty$$ as infinity is not a number. Consider n=2, for example.... $$\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}$$ = $$\frac{3^5}{2^{19}}$$ As you can see the $$denominator >> numerator$$ due to the higher exponent on n in the exponential. Thus, $$lim_{n\to\infty}(\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}) = 0$$"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T05:25:16Z", "content": "You cannot simply plug in/substitute $$\infty$$ as infinity is not a number. The proper way to look at this is using limits. Notice here the denominator grows much much faster than the numerator. For example consider... Consider n=2... $$\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}$$ = $$\frac{3^5}{2^{19}}$$ As you can see the $$denominator >> numerator$$ due to the higher exponent on n in the exponential. This discrepancy only gets bigger and bigger as n increases, making the term $$\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}$$ approach 0 as n gets sufficiently large. Thus, $$lim_{n\to\infty}(\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}) = 0$$"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lly6utysh6g2ms", "lm7ul1y9ok83vg"], "children": [], "id": "ltxxktnavys6mx", "config": {"editor": "plain"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltxwb8ii5i36x7", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173853272, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I'm a bit confused about the highlighted steps. How did we get $$\frac{d}{dt}(\frac{1}{t}y)$$?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 123, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-19T05:33:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T13:51:23Z", "content": "The step is an application of the product rule for derivatives, but in reverse: let $$f(x)=y$$ and $$g(x)=\frac{1}{x}$$, so $$\left(f(x)g(x)\right)'=f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x)=y'\frac{1}{t}+y\left(\frac{-1}{t^2}\right)$$. EDIT: Its just the "Integrating factor" method."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T05:33:43Z", "content": "The step is an application of the product rule for derivatives, but in reverse: let $$f(x)=y$$ and $$g(x)=\frac{1}{x}$$, so $$\left(f(x)g(x)\right)'=f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x)=y'\frac{1}{t}+y\left(\frac{-1}{t^2}\right)$$."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T05:33:14Z", "content": "L'étape est une application du règle de produit pour des dérivées en revers: soient $$f(x)=y$$ et $$g(x)=\frac{1}{x}$$, donc $$\left(f(x)g(x)\right)'=f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x)=y'\frac{1}{t}+y\left(\frac{-1}{t^2}\right)$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul3hccbr41t", "jvbpijsmgxy40f"], "children": [], "id": "ltxxv2tf5fm5g5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltxwlju1i9d5rg", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173854361, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Could someone please explain the steps to the solution of this question? I'm a bit confused about the process.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 123, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-19T14:22:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-19T14:22:50Z", "content": "

They took the derivative with respect to $$x$$ to arrive at the second equation:

$$\frac{d}{dx}\left[(y(x))^2\right] = \frac{d}{dx}\left[v(x)-x^2\right] \Rightarrow 2yy'=v'-2x$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7ul3hccbr41t", "jvbpijsmgxy40f"], "children": [], "id": "ltygs596a213kb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I see that now, thank you! From the second to the third equation, where did the v go?", "created": "2024-03-19T14:27:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

From my understanding, I don't think they should have written $$vv'$$ in the second equation at all, since as $$v(x)$$ gets differentiated w/ respect to $$x$$ it goes directly to $$v'(x)$$.

There is no chain rule that is applied to it, like the way $$(y(x))^2$$ goes to $$2yy'$$.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Lecture E4 Part 1 Question.", "created": "2024-03-21T16:56:08Z", "content": "U have a couple questions regarding how we manipulate power series with the following methods:\u00a0


Firstly, what is meant by x E I \u00a0?

Secondly, what mathematical laws can we not break when doing these manipulations?\u00a0
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0102", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 88, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-21T19:50:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Will Nakatsu McCoy", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f0775a5r6op", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-21T19:50:18Z", "content": "

In mathematics, we usually use $$I$$ to denote an arbitrary interval (similar to how we use $$C$$ for an arbitrary constant). Here, the expression $$x\\in I$$ means that these two series converge when $$x$$ is part of an (unknown) interval.

\n

\n

To your second question, we have to follow all the laws of mathematics (don't divide by zero, for example).

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l79f0775a5r6op"], "children": [], "id": "lu1ncyintea58a", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-22T14:36:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-22T14:36:50Z", "content": "The crucial point is the list of manipulation is only valid when the series is convergent to the function $$f(x)$$ and $$g(x)$$ respectively. Interval $$I$$ is an interval over which both convergence hold.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lu2rlp1oj5k1a1", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu1h4zkjlto1mc", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173871719, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0102"], "nr": 946, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-21T17:33:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lu1ih0qk4hj5cr", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-21T17:33:29Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lu1o2s8qkzb4ww", "to": "lu1ih0qd1po5cq", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-21T20:10:22Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lu2q8ube41e6v3", "to": "lu1ih0qd1po5cq", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-22T13:58:51Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PCE E4 part 2 question.", "created": "2024-03-21T17:33:29Z", "content": "When we\u2019re integrating a power series, rather than putting the series in ellipsis notation, subbing in values of n, and integrating each term individually, is it possible to integrate the nth term of the power series and then convert to ellipsis notation?\u00a0

I tried doing so here, but my series is incorrect:\u00a0

Is it a mistake in my math or is it just wrong to do this?\u00a0
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0102", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-21T20:10:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Will Nakatsu McCoy", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l79f0775a5r6op", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-21T20:10:22Z", "content": "

Because of the linearity of integrals ($$\\int_a^b (f+g) = \\int_a^b f + \\int_a^b g$$), it's generally valid to take the integral of the summand and substitute afterwards.

\n

\n

Here you've made a mistake with the algebra; the rule of powers says that $$\\int x^n\\,dx= \\frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}+C$$, thus $$\\int x^{2n}\\,dx =\\frac{x^{2n+1}}{2n+1}+C$$ and not $$\\frac{x^{2n+1}}{2^{n+1}}$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l79f0775a5r6op", "jvbpijsmgxy40f"], "children": [], "id": "lu1o2s8i2co4wv", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-22T13:58:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-22T13:58:51Z", "content": "You can integrate/differentiate the general term. However, I do recommend writing the first few terms to see how they change. When you use the sigma notation, you can also incorporate the change by changing the indexing, which may become confusing."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lu2q8uba4kr6v2", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu1ih0qd1po5cq", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173872803, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"Justification for exchanging a limit and an integral", "created": "2024-03-23T05:57:26Z", "content": "

During Thursday's lecture (section 103), we calculated a series to express $$\ln(1-x)$$ for $$x\in(-1,1)$$ using the following process:

$$\frac{1}{1-t}=\lim\limits_{N\to\infty}\sum_{n=0}^N t^n,\quad t\in]-1,1[$$

$$\int_0^x \frac{1}{1-t}\,dt = \int_0^x \lim\limits_{N\to\infty}\sum_{n=0}^N t^n\, dt, \quad x\in]-1,1[$$

$$-\ln(1-x) = \lim\limits_{N\to\infty} \sum_{n=0}^N \int_0 ^x t^n\,dt$$

$$\ln(1-x) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}.$$

I understand that the first line describes the uniform convergence of $$f_p(t)=\sum_{n=0}^p t^n$$ to $$f(t)=\frac{1}{1-t}$$ on the domain $$(-1,1)$$, and that because of this we can take the definite integral on $$[0,x]$$ if $$x\in(-1, 1)$$ [PfW1] to deduce the second line.

But I don't understand the third line, specifically how we can deduce $$\lim\limits_{N\to\infty}\int_0^x \sum_{n=0}^N t^n\,dt$$ from $$\int_0^x \lim\limits_{N\to\infty} \sum_{n=0}^N t^n\,dt$$. That is, I don't understand why we can change the order of the integral and the limit, as there are cases in which this fails (a math professor named Michael Penn made a video about a counterexample but I can't find it right now). What property(ies) of the mathematical objects allow us to do this? (I would prefer a rigorous answer rather than a heuristic argument).

[PfW1] https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Definite_Integral_of_Limit_of_Uniformly_Convergent_Sequence_of_Integrable_Functions.

I suggest you read up on Lebesque integration, and in particular the dominated convergence theorem. A rigorous argument is presented there.

Slightly less rigorously, in this course we define the integral of a function on a domain $$[a,b]$$ as

$$\int_a^b f(x)dx = \lim_{k \to \inf} \sum_1^k f(x_k)\frac{b-a}{k}$$

In other words, the validity of exchanging a limit and an integral can be phrased in terms of the validity of exchanging 

$$\lim_{n \to \inf} [ \lim_{k \to \inf}] = \lim_{k \to \inf} [ \lim_{n \to \inf}] $$

Slightly less rigorously once more, you can usually exchange a limit and and integral provided that the bounds of the integral do not depend on the limiting variable. For instance this is valid:

$$\lim_{n \to \inf} \int_o^x f_n(x) dx =  \int_o^x \lim_{n \to \inf} f_n(x) dx$$

Notice first, $$ \lim\limits_{N\to\infty}\sum_{n=0}^N t^n = \sum_{n=0}^\infty t^{^n}.$$ And by basic summation properties of integrals... $$\int_0^x \sum_{n=0}^\infty t^n\, dt = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \int_0 ^x t^n\,dt$$ To convince yourself this is true, consider the first few terms up to n=2... LHS = $$\int_0^x \sum_{n=0}^2t^n\, dt$$ = $$\int_0^x (1+t+t^2) dt$$ = $$x+\frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3$$ RHS = $$\sum_{n=0}^2 \int_0 ^x t^n\,dt$$ = $$\sum_{n=0}^2 \int_0 ^x \frac{t^{n+1}}{n+1}\,dt$$ = $$\sum_{n=0}^2 \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}\,dt$$ = $$x+\frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{3}x^3 $$ Thus LHS = RHS", "created": "2024-03-27T01:45:46Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "k07ghb5kyi669r", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 1, "id": "lu959d4ecfe345", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-03-27T02:07:54Z", "config": {"editor": "plain"}}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-28T02:51:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-28T02:54:43Z", "content": "

When I asked this question, I had no intention of answering it myself, but today I've found a simpler theorem according to which the exchange of the limit and the integral is valid (in this case). The theorem is as follows:

If $$\displaystyle (f_{n})_{n=1}^{\infty }$$ is a sequence of Riemann integrable functions defined on a compact interval $${\displaystyle I}$$ which uniformly converge with limit $${\displaystyle f}$$, then $${\displaystyle f}$$ is Riemann integrable and its integral can be computed as the limit of the integrals of the $${\displaystyle f_{n}}$$ : $$\displaystyle \int_I f=\lim\limits_{n\to\infty} \int_I f_n$$.

Since $$\frac{1}{1-t}=\lim\limits_{N\to\infty}\sum_{n=0}^N t^n$$ uniformly for $$t\in(-1,1)$$, the above theorem applies so the interchange is justified.

you can't integrate the terms of two series that are being multiplied. for example, the unintegrated series should distribute into an $$x$$ term that then integrates into an $$x^2$$, but your process has a minimum degree of $$x^3$$.

you need to perform the last step before integrating. alternatively, use the series for $$\sin x$$, and see how the series changes when you divide it by $$x$$ (instead of multiplying two series).

I feel like what I did was illegal but I can't explain why. Also how would you actually solve this problem?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "webwork"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nithura Thevarajah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk96a8bm1dp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 125, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-24T23:58:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xianghan Zhang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lke8u90hrep775", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-24T23:58:42Z", "content": "

The error occurs in your 2nd line; in general we can't conclude that $$\sum f(n)g(n)=\sum[f(n)]\times\sum[g(n)]$$ (let $$f,g:\mathbb{N}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ be functions and let $$n$$ be the indexing variable), even for finite sums.

For example, consider the sum $$\sum_{n=1}^3[n^2\cdot n]=\sum_{n=1}^3 n^3$$. Evaluating it, we calculate an answer of $$1+8+27=36$$. But, if we evaluate the sum $$\sum_{n=1}^3 [n^2]\times\sum_{n=1}^3[n]$$ we calculate a totally different answer: $$[1+4+9]\times[1+2+3]=14\times 6=84\ne 36$$.

In your solution you made this mistake by dividing the sum $$\sum_{n=0}^\infty \left[\frac{(-1)^n}{(2n)!}x^{2n}\right]\left[\frac{1}{4^{2n}}\right]$$ into $$\sum_{n=0}^\infty \left[\frac{(-1)^n}{(2n)! }x^{2n}\right] \times \sum_{n=0}^\infty \left[\frac{1}{4^{2n}}\right] = \sin(x)\times\left(\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{16}}\right)$$.

To solve this problem correctly, I'd advise you to combine terms with the same exponent: $$\frac{(-1)^n}{(2n)!}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{2n}$$. It'll (maybe) give you a hint about the next step.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lke8u90hrep775"], "children": [], "id": "lu66jz293c1zi", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lm7uk96a8bm1dp"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu56drhuh554y3", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173884743, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["lectures_section0101"], "nr": 974, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-27T19:12:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lua6nd7g2on48g", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-27T19:12:25Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lubfyac5mbx5vu", "to": "lua6nd762j48f", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-28T16:20:37Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lubfyhrg86r68o", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-28T16:20:47Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "data": "lubfz3m2d2e7c5", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-28T16:21:15Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Deriving Series", "created": "2024-03-27T19:12:25Z", "content": "
Is there a specific time to re-index? I know in this case it’s because it goes to zero but is there a general case of when re-indexing is necessary ? Lastly, is the reduction of n/n! = 1/(n-1)! only applicable when n=1? (I doubt it matters, just wanted to be sure)


Thanks alot!
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0101", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 73, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-28T16:20:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-28T16:21:15Z", "content": "

1) When to reindex series:

Apriory, your indexing does not matter as long as it generates the correct terms. However, in practice you find yourself wanting to compare series (given two series are they equal) or add or subtract them. In all these instances, it is immensely useful if your indexing matches so that your comparison makes sense, and so that you can add/subtract your series term by term. 

2) How to simplify factorial 

$$\frac{n}{n!}=\frac{n}{n(n-1)(n-2)\cdots(2)(1)}=\frac{1}{(n-1)(n-2)\cdots(2)(1)}=\frac{1}{(n-1)!}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-28T16:20:47Z", "content": "

2) $$\frac{n}{n!}=\frac{n}{n(n-1)(n-2)\cdots(2)(1)}=\frac{1}{(n-1)(n-2)\cdots(2)(1)}=\frac{1}{(n-1)!}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-28T16:20:37Z", "content": "

1) When to reindex series:

Apriory, your indexing does not matter as long as it generates the correct terms. However, in practice you find yourself wanting to compare series (given two series are they equal) or add or subtract them. In all these instances, it is immensely useful if your indexing matches so that your comparison makes sense, and so that you can add/subtract your series term by term. 

2) $$\frac{n}{(n!}=\frac{n}{n(n-1)(n-2)\cdots(2)(1)}=\frac{1}{(n-1)(n-2)\cdots(2)(1)}=\frac{1}{(n-1)!}$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lubfyabxal55vt", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lua6nd762j48f", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173903211, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Could someone the highlighted steps to me? I don't get how they completed the square, as well as where $$a = \frac{1}{2}$$ came from.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["lectures_section0103", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Hanna Bui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7ul3hccbr41t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 84, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-28T02:38:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Mahdi Zeidi", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kjvi78x7tda2lo", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Camelia Karimianpour", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "jvbpijsmgxy40f", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-28T02:38:10Z", "content": "

We know that a perfect square binomial is of the form $$(p\pm q)^2 = p^2 \pm 2pq + q^2$$; here $$p=y$$ and $$q$$ is the unknown (it can be chosen). Using this substitution for $$y$$, the expression $$y^2-y$$ becomes $$p^2+p=p^2+2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)p$$.


If we treat $$\frac{1}{2}$$ as $$q$$ we can write $$p^2+2\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)p=p^2+2pq+q^2-q^2$$ (we add and subtract the same value so this manipulation is valid). Thus we have $$(p+q)^2-q^2=\left(y+\frac{1}{2}\right)-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2=\left(y+\frac{1}{2}\right)-\frac{1}{4}$$.


Translated with DeepL.com (free version)

Taking you one step back from your solution for r(t), trace the step where you had

x^3 + (tx)^3 = Ax*tx, where A is a constant, positive integer.

Here, notice that t must be greater, or equal to zero for the conjecture to hold.

To understand this, notice that the term (tx)^3 is always more negative than the term Ax*tx, provided that t is negative.

Based on this, we can conclude that t must be greater than or equal to zero.

Notice that these relationships can be discovered and manifested by simply tracing each step and linking them to what we already know.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-28T11:23:18Z", "content": "

and based on ur answers

x is 6t/1+t^3

and 

y is 6t^2/1+t^3

so now try putting a negative t value and then seeing what happens to y, it becomes negative too (while x is positive), but that's not what's in the curve, so we know t can't be negative

then try putting zero for t and u get 0,0 based on ur answers, which agrees with the graph, so t can be zero

and I see u noticed that t tends to infinity since u answered c for as t -> inf

so that should prolly give u an idea of where the answer lingers

The polar coordinates for each point are not unique; in general, if we have a point $$P=(r,\theta)$$, letting $$k$$ be any integer, we have $$P=(r,\theta+2k\pi )$$ by rotation and $$P=(-r,\theta+(2k+1)\pi)$$ by reflection. Since a circle of radius $$R$$ includes any point of the form $$(R,\phi)$$ where $$\phi\in\mathbb{R}$$ is any angle and $$(R,\theta)=(-R,\theta+\pi)$$ is of this form, we conclude that any point of the form $$(R,\phi)$$ or $$(-R,\phi)$$ is part of the circle.

Original: I'm also wondering this, but wouldn't this not help since the negatives cancel out regardless?

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T06:50:34Z", "content": "

The polar coordinates for each point are not unique; in general, if we have a point $$P=(r,\theta)$$, letting $$k$$ be any integer, we have $$P=(r,\theta+2k\pi )$$ by rotation and $$P=(-r,\theta+(2k+1)\pi)$$ by reflection. Since a circle of radius $$R$$ includes any point of the form $$(R,\phi)$$ where $$\phi\in\mathbb{R}$$ is any angle and $$(R,\theta)=(-R,\theta+\pi)$$ is of this form, we conclude that any point $$(R,\phi)$$ and $$(-R,\phi)$$ is part of the circle.

Original: I'm also wondering this, but wouldn't this not help since the negatives cancel out regardless?
