{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 1002, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-30T23:17:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luepqe8ya16ui", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-30T23:17:44Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "data": "lugm0knhh6r7lb", "to": "luepqe8p7bkuh", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-01T07:09:13Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luepqe8p7bkuh", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-01T07:11:51Z", "cid": "lugm3yszbz241q", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2020 - Essay Questions - 2", "created": "2024-03-30T23:17:44Z", "content": "

Hi i solved part a by solving the ODE but then saw that part b asked me what method I would use to solve it. So i assume i didn't need to actually solve it to do part a, so how should i have done it?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T07:09:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mark Samuel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7uk1qrnpwn0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm7ukqff3d82v1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T07:09:13Z", "content": "

To solve part a) without finding the exact solution, simply note that $$b$$ determines where the equilibrium solution lies because $$(b-y)$$ is the only root in the equation. Since we want to have equilibrium at $$y=10^6$$, it follows that a root must lie at $$y=10^6$$, so $$b=10^6$$.

To choose the sign of $$a$$, we know that the function increases from $$y=0$$ to $$y=10^6$$, so the derivative $$y'$$ must be positive. When $$y\in[0,10^6)$$ we know that $$(b-y)=(10^6-y)>0$$, so $$a>0$$ too.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7uk1qrnpwn0"], "children": [], "id": "lugm0kn866n7la", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Ah it’s much simpler than I thought, thank you", "created": "2024-04-01T07:11:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lugm3yszbz241q", "updated": "2024-04-01T07:11:55Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luepqe8p7bkuh", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173933792, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 1003, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-31T01:17:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lueu0vce1s02ub", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-31T01:17:51Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm15xdyfa1i7c0", "data": "luhbdb53pvd53m", "to": "lueu0vc6jep2ua", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-01T18:58:57Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm15xdyfa1i7c0", "data": "luhbe7h1vak73u", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-01T18:59:39Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Difference between chain ruling and dividing derivatives for Parametric curves", "created": "2024-03-31T01:17:51Z", "content": "I'm not sure if I missed this in lectures, but for parametric curves, instead of doing y'(t)/x'(t) could you instead do dy/dt*dt/dx? It'll probably just be a lot more annoying in more scenarios considering how you might have to implicitly differentiate the function, but is it still valid? Is there any scenario where you cannot use y'(t)/x'(t) (aside from like x'(t) = 0) or is that a general formula?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 75, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T18:58:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lm15xdyfa1i7c0", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T18:59:39Z", "content": "dy/dt is equivalent to y'(t) and dx/dt is equivalent to x'(t). Doing dy/dt * dt/dx is equivalent to dy/dt / dx/dt where dx/dt is not zero"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lm15xdyfa1i7c0", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T18:58:57Z", "content": "dy/dt is equivalent to y'(t) and dx/dt is equivalent to x'(t)"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luhbdb4x7zh53l", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lueu0vc6jep2ua", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1716173934876, "default_anonymity": "no"}

\n

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 1010, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-31T21:01:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 1, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lug0aehvyco62k", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-31T21:01:00Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lug1lt74l4mic", "to": "lug0aehng1j62g", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-31T21:37:52Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lug0aehng1j62g", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-31T21:40:09Z", "cid": "lug1or58v073ux", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lug0aehng1j62g", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-31T22:22:47Z", "cid": "lug37kmc7xg7jx", "uid_a": "a_2"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Midterm Question 3 Part C Question", "created": "2024-03-31T21:01:00Z", "content": "

Hi, I was just going over the answer key for the midterm and I was confused by one of the answers.

Here it asks for the series of a and if it converges, but it uses the ratio test. However, I was confused by how it uses the ratio test because it clearly states in part a that we cannot use the ratio test to test the convergence.
